Not for Redistribution GUATEMALA (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Guatemala is the Guatemalan Quetzal. Guatemala maintains a unified, interbank exchange system under which the exchange rate of the quetzal is allowed to be determined in response to market forces. Intervention by the Bank of Guatemala is limited to maintaining orderly de- velopments in the market. The Bank of Guatemala buys and sells foreign exchange at the prevailing interbank market rate and sets a daily reference rate that is used for government transactions and for calculating foreign trade taxes. The reference rate is based on the weighted average of the exchange rate of the previous week or, in case the change in the exchange rate on any one day exceeds Q 0.05 per US$1, the prevailing rate on the previous day. On December 29,1989, the buying and selling rates of the Bank of Guatemala in terms of the U.S. dollar were Q 3.44 - US$1 and Q 3.48 = US$1, respectively. Certain foreign exchange operations of the Bank of Guatemala (e.g., servicing of its external debt disbursed before June 6, 1986), which have no eco- nomic effect, are conducted at an accounting ex- change rate of Q1 = US$1. Buying and selling rates for certain currencies other than the U.S. dollar1 are officially quoted, mainly on the basis of their rates in the New York market. The central bank does not issue new exchange rate guarantees, but it honors guarantees granted prior to end October 1989. There are no other arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk operating in the official or the commercial banking sector. On January 27, 1947, Guatemala formally ac- cepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control The Foreign Exchange Department of the Bank of Guatemala is in charge of administering the Transi- tional Law on the Foreign Exchange Regime. For- eign exchange transactions of the public sector are carried out exclusively through the Bank of Guatemala; those of the private sector are made through banks authorized by the Monetary Board. 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, deut- sche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Mexican pesos, Netherland guilders, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, and Swiss francs. Exports of goods must be registered in the Foreign Exchange Department to guarantee repatriation of the corresponding foreign exchange proceeds. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency In practice, most transactions in foreign exchange are denominated in U.S. dollars. Transactions with other Central American countries are settled in U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports of most goods are unrestricted and do not require registration or a license. Import licenses issued by the Ministry of Economy are required for imports of maps of Guatemala, coffee beans and coffee plants, explosives, lead, poultry, milk, eggs, sugar, wheat flour, basic food grains, cottonseed, tallow, and a few other goods. Imports of cocoa are prohibited from all sources. Foreign exchange for import payments may be purchased at the inter- bank exchange market rate. Petroleum is imported at a preferential rate of exchange. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Invisible transactions relating to travel outside the country, school fees, study expenses, international credit card payments, and others are permitted without restriction. Exports and Export Proceeds Certain exports are subject to licenses issued by the Ministry of Economy. Exports of a few other items are prohibited, including the export of gold (unless the Bank of Guatemala issues a special ex- port license) and silver in any form. Travelers may, however, take out up to Q 25 in silver coins that are legal tender in foreign countries. Exporters must obtain an export permit issued by the Foreign Exchange Department before the Guatemalan customs can authorize shipment of the merchandise; the granting of export permits is con- tingent on agreement to sell export proceeds to the Bank of Guatemala or an authorized bank within 45 days of the date of issuance. In the case of exports to Central America, there are clearing arrangements among the central banks to settle payments in their 190 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution GUATEMALA 191 own national currencies, Derecho de Importation Centroamericana (DICA), U.S. dollars, or barter. Certain exports are subject to export taxes, which are planned to be abolished by the end of March 1990. Capital All capital transactions take place without limita- tions. All investment by foreign or foreign- controlled companies in the construction of private housing in Guatemala requires the prior approval of the Ministry of Economy. Investment in the petro- leum sector is governed by special legislation. Gold The Bank of Guatemala may buy and sell gold in coins or bullion either directly or through the banks, and is entitled to require the surrender, directly or through authorized banks, of the gold holdings of any resident. The Bank sells gold to domestic artis- tic or industrial users, in accordance with directives of the Monetary Board. The export of gold is pro- hibited except when the Bank of Guatemala issues a special export license. Gold is imported only by the Bank of Guatemala. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement October 25. The Bank of Guatemala ceased to provide exchange rate guarantees for import letters of credit. November 3. A floating exchange rate system was introduced. The Bank of Guatemala ceased to provide exchange rate guarantees for prefinancing of exports. Imports and Import Payments January 11. Prior registration of imports with the Bank of Guatemala was no longer required. November 18. The first stage of a reform of the customs tariff regime was introduced, whereby the customs tariffs on some 240 items, accounting for about 10 percent of the items subject to customs tariffs, were reduced to the range of 2-37 percent from the range of 0-150 percent. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution GUINEA (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Guinea is the Guinean Franc. Guinea maintains a floating exchange rate system, under which the exchange rate against the U.S. dollar is set in weekly fixing sessions. The private sector and public enterprises, through the inter- mediation of commercial banks, may sell and pur- chase foreign exchange for all import and invisible payments, except for limitations placed on pur- chases for tourist travel and the transfer abroad of salaries by nonresident workers. All other public sector transactions take place at the latest fixing rate. The exchange rate of the Guinean franc is quoted in terms of the U.S. dollar; the rates for other curren- cies are determined on the basis of their U.S. dollar rates in international markets. The exchange rate for the CFA franc results from the relationship between this currency and the French franc. Settlements un- der the bilateral payments agreement with the Peo- ple's Republic of China are effected in renminbi at the rate resulting from the current GF/U.S. dollar and U.S. dollar/yuan rates. On December 29, 1989, the official exchange rate for the U.S. dollar was GF 620.00 per US$1. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk operating in the official or the commercial banking sector. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Cen- tral Bank, which is under the direct supervision of the presidency. The Bank has not delegated any of its exchange control powers. All settlements with foreign countries, including payments for imports, require approval by the Exchange Department of the Central Bank. Arrears are maintained with re- spect to external payments. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of transactions covered by bilateral payments agreements are made in curren- cies prescribed by, and through accounts estab- lished under, the provisions of the agreements.1 Settlements with the Central Bank of West African States (for Benin, Burkina Faso, Cote d'lvoire, Mali, Niger, Senegal, and Togo) and The Gambia, Ghana, 1 Guinea maintains bilateral payments agreements with the People's Republic of China, Cuba, and Viet Nam; all agreements are inoperative. Guinea-Bissau, Liberia, Mauritania, Nigeria, and Sierra Leone are normally made through the West African Clearing House. Settlements with other countries are made in designated convertible cur- rencies quoted by the Central Bank. All current transactions effected in Guinea must be settled in Guinean francs. Resident Foreign Currency Accounts The opening of deposit accounts in foreign cur- rency by residents at the domestic commercial banks is subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank. Nonresident Accounts There are two types of nonresident accounts: Nonresident Transferable Accounts in Foreign Cur- rencies, and Nonresident Accounts in Guinean Francs. The opening of a nonresident account is subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank. Convertible Accounts Accounts in convertible Guinean francs may be opened by residents and nonresidents. Such ac- counts are to be credited with deposits in foreign exchange, irrespective of its origin. Exporters may hold up to 25 percent of their foreign exchange proceeds in convertible Guinean francs. Such ac- counts may be debited freely and converted by com- mercial banks into foreign currencies without prior authorization from the Central Bank. These ac- counts carry an interest premium of 2 percentage points over deposit accounts in Guinean francs. Imports and Import Payments Almost all products may be freely imported into Guinea (except armaments, munitions, and narco- tics). Petroleum products may be imported only by the public sector. Mining companies may, however, import crude oil directly. All imports require authorization, which is granted by the commercial banks on behalf of the Central Bank. There are two types of authorization: that given for imports with access to foreign ex- change provided at rates determined during weekly fixing sessions, and that given for imports financed with own foreign exchange (autorisation sans achat de devises). To obtain authorization, importers are re- quired to fill out a form (descriptif d'importation), on 192 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution GUINEA 193 which they must provide information on products to be imported, their prices, and the terms of financing. For imports with access to the auction market, authorization is given only after the prices and quality of products and the terms of financing (in the case of import credits) are verified. Requests for foreign exchange must be submitted through com- mercial banks at the weekly fixing sessions. Certain imports are effected outside the auction system. This category comprises goods for which foreign exchange is derived from sources other than the official foreign exchange resources of Guinea and mainly covers imports by four "mixed-economy companies" (the Friguia Company; the Guinea Baux- ite Company; AREDOR, the diamond company; and AUG, the gold company) and foreign embassies. All commodities are subject to customs tariffs. Rice is subject to a 10 percent turnover tax; a 5 per- cent tariff is levied on certain primary foodstuffs, including edible oils, wheat flour, sugar, meat, and fowl; all other imports are subject to a 10 percent tariff. In addition, a surtax of 20 percent or 30 per- cent is imposed on all luxury goods, and a surtax of 50-130 percent is levied on nonalcoholic beverages and certain wine and spirits. The import tariff pay- able by the two mixed enterprises in the mining sector is subject to special agreements. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles through the official foreign exchange market require the authorization of the Central Bank. Payments for freight and insur- ance in connection with imports are authorized as part of the import operation. No official exchange is granted for other types of insurance with com- panies abroad. Allocations for tourism, other than for the purchase of airline tickets, are limited to US$800 a person a trip, with a maximum of four trips a calendar year; each application is considered individually. Government officials on official mis- sions are permitted an allowance of US$90 a day. In cases of serious illness, when a doctor's certificate is submitted, residents may be granted foreign ex- change for medical care abroad or they may be per- mitted to transfer exchange for the care of relatives receiving medical treatment abroad. Payments for family support through the official market may be made up to monthly amounts deter- mined on the merits of the case; for officially recog- nized study abroad, the allocation is the equivalent of the amount of a government scholarship—that is, US$100 a month —but students beginning their studies abroad are granted an additional foreign exchange allowance of up to US$150. The Investment Law of 1985 (as amended in 1987) guarantees that profits earned from approved for- eign investments may be transferred abroad, and that certified dividends and royalties may be trans- ferred in full. It also provides for certain tax incen- tives. The transfer abroad of salaries by expatriate workers is authorized up to a limit of 50 percent of base earnings, and only for those contracts ap- proved by the Ministry of Labor. The export of Gui- nean currency is limited to GF 5,000 a person a trip. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require domiciliation with a commer- cial bank and submission of export description in order to (1) permit the Treasury to levy certain du- ties (e.g., special taxes payable in foreign exchange are levied on the volume of bauxite and alumina exported); (2) prevent shortages of goods needed for domestic consumption; and (3) prevent the ex- port of capital. For the following commodities, special authoriza- tion from designated agencies is required: wild ani- mals (dead or alive), edible animals, articles of his- toric or ethnographic interest, jewelry, articles made of precious metals, and plants and seeds. Foreign planters may be granted special transfer privileges related to the quantity of pineapples, ba- nanas, or citrus fruits exported, and private traders may also be permitted to retain a part of their export proceeds in order to finance authorized imports. The mixed-economy companies are allowed to re- tain their export proceeds abroad, to pay for their imports and operating requirements, and to service their external debt. Proceeds from Invisibles In principle, exchange proceeds accruing to resi- dents in respect of invisibles must be surrendered. The import of foreign bank notes and traveler's checks is permitted freely, subject to declaration on entry; however, residents must surrender both to commercial banks within 15 days, with an option for deposit in resident foreign currency accounts. Non- resident travelers may re-export the foreign ex- change they declared upon entry. The import of Guinean currency is limited to GF 5,000 a traveler a trip. Capital All capital transfers through the official market require authorization. Outward capital transfers by Guinean nationals through the official market are prohibited. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 194 GUINEA The Investment Law of 1985 provides guarantees against the nationalization of foreign investments in the industrial and mining sectors. It also provides for preferential tax and customs treatment applica- ble to foreign investments and for the transfer of profits, interest, amortization, and liquidation pro- ceeds of such investments. Small and medium-size enterprises in which at least GF 50 million is in- vested over a three-year period may receive import tax reductions and exemptions from other taxes for a period of 8 to 10 years. Exemptions for up to 15 years may be granted on long-term investments of par- ticular importance to the economy. The minimum foreign investment in Guinean enterprises is GF 10 million. Guinean nationals must have controlling interests in enterprises requiring foreign invest- ment of GF 10 million to GF 50 million. Gold The Central Bank purchases gold from individ- uals, who may choose to be paid in Guinean francs or up to 50 percent in foreign currency and the rest in local currency. The proceeds from gold sales in foreign currencies may be credited to the convert- ible acounts in Guinean francs, and the funds with- drawn from these accounts may be used only for import payments. Guinea has four issues of commemorative gold coins, which are legal tender. Furthermore, resi- dents may hold and acquire gold coins in Guinea for numismatic purposes. With these exceptions, resi- dents other than the monetary authorities and au- thorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than artisanal gold or jewelry, at home or abroad. Changes During 1989 Imports and Import Payments February 1. Prior authorization of import declara- tions by the Central Bank was no longer required. March 13. The following modifications were made in the import tax regime: (1) rice was subject to a 10 percent turnover tax; (2) imports of lemonades, carbonated beverages, and other nonalcoholic bev- erages were subject to a surtax of 50 percent; and (3) the rate of surtax applicable to wine and spirits was raised to 130 percent from 40 percent. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution GUINEA-BISSAU (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Guinea-Bissau is the Guinea- Bissau Peso. Guinea-Bissau follows a flexible ex- change rate policy under which the exchange rate of the Guinea-Bissau peso in terms of the SDR is ad- justed at relatively short intervals on the basis of estimated domestic price developments. Daily buy- ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar, the inter- vention currency, and for other foreign currencies are fixed within margins of 2.25 percent of the SDR rate for the Guinea-Bissau peso. On December 29, 1989, the official exchange rate for the U.S. dollar was PG 1,986.0 per US$1. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk in the official or the com- mercial banking sector. Administration of Control Foreign exchange transactions are under the con- trol of the National Bank of Guinea-Bissau (the cen- tral bank). Residents must declare to the central bank all their physical assets and foreign exchange holdings abroad. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency Settlements with all foreign countries must be made in foreign currency. The central bank may prescribe the currency in which export earnings are to be received. Guinea-Bissau maintains a bilateral payments agreement with Algeria, but this agree- ment has been inoperative since 1981. Settlements with the Central Bank of West African States (for Benin, Burkina Faso, Cote d'lvoire, Mali, Niger, Senegal, and Togo) and The Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Liberia, Mauritania, Nigeria, and Sierra Leone are normally made through the West African Clearing House. Imports and Import Payments Before February 1989, all imports were subject to prior licensing. Licenses were issued by the Minis- try of Economic Coordination, Commerce, and Tourism in line with availability of foreign exchange and on the basis of a program agreed between the central bank and the Ministry. Effective February 1, 1989, an open general license system was intro- duced. Under the new system, import licenses are automatically issued upon request, after verification of the invoiced prices, except for petroleum imports and products on a negative list. Imports of petro- leum products are a state monopoly. Private sector importers with valid import licenses may freely provide their foreign exchange to finance their imports. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require the prior ap- proval of the Committee of Foreign Exchange Con- trol. Foreign exchange allocations for many pay- ments for invisibles, including those for tourism, for purchases of stocks, bonds, and real estate, and for profit remittances, have been temporarily sus- pended. Transfers of pension payments are autho- rized in accordance with specific criteria. Although no foreign exchange may be purchased for tourism, airplane tickets can be bought with domestic cur- rency. Airline companies may transfer in foreign exchange the difference between their payments and receipts in Guinea-Bissau pesos. These trans- fers are approved on an ad hoc basis. Foreign exchange allowances for business travel are limited to the equivalent of PG 50,000 a trip. For study abroad, foreign exchange is granted up to the equivalent of PG 17,100 each month (PG 13,800 for high school students). Allowances for travel for health reasons are permitted up to the equivalent of PG 80,000. Remittances to close relatives (parents and children) living abroad are permitted. Foreign travelers may take out any remaining foreign cur- rency declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require an export license. Only export- ers registered with the Ministry of Economic Coor- dination, Commerce, and Tourism may obtain ex- port licenses, which are granted automatically in most cases. Until August 1986, exports of ground- nuts and cashew nuts were reserved for the Govern- ment and were effected by two state companies, the People's Stores and SOCOMIM. Other products ex- ported solely by the Government included palm 195 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 196 GUINEA-BISSAU kernels, sawn wood and logs, shrimp, fish, beer, nonalcoholic beverages, groundnut oil, and par- quet flooring. On August 13,1986, the Government authorized the private sector to engage in exportation of any product. Exporters are allowed to retain up to 50 percent of proceeds to pay for eligible merchan- dise imports. Since May 4, 1987, foreign exchange earnings may be surrendered to the banking system without their sources being identified. Private ex- porters of nontraditional products are authorized to use up to the equivalent of their total foreign ex- change receipts, less an export duty, to pay for mer- chandise imports. All exports are subject to a general customs fee of 1 percent. During 1987, the effective export tax rate on cashew nuts was reduced in stages, to 46 percent from 80 percent, ad valorem, and all other export taxes were abolished. The export tax on cashew nuts was further reduced to 41 percent in 1988 and to 34 percent in 1989. A special regime applies to ex- ports destined for countries of the Economic Com- munity of West African States (ECOWAS); they are exempt from the 1 percent general customs fee. Proceeds from Invisibles Travelers may bring in any amount of foreign currency. Foreign airline companies must cover the excess of their expenditures over revenues in Guinea-Bissau pesos by transfers from abroad or by the sale of their foreign exchange receipts for Guinea-Bissau pesos. All proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered to the central bank. Capital Foreign investment operations are guided by the Investment Code introduced in 1980. Under this Code, which is being reviewed, exchange control is exercised over capital receipts and payments. Capi- tal transfers associated with emigration are autho- rized by "transitional norms" within a monthly limit of PG 50,000 and up to 20 percent of total taxable income earned during a period of not more than ten years. At present, however, such transfers are suspended. Gold Exports and imports of gold are prohibited, ex- cept when authorized by the head of state and the Ministry of Finance. Changes During 1989 Imports and Import Payments February 1. An open general license system was introduced, under which all imports were allowed without restriction, with the exception of petroleum and products on a negative list. February 1. Price controls on sugar, cooking oil, and fertilizers imported by the public sector were abolished. April 1. The state import monopoly on cereal was abolished. Exports and Export Proceeds January 1. The rate of export tax on cashew nuts was reduced to 34 percent ad valorem. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution GUYANA (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Guyana is the Guyana Dollar. Although the exchange rate of the Guyana dollar is officially determined on the basis of its fixed rela- tionship to a basket of currencies,1 in practice it is adjusted to maintain a certain level against the U.S. dollar. The intervention currency of the Guyana dol- lar is the U.S. dollar. Effective April 1, 1989, the official rate for the Guyana dollar, which is applica- ble to all foreign exchange transactions, was changed from G$10.0 = US$1 to G$33.0 = US$1. Buying and selling rates for certain other curren- cies2 are also officially quoted, with daily quotations based on the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. The Bank of Guyana (the central bank) charges commissions at different rates on the purchase and sale of the officially quoted currencies. There are no taxes or subsidies on pur- chases or sales of foreign exchange. The only arrangement for forward cover against exchange risk operates in the official sector in re- spect of exchange rate guarantees that are provided to certain deposits in the blocked accounts. (See section on Nonresident Accounts, below.) Guyana formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from December 27, 1966. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Minis- ter of Finance who has entrusted its administration to the Bank of Guyana. Authority for approving certain current payments up to specified amounts is delegated, in principle, to the banks authorized for this purpose; all other payments require the approval of the Bank of Guyana. The Ministry of Trade and Consumer Protection is responsible for issuing import and export licenses, but import li- censes involving use of official foreign exchange require the endorsement of the Bank of Guyana. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency Exchange control applies to all countries, and all currencies other than the Guyana dollar are consid- ered foreign currencies. Authorized payments, in- cluding payments for imports, by residents of Guyana to residents of countries outside Guyana may be made in any foreign currency or in Guyana dollars to the credit of an External Account in Guyana. Receipts from countries outside Guyana may be obtained in any foreign currency (in any listed specified currency3 for export proceeds) or in Guyana dollars from an External Account. Nonresident Accounts There are two categories of accounts for persons who are not residents of Guyana: External Accounts and Blocked Accounts. External Accounts may be opened, with exchange control approval, for persons resident outside Guyana. They may be credited freely with all autho- rized payments by residents of Guyana to nonresi- dents and with transfers from other External Ac- counts; other credits require approval. They may be debited freely for payments for any purpose to resi- dents of any country, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for withdrawals by the account holder while he is in Guyana; other debits require approval. Blocked Accounts may, in principle, be credited with funds that are not placed at the free disposal of nonresidents (e.g., certain capital proceeds); these accounts may be debited for certain authorized pay- ments, including the purchase of approved se- curities. Since mid-1978 Blocked Accounts have been used to hold domestic currency deposits equivalent in value to pending applications for for- eign exchange. Such deposits carry a market-related interest rate. The Bank of Guyana provides full ex- change rate guarantee for deposits made before the devaluation of January 1984, partial exchange rate guarantee (at the rate of G$5.0 = US$1) for deposits made between January 1984 (after devaluation) and end-January 1987, partial exchange rate guarantee (at the rate of G$10 = US$1) for deposits made 1 Since January 1984, the currency basket has been defined to include pounds sterling, deutsche mark, Japanese yen, French francs, and Netherlands guilders. 2Barbados dollars, Canadian dollars, Eastern Caribbean dol- lars, Jamaica dollars, pounds sterling, and Trinidad and Tobago dollars. 3Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 197 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 198 GUYANA between January 1987 and end-March 1989, and no exchange rate guarantee for the deposits made after March 1989. Imports and Import Payments All imports from or transiting South Africa are prohibited. Imports of certain products are also pro- hibited from all sources. Import prohibitions are currently applicable only to certain categories of food items. Permissible imports are subject to indi- vidual licensing, but the following commodities are exempted: passengers' baggage, household effects and personal effects, bona fide patterns and sam- ples that have a stipulated f .o .b. value, parcel post items of a certain value imported by individuals, and gifts subject to certain conditions. Effective October 1,1988, import licenses are not required for goods originating and consigned from CARICOM states. Import licenses are granted on a priority basis, as follows: (1) petroleum products; (2) raw materials for the manufacture of essential items; (3) essential items; (4) raw materials for manufacturers serving the export markets and the essential services in industry; (5) equipment and materials for sawmills in the timber industry; (6) commodities for hatch- eries; (7) spare parts; (8) importation by interna- tional organizations and diplomatic personnel; and (9) drugs. However, an application for an import license will not normally be approved for com- modities when similar ones are produced locally and at reasonable levels to supply domestic needs or sustain exportation. Import licenses are issued in respect of certain specified commodities only to the government cor- poration that has been identified to procure them centrally. When the responsibility of handling im- ports of any commodity has been given to a single government agency with a view to eliminating du- plication of ordering between such agencies, the relevant licenses are issued only to that corporation. A similar course of action is adopted when stan- dardization of commodities is involved. As a gen- eral rule, licenses are issued only to government corporations for the procurement of supplies for the retail and distributive sectors of the economy on a national, rather than a local, basis. Licenses are not normally made available to private sector concerns or individuals for goods to be disposed of by retail trade, other than to dealers in spare parts. Import licenses continue to be approved for specialized re- quirements of government and private concerns connected with sugar, bauxite, rice, timber, and manufacturing industries, as the case may be. There are no import quotas, but the granting of import licenses is subject in large measure to the availability of foreign exchange. All applications for foreign exchange must be accompanied by a domes- tic currency deposit of equivalent value, to be held in blocked accounts with commercial banks. Com- mercial banks are required to maintain a 100 percent reserve requirement against these deposits at the Bank of Guyana. In general, import transactions not involving use of official foreign exchange (i.e., "no-foreign cur- rency" import transactions) are permitted without restriction; most imports of consumer goods take place on this basis. On June 1,1988, import licenses with respect to no-foreign currency import transac- tions for the following goods were abolished: (1) goods imported by individuals for personal use; (2) machinery and equipment to be used in pursuit of self-employment; and (3) goods to be used by noncommercial, nonagricultural, nonindustrial, or social organizations. Since September 1988, import licenses for the remaining categories of no-foreign currency imports are granted automatically if the transactions are bona fide and the documentary requirements are met. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries require approval. The basic annual exchange allocation for tourist travel is G$2,475 a person and is not cumula- tive. The allocation for education depends on each circumstance and is granted in terms of foreign currency needs. Resident and nonresident travelers are subject on departure to an exit tax of C$165 a person. Persons traveling abroad may take with them Guyana currency notes not exceeding C$200; these notes do not form part of any allotment of exchange for travel. The equivalent of up to G$2,475 may be taken out in actual currency notes as part of the foreign exchange allowance for foreign travel. Non- resident travelers may, within one month of their last entry, freely take out any foreign currency notes declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to South Africa are prohibited. Sugar may be exported only by the Guyana Sugar Corpo- ration, and bauxite and alumina, only by the Guyana Mining Enterprise Limited. Certain other exports are also channeled through official agen- cies. Rice may be imported by the Guyana Rice Export Board and the private sector. Most exports do not require export licenses, but transactions are ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution GUYANA 199 supervised by the Bank of Guyana and the Customs and Excise Department to ensure that the exchange proceeds are repatriated and, if obtained in listed specified currencies (see footnote 2), surrendered. Exchange control forms have to be completed for all exports exceeding C$200 in value. A foreign ex- change retention scheme permits exporters to retain a certain percentage of export proceeds. The reten- tion ratio is 100 percent for bauxite, 15 percent for sugar, and 10 percent for other products. Retained foreign exchange may be used relatively liberally for imports of inputs and external debt servicing by exporters. Proceeds from Invisibles Specified currencies (see footnote 2) received on account of invisibles must be sold to an authorized bank, but other currencies may be retained by the recipient. Travelers may bring in freely any amount in foreign bank notes; domestic bank notes up to a value of C$200 may be brought in by returning travelers only. Capital Private investment, both foreign and domestic, is governed by the Private Investment Code of 1979. Foreign investors must apply to the Bank of Guyana for approved status for new investments at the time of investment in order to be able to repatriate capi- tal. Such approval is normally given for direct in- vestments in new projects that would benefit the balance of payments or the economy of Guyana; "approved status" assures that profits may be remit- ted, and that upon liquidation of the investment, the proceeds, including any capital increments after payment of all taxes, may be repatriated in full in the currency of the original investment. Foreign-based companies and their subsidiaries can borrow in Guyana only with the express approval of the Bank of Guyana. The export of capital by residents is not normally permitted. Listed specified currencies (see footnote 2) obtained by residents through capital transac- tions must be surrendered to an authorized bank, but other currencies may be retained by the recip- ient. Emigrants of Guyanese nationality may not transfer abroad any part of their capital assets other than a settling-in allowance of C$825 for each mem- ber of a family unit; emigrants of foreign nationality may export all declared capital assets, an amount of C$50,000 a family unit at the time of emigration, and C$30,000 in each successive calendar year. Borrowing from nonresidents requires exchange control approval. However, publicly owned enter- prises are encouraged to borrow abroad for the fi- nancing of specific projects and in some instances for working capital purposes. Since mid-1979 any borrowing by a public sector corporation is sub- ject to prior approval by the Government Debt Committee. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Guyana for numismatic purposes, and also jewelry. With these exceptions, residents other than the monetary authorities, authorized dealers, pro- ducers of gold, and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form, at home or abroad, without special permission. Im- ports and exports of gold in any form by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, authorized dealers, producers of gold, and industrial users require li- censes issued by the Ministry of Trade. Residents traveling abroad are allowed to take out with them jewelry up to a value of G$12,000, C$9,000, and C$3,000 for women, men, and children under 12 years of age, respectively. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement April 1. The exchange rate system was unified, with the abolishments of the bank window rate and the special rates for gold and diamond, and the official rate was changed from G$10.0 = US$1 to G$33.0 = US$1. November 28. An act providing for the licensing of authorized dealers to buy and sell foreign curren- cies at freely determined rates was promulgated. (The act would come into effect by the order of the Minister of Finance.) Exports and Export Proceeds March 31. The retention ratios under the foreign exchange retention scheme were unified to 10 per- cent for all exporters other than bauxite. August 1. The retention percentage under the for- eign exchange retention scheme for the sugar in- dustry was raised to 15 percent. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution HAITI (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Haiti is the Haitian Gourde, the external value of which is defined in terms of the SDR, but in such a way as to preserve the relation- ship of G 5 = US$1. Both the official buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar are G 5 = US$1. The U.S. dollar circulates freely and is generally ac- cepted in Haiti. Commercial banks quote buying and selling rates for certain other currencies, based on the buying and selling rates of the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. Sales of foreign exchange are sub- ject to an average local tax of 0.03 percent. The official rate applies, on the receipts side, to (1) proceeds from exports of sugar, (2) foreign ex- change receipts of public enterprises, (3) official external loans and grants and transfers received by exchange houses, (4) 50 percent of all other export proceeds, and (5) 50 percent of all foreign exchange received by maritime agencies and nongovernmen- tal organizations. The official rate applies, on the payments side, to (1) public debt-service payments, (2) payments for imports of petroleum products, (3) sugar, (4) wheat, and (5) certain public sector payments. A different rate, established freely in a parallel mar- ket, consisting of a limited number of authorized ex- change houses, is used for all other transactions. On December 29, 1989, the exchange rate in this market was in the range of G 7.45-G 7.60 per US$1. Commercial banks may open accounts in foreign exchange in favor of residents; these accounts may not be credited with export proceeds, with transfers from abroad received by exchange houses, or with receipts by maritime agencies and nongovernmen- tal organizations. Haiti formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2,3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from December 22, 1953. Administration of Control The administration of the foreign exchange sys- tem is under the control of the Bank of the Republic of Haiti (the central bank). The tax code provides for a penalty, payable to the tax authorities, equal to 20 percent of any commercial foreign exchange transaction not conducted through a bank estab- lished in Haiti.1 Aside from this requirement, there aAs of the end of 1989, the tax had not been enforced. is no exchange control, and there are no obligations prescribing the method or currency for payments to or from nonresidents. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Imports and Import Payments Seven products (beans, maize, millet, rice, sugar, chicken parts, and pork) are subject to licensing requirements without quantitative restrictions. By a decree of February 10, 1987, a new tariff structure was introduced that eliminated all specific duties and established new ad valorem tariff rates of be- tween zero and 40 percent, with the exception of five products (rice, maize, millet, flour, and gas- oline). Gasoline is subject to a tariff of 57.8 percent, and rice, maize, millet, and flour are subject to a rate of 50 percent. The average tariff rate is about 20 per- cent, with the tariffs on equipment, raw materials, and some inputs at 10 percent or lower. Phar- maceutical imports are exempt from import duties. Customs tariffs and the value-added tax applicable to most imports are calculated on the basis of a conversion rate of exchange that is 30 percent above (in terms of gourdes) the official exchange rate. All imports, except for inputs used by certain export industries, are subject to a consular fee of 3 percent. The fee is payable in Haiti. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of agricultural products require prior au- thorization from the Ministry of Commerce and In- dustry. Such authorization is usually granted freely but may be withheld when domestic supplies are low. In accordance with a decree of July 7,1989, the export proceeds and foreign exchange receipts of maritime agencies and nongovernmental organiza- tions are required to be surrendered to the central bank through the commercial banks. Exchange houses are required to surrender all foreign ex- change transfers to the central bank. The central bank determines the proportion of the surrendered foreign exchange that is returned to the commercial banks; on December 31, 1989, the proportion was 50 percent, of which 15 percent was returned to exporters by the commercial banks. Exporters are required to negotiate documentary drafts with local commercial banks to ensure the repatriation of their export proceeds. Under a law published on June 4, 1984, the customs administration will refuse export 200 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution HAITI 201 approval unless such drafts are cleared by the cen- tral bank. There are no export taxes. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not restricted. Resi- dents traveling abroad must pay a tax of G 250 on tickets and an airport tax of G 75. They must also buy a G 25,000 travel insurance policy by paying a premium of G 52; diplomats and staff members of international organizations are exempt. Capital Capital transfers abroad are not normally permit- ted, but imports of capital may be made freely. For- eign investment in Haiti is regulated by the decrees of March 13, 1963, October 8, 1969, and Decem- ber 31, 1984, and requires prior government ap- proval. Permission is normally not granted to non- residents for investments in handicraft industries. Under a decree of April 6,1973, private banks oper- ating in Haiti are required to keep a minimum of 85 percent of their liabilities for local customers in the form of domestic assets. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Haiti for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. The Bank of the Republic of Haiti has the exclusive right to purchase gold domes- tically and to export gold in the form of coins, min- eral dust, or bars. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry carried as personal effects by travelers may be made only by the Bank of the Republic of Haiti; exports require, in addition, prior authorization by the Ministry of Commerce and In- dustry and the Ministry of Finance, as well as an endorsement by the Ministry of Commerce and In- dustry before customs clearance. However, com- mercial imports of articles containing a limited amount of gold, such as gold watches, are freely permitted and do not require an import license or other authorization. Several gold coins have been issued, which are legal tender but do not circulate. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement September 29. Commercial banks were authorized to open accounts in foreign exchange in favor of residents; such accounts may not be credited with export proceeds, with transfers from abroad re- ceived by exchange houses, or with receipts by mar- itime agencies and nongovernmental organizations. Exports and Export Proceeds July 7. All export proceeds and foreign exchange receipts by maritime agencies and nongovernmen- tal organizations were required to be surrendered to the commercial banks, which in turn would transfer these receipts to the central bank. Exchange houses were also required to surrender all transfers re- ceived from abroad to the central bank. October 1. A conversion exchange rate that is 30 percent (in terms of gourdes) above the official exchange rate was introduced for the purpose of customs tariff and value-added tax assessment of all imports. Not for Redistribution HONDURAS (Position on December 31, 2989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Honduras is the Honduran Lem- pira, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar, the inter- vention currency, at L 2 = US$1. The official buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar are L 2.00 and L 2.02, respectively, per US$1. The buying and sell- ing rates for other currencies that are of significance to the foreign trade of Honduras are fixed daily on the basis of the buying and selling rates of the cur- rency concerned against the U.S. dollar in foreign markets.1 Separate exchange rates arise from an arrangement permitting exporters to Costa Rica, El Salvador, and Guatemala to transfer their foreign exchange proceeds to importers at freely negotiated exchange rates. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk operating in the official or the commercial banking sector. On August 19, 1950, Honduras formally notified the Fund that it had assumed the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, beginning on July 1, 1950. Administration of Control The administration of exchange control regula- tions is under the control of the Central Bank of Honduras. The External Financing Department of the Central Bank issues import and export permits. Import permits can be used within nine months of the date of issuance, or up to 12 months under special circumstances. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Affective March 13, 1990, a new exchange rate system came into operation. With the exception of debt-service payments, including debt conversions by the Central Government, and transactions with certain Central American countries, all permit- ted foreign exchange transactions are conducted in an interbank market in which the exchange rate is allowed to float within margins of 2.5 percent above or below a reference exchange rate. The reference exchange rate was initially set at L 4 = US$1. The reference exchange rate, which is determined by the Central Bank of Honduras, is adjusted periodically, taking into account market conditions as reflected in the movement of the weighted average of exchange rates prevailing in the transactions of the commercial banks and other macroeconomic factors. Debt- service payments, including debt conversions by the Central Government, continue to be conducted at the official rate of L 2 = US$1. The self-financed barter and compensation mechanisms and the CETRA schemes were abolished. Prescription of Currency There are no regulations prescribing the method of currency for payments to or from nonresidents. Trade transactions with the rest of Central America may be carried out in local currencies, barter and compensation mechanisms, or U.S. dollar proceeds from exports to the rest of the Central American countries. In addition, a bilateral clearinghouse ar- rangement operates for transactions with Guate- mala, under which outstanding balances are re- quired to be settled every two months. The Central Bank of Honduras authorizes imports under this arrangement only when exports to Guatemala have taken place. Trade transactions with Nicaragua are carried out under a bilateral credit agreement. Pay- ments to and receipts from Mexico in respect of merchandise trade and invisibles are settled on a four-month basis in U.S. dollars under an agree- ment between the Central American central banks and the Bank of Mexico. Beginning August 1983, all lempira-denominated payments amounting to at least L 1,500 processed through the Central American Clearing House in respect of trade and trade-related transactions with Mexico, Colombia, and member countries of the Central American Common Market (CACM) re- quire prior authorization from the Central Bank of Honduras. Imports and Import Payments Import permits are required for all imports in excess of L 5,000 and are issued by the External Financing Department of the Central Bank (DERFE). There is a list of products that can be imported with foreign exchange allocated by the Central Bank and a list of products that can be imported with the Transferable Certificates of Foreign Exchange (CETRAS). Products that can be imported with for- eign exchange allocated by the monetary authorities include milk, seeds, wheat, fertilizers, medicines, corn, rice, organic and inorganic chemical inputs used in the production of medicines, agricultural machinery, oil, tires and parts for public transporta- tion and tracks, inputs for the mass communication industry and public sector imports. Products that can be imported with CETRAS include textiles, ma- chinery, specialized tools, packing sacks, animal and vegetable oils, grains, oxides, different kinds of glasses, metal bars and rods, and cattle. Products 202 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution HONDURAS 203 not included in these lists can be imported only on a self-financed basis, including imports directly bought by exporters using the permitted retained portion of their foreign exchange receipts. Imports of corn, wheat, beans, rice, soya, and cattle require a license issued by the Honduran Institute of Agri- cultural Marketing (IHMA) before an import permit can be authorized by DERFE. Imports of some agri- cultural inputs (such as fertilizers and pesticides) require a license issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources. Imports of arms and similar items re- quire a license issued by the Ministry of Defense. The waiting period for self-financed, including CETRA-financed, imports has been modified period- ically. At the end of 1989, the waiting period was between 30 and 90 days;2 in addition, 10 days were required for processing of information. Imports may be checked for appropriate pricing, and import pre- payments are subject to certain restrictions regard- ing the means of settlement. Depending on the foreign exchange situation, the Foreign Exchange Department of the Central Bank may subject the allocation of foreign exchange for imported goods and services to a set of policy- determined priorities.3 A guarantee deposit of up to 100 percent may be required against requests to open sight letters of credit for import payments; the deposits are held with commercial banks. Importers are also required to deposit with the Central Bank the lempira equivalent of requests for official for- eign exchange that are not granted within a spec- ified waiting period. A system of "Transferable Certificates of Foreign Exchange" (CETRAS) operates to promote exports and encourage the repatriation of proceeds from these exports. Under this system, the commercial banks issue CETRAS to exporters when they sell export proceeds to the banks. Since July 1989, the proportion of CETRAS issued per dollar of foreign exchange receipts has been set at 50 percent for all exports. CETRAS are denominated in lempiras and provide the holder with preferential access to for- eign exchange at the official rate. They may be used during the first four months from the day of issu- ance to register under the system of "own foreign 2As from January 30, 1990, the waiting period was shortened to 15-30 days; effective March 13, 1990, both schemes were abolished. 3The Central Bank is authorized to allocate foreign exchange in accordance with the following priorities: external financial pay- ments; essential consumer items; health products; educational materials; fuel and lubricants; raw materials; agricultural and industrial inputs; machinery, equipment, and spare parts; and other goods and services. exchange" imports and to request foreign exchange at the official rate for payments for imports, ser- vices, or other purposes approved by the Central Bank of Honduras. During the subsequent three- month period, CETRAS may be utilized to purchase foreign exchange for the transactions authorized by the Central Bank. Unutilized CETRAS will lose their value seven months after they are issued. Since Sep- tember 1988, the commercial banks have been per- mitted to intermediate the sale of CETRAS from ex- porters to importers, for their own account and at their own risk, subject to a 5 percent commission over an exchange differential per transaction. Banks are required to post daily the buying and selling rates of CETRAS. Since July 1989, the CETRAS are not allowed to be transferred outside the banking system. Most imports from countries outside the CACM are subject to customs duty, ranging from 1 percent to 90 percent.4 Imports from the CACM are subject to customs duty ranging from zero to 35 percent. Certain goods are subject to a customs surtax of 12 percent of the duty and to a consular charge of 8 percent of the f .o .b. value. In addition, most im- ports are subject to an import service fee of 5 per- cent. There is a duty-free zone in Puerto Cortes. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports with a value exceeding US$5,000 require a license and are subject to prior autho- rization of the DERFE. All foreign exchange proceeds must be surrendered either to the Central Bank or to authorized banks and institutions, or be held as dollar-denominated deposits with commercial banks. Subject to prior authorization by the Central Bank, exporters are allowed to retain up to 60 per- cent of their foreign exchange proceeds to finance their own imports. The withdrawal of dollar- denominated deposits is subject to compliance with the procedures on the use of foreign exchange. In general, the surrender of export proceeds must be made within 90 days following the negotiation of export documents. The banks are required to trans- fer at least 30 percent of their holdings of foreign exchange proceeds from exports to the Central Bank. Exports of coffee are supervised by the Honduran Coffee Institute (!HCAFE). Exports of corn, rice, beans, and potatoes are controlled by IHMA, and lumber exports are channeled through the Honduran Forest Development Corporation Effective March 13, 1990, this range was changed to 2 to 40 percent. ©International Monetary Fund. Exports of bananas are subject to a tax at the rate of L1 for each 40-pound box, but the tax is refunded for exports exceeding a certain ceiling.5 The export promotion law enables nontraditional exports to receive freely negotiable tax credit certifi- cates (CEFEX), ranging from 5 percent to 15 percent of the f .o .b. value of exports.6 CETRAS are made available under a system set up to promote exports and encourage the repatriation of their proceeds (see section on Imports and Import Payments, above). Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles All purchases of foreign exchange in excess of L5,000 require prior approval of the Central Bank, and all buyers of foreign exchange are required to file an application stating the purpose for which the funds will be used.7 Within this limit, persons trav- eling abroad may purchase foreign currency in the CETRAS market for up to US$2,500 a person. No restrictions exist on the import of foreign bank notes by travelers. There are delays in the provision of foreign exchange for the transfers of dividends and profits. Proceeds from invisibles are either subject to a surrender requirement or must be held as dollar-denominated deposits with commercial banks. Capital The authorization of the Minister of Finance and the approval of the Central Bank are required for all activities involving the receipt of foreign exchange and its transfer abroad for investment in mutual funds, housing developments, real estate, or simi- lar activities. Foreign mutual funds and similar fi- nancial institutions require permission to collect funds in Honduras for deposit or investment abroad. The approval of the Ministry of Finance, the Secretariat of Coordination, Planning, and Budget (SECPLAN), and the Central Bank is required for the public sector to contract any foreign indebtedness, whether for import financing or for other purposes. The contracting of external debt by the private sec- tor requires approval by the Central Bank. The contracting of external financing must conform with specified priorities. Sight and term deposits in foreign currency at the banks are subject to a reserve requirement of 30 percent; the reserve requirement for certificates of deposit of US$25,000 and more is 20 percent, and 15 percent for savings deposits in foreign currency with sav- ings and loan associations. Commercial banks are required to transfer foreign exchange holdings in excess of specified limits to the Central Bank. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Honduras for numismatic purposes. With this ex- ception, residents other than the monetary au- thorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and ex- ports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Central Bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, industrial users, and producers of gold. All locally produced gold is exported in the form of ore for refining. Commercial imports and exports of jewelry and other articles containing gold require licenses issued by the Ministry of Economy; for most articles, these are granted freely. Not for Redistribution HONG KONG1 (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Hong Kong is the Hong Kong Dollar. The authorities do not maintain margins in respect of exchange transactions. Starting on Octo- ber 17, 1983, certificates of indebtedness denomi- nated in Hong Kong dollars and issued by the Gov- ernment Exchange Fund, which the two note- issuing commercial banks are required to hold as backing for their Hong Kong dollar note issues, are issued only against payment of U.S. dollars at a fixed exchange rate of HK$7.80 = US$1; payments by the Exchange Fund on surrender of certificates of indebtedness to it when the note issue declines are also made in U.S. dollars at the same exchange rate. By arrangement, other licensed banks also pay or receive U.S. dollars at this same rate when they draw bank notes from or surrender them to the note-issuing banks. With these exceptions, the ex- change rate for the Hong Kong dollar is freely deter- mined by supply and demand in the foreign ex- change market, though influenced by the fixed rate that applies to note-issue transactions. The au- thorities do, however, retain a capability to inter- vene in the market. On December 31, 1989, the middle rate in the interbank foreign exchange mar- ket for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, was HK$7.807 = US$1. There are no taxes or sub- sidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. The forward exchange markets are operated on pri- vate sector initiatives and the Government has no official role. Administration of Control There is no exchange control. Import and export licensing is carried out mainly by the Director- General of Trade. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Settlements between residents of Hong Kong and nonresidents may be made and received freely in Hong Kong dollars or any other currency. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between resident and non- resident accounts. 1Hong Kong is a nonmetropolitan territory in respect of which the United Kingdom has accepted the Fund's Articles of Agreement. Imports and Import Payments Imports are free from licensing control, except for certain dutiable commodities, items controlled for health, safety, or security reasons, and textiles that are subject to licensing control for surveillance reasons. Imports of rice are subject to a quota system operated by the Trade Department. With a few exceptions, a trade declaration must be lodged with the Customs and Excise Department within 14 days of importation in respect of each consignment of goods imported into or exported from Hong Kong. Payments for permit- ted imports may be made freely, at any time, and in any currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are required for a small number of items to enable Hong Kong to fulfill its international obligations and for health, safety, or security rea- sons. Textiles are also subject to licensing control because of a number of bilateral arrangements with specified countries under which the export of cer- tain textiles is restricted. Export proceeds may be collected at any time and in any currency. They need not be repatriated or surrendered. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles There are no limitations on payments for or re- ceipts from invisibles. Resident and nonresident travelers may freely bring in and take out any amount in domestic or foreign bank notes, trav- eler's checks, and other means of payment. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or non- residents. A license is required before any com- pany, whether incorporated in Hong Kong or elsewhere, can do banking business in Hong Kong. Subject to certain conditions, an overseas bank may establish a representative office in Hong Kong and may also register a subsidiary as a deposit-taking company. A deposit-taking company may not, however, conduct banking business or use the word "bank" in its title. Gold There is a free market for gold in which dealings by residents and nonresidents are unrestricted. Im- ports and exports of gold in any form (including 206 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution HONG KONG 207 finished jewelry) are freely permitted and do not require licenses. Residents may hold gold in any form in Hong Kong or abroad. A gold coin of HK$1,000 is legal tender but does not circulate. Changes During 1989 No significant changes occurred in the exchange and trade system. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution HUNGARY (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Hungary is the Hungarian Fo rint. The exchange rate of the forint against curren- cies other than those of the member countries of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA)1 and Albania and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is derived on the basis of a weighted basket of eleven currencies;2 the weights are adjusted an- nually and reflect the currency composition of Hun- gary's foreign trade turnover (export receipts from and import payments to) with the nonruble cur- rency area. The value of the forint in terms of the basket is adjusted at irregular intervals, notably on the basis of the difference between the domestic and foreign rates of inflation. Exchange rates are quoted on a daily basis by the National Bank of Hungary for 21 convertible curren- cies,3 and the National Bank stands ready to effect transactions in any of these currencies. Buying and selling rates are set with a spread of 0.1 percent around the middle rate for each currency.4 Rates for other currencies are based on the quoted rate for the U.S. dollar and the dollar rates for the currencies concerned in international markets. Rates for cur- rencies included in the basket to which the forint is pegged are based on the day's exchange rates in major international markets. The buying and selling rates for spot transactions in U.S. dollars on Decem- ber 29,1989 were Ft 62.48 and Ft 62.61, respectively, per US$1. Forward exchange rates are quoted by the Na- tional Bank of Hungary in respect of 21 officially aThe member countries of the CMEA are Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and Viet Nam. 2Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 3Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Cana- dian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Irish pounds, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Kuwaiti dinars, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese es- cudos, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, U.S. dollars, and European Currency Units (ECUs). In addition to the above, exchange rates for bank notes and trav- eler's checks are quoted for Greek drachmas. At the end of 1989, the exchange rate quotation for traveler's checks in Yugoslav dinars was terminated. 4The spread of 0.2 percent between buying and selling rates applies to spot telegraphic transactions. For checks and bank notes, a 6 percent spread is maintained between buying and selling rates. quoted convertible currencies and convertible currency-based clearing currencies. Forward rates are quoted according to international methods, that is, based on the daily official rates and swap dif- ferentials between the forint and other currencies for periods of 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months. The National Bank buys and sells foreign currencies from and to Hungarian commercial banks.5 The largest portion of Hungary's trade and finan- cial settlements with the member countries of the CMEA is settled in transferable rubles through the International Bank for Economic Cooperation (IBEC), and with Albania, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the Lao People's Democratic Re- public, and Democratic Kampuchea in clearing rubles. Official exchange rates for the transferable ruble and the clearing ruble are, in principle, quoted daily by the National Bank, although these rates remain fixed for longer periods. At the end of December 1989, the buying and selling rates for the forint against 1 transferable ruble were Ft 27.47 and Ft 27.53, respectively. The same rates applied to the clearing ruble. The National Bank also quotes ex- change rates for the forint against the currencies of member countries of the CMEA, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. These rates are used for noncommercial settlements; for exam- ple, international travel, expenses of diplomatic rep- resentation, and scholarships6 are based on multi- lateral agreements or, in some cases, on supplemental bilateral agreements. Administration of Control The authority for enforcement of foreign ex- change regulations is vested in the Minister of Fi- nance. Related functions are exercised by the Minis- ter through the National Bank, except for those functions reserved for the Minister himself or dele- gated to other institutions. The Central European International Bank Ltd., Inter-Europa, Ltd., Unicbank Budapest, Ltd., and Citibank Budapest, Ltd., are exempt from Hungarian foreign exchange regulations and re- strictions in respect of authorized activities. The regulations governing foreign trade in con- vertible currencies were liberalized in 1988. Since January 1988, all economic organizations in Hun- gary have been entitled to carry out foreign trade activity in convertible currencies after having been registered by the Ministry of Trade. The registration takes place automatically at the request of the organ- ization concerned and on the basis of a declaration by the company that organizational and personnel conditions are fulfilled. If legal requirements are met, the Ministry has no right to reject the registra- tion application, which must be processed within 30 days. Each economic unit may be registered as con- ducting foreign trade activities (export and import) in respect of any product and service except for those specified on the negative lists. The latter goods and services may be traded only upon formal authorization. Private persons can also be autho- rized to carry out foreign trade activities. Foreign trading rights concerning products on the negative list and for private persons are granted within 60 days. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Hun- gary has multilateral and bilateral payments agree- ments are made in the currencies and in accordance with the procedures set forth in those agreements.7 If there are no specific agreements, or if trade takes place outside the scope of the agreements, settle- ment is made in a convertible currency. Resident and Nonresident Accounts Nonresident juridical and physical persons may maintain convertible currency accounts at the au- 7At the end of December 1989, Hungary had bilateral pay- ments agreements with Albania, Brazil, the People's Republic of China, Colombia, Ecuador, Democratic Kampuchea, the Demo- cratic People's Republic of Korea, and the Lao People's Demo- cratic Republic.
