Not for Redistribution ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF IRAN (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of the Islamic Republic of Iran is the Iranian Rial, which is pegged to the SDR at Rls 92.300 = SDR 1. The official exchange rates are determined daily on the basis of the SDR-rial rate. On December 31, 1989, the official buying and sell- ing rates of Bank Markazi Jomhouri Islami Iran (the central bank) for the U.S. dollar were Rls 69.785 and Rls 70.685, respectively, per US$1. In addition to the official exchange rate, which is applied mainly to exports of oil, imports of essential goods, military items, certain raw materials and machinery, foreign exchange allowances for certain invisibles, and pub- lic sector capital transactions, the exchange rate sys- tem also consists of two "incentive" rates that apply to non-oil exports, a "preferential" rate and a "pref- erential competitive" rate that apply to certain im- ports, a "service" rate used for some invisibles, and the "free" market exchange rate that applies only to Iranian nationals residing in the Islamic Republic of Iran. The following transactions take place at rates that d iffer from the official rate: (1) exporters of non- oil products are required to surrender to Bank Markazi a certain proportion of their export earn- ings (calculated on the basis of "reference prices") at the official rate plus Rls 350 per US$1 when pro- ceeds are received in a convertible currency, or at the official rate plus Rls 270 per US$1 when exports take place within the framework of a barter or clear- ing arrangement. The proportion of export earnings that must be surrendered varies according to the type of non-oil export; the remaining proceeds may be sold in the free market. On December 31, 1989, the exchange rate in the free market was equivalent to approximately Rls 1,140 per US$1; (2) the prefer- ential exchange rate of Rls 420 per US$1 is applied to imports of spare parts used in the production of some durable goods; (3) the preferential competi- tive exchange rate is applied to imports of raw mate- rials and spare parts for the production of 131 items by enterprises affiliated with the public sector and to certain items imported by the private sector. At the end of December 1989, this exchange rate was Rls 800 per US$1; (4) the service rate of Rls 845 per US$1 is applied to the sale of foreign exchange for certain invisible transactions; and (5) all other trans- actions take place in the free market, in which cur- rently only Iranian nationals residing in the Islamic Republic of Iran are allowed to operate. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in Bank Markazi. All foreign exchange transactions other than those permitted through the free exchange market must take place through this Bank or autho- rized banks. Imports and exports are governed by regulations issued periodically by the Ministry of Commerce after approval by the Council of Ministers. Prescription of Currency Transactions with countries1 with which the Is- lamic Republic of Iran maintains clearing agree- ments are conducted in accordance with the terms of those agreements. The unit of account of these agreements is usually the U.S. dollar. Settlements of current transactions with member countries of the Asian Clearing Union (ACU) (Ban- gladesh, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan,2 and Sri Lanka) are required to be effected in Asian Mone- tary Units (AMUs). Final settlement, when neces- sary, takes place by converting AMUs to an agreed currency. Certain payments to and from Pakistan and Turkey relating to the exchange of goods and related services (excluding border trade and petro- leum and petroleum products) are settled through clearing accounts maintained by the respective cen- tral banks in U.S. dollars. Settlements in respect of petroleum and petroleum products and certain ser- vices are made through special accounts held by the central banks of these three countries. Banking ar- rangements have been concluded with major West- ern European banks to establish "Special Accounts" for clearing payments related to the sale of crude oil in exchange for purchase of a variety of products and raw materials. Nonresident Accounts Foreign nationals may maintain rial accounts and foreign currency accounts with authorized banks. The rial funds to be deposited to the rial accounts 1 Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Democratic People's Republic of Korea, Poland, Romania, Syrian Arab Republic, U.S.S.R, and Yugoslavia. 2 Pakistan, being a member of a separate agreement with the Islamic Republic of Iran, settles its payments through that agree- ment instead of in AMUs. 236 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF IRAN 237 must have originated through the sale of foreign exchange to the banking system. The foreign cur- rencies to be deposited must have originated abroad. The balance of the rial accounts may be used only in the Islamic Republic of Iran. Imports and Import Payments All imports into the Islamic Republic of Iran are required to be authorized by the Ministry of Com- merce (except for special military and pharmaceuti- cal goods, souvenirs, and gifts brought in by incom- ing travelers) before being registered by authorized banks. Imports from Israel and South Africa are prohibited. The foreign exchange budget, which is approved by Parliament, establishes allocations for imports by the different ministries and institutions. The ministries and institutions decide how to dis- tribute their own allocations among the different items, including imports by the public and private sectors. All imports require the prior approval of the procurement and distribution centers, except for goods imported by the Ministry of Defense and certain other military goods. The import policy is re- examined periodically at the end of each Iranian calendar year (March 20). New export-import reg- ulations, effective for the next year, are published by the Ministry of Commerce. The regulations dis- tinguish between "authorized," "unauthorized," and "prohibited" goods. Authorized goods are those whose import and export, with due consid- eration for the regulations, are permitted. Unautho- rized goods are those whose import and export are temporarily prohibited by the Government or are contingent on the fulfillment of certain require- ments (as explained in the relative tariff). Prohibited goods consist of those whose transactions are forbidden. At the time of registration of imports, (1) a regis- tration fee of 15 percent of the value of the order for ordinary goods and of 5 percent of the value of the order for essential goods, calculated on a c . i .f. basis, is collected by authorized banks; and (2) for some goods, importers must also deposit with Bank Markazi, through an authorized bank, an additional 15 percent of the c . i .f. value of these goods. Most food items and certain other products are, however, exempt from this registration deposit requirement. The registration deposit, which is not interest bear- ing, is refundable upon presentation of the customs clearance certificate or when the order is canceled. If less than 90 percent of the registration value is used, the amount of refund of the registration deposit is in proportion to the unused amount of the registered order. Bank Markazi may permit, when necessary, the transfer of imports from the category in which a registration deposit is required to the exempt cate- gory, and vice versa. Most imports are subject to commercial benefit taxes, which are either specific or ad valorem and are imposed in addition to any applicable customs duty. Monopoly taxes, if any, are included in the commercial benefit taxes. The authorities specify in the export-import regulations the rate of commer- cial benefit taxes for each year. These taxes are paid to customs before customs clearance. The clearance through customs is authorized upon presentation of shipping documents endorsed by an authorized bank and the permission of the relative procure- ment and distribution center (this permit may be issued at the time of opening of letters of credit and need not be reissued). Goods that are not covered by any center do not require a permission. For some goods, such as pharmaceuticals, imports by the Ministry of Post, Telegraph, and Telephone, and imports of the Atomic Energy Organization, special permission must be presented when they are cleared through the customs. In the transportation of imported goods for which letters of credit have been opened, priority should be accorded to the Iranian transportation carriers (air, land, or sea). The ceiling on the amount of goods that an in- coming traveler is permitted to import is governed by the export-import regulations. Payments for Invisibles The transfer of premiums for reinsurance is per- mitted at the daily rate upon the request of the respective insurance company and with the ap- proval of the Central Insurance Company of Iran. Foreign nationals working in the Islamic Republic of Iran whose services are considered essential are allowed to remit up to 30 percent of their net sal- aries, with the prior approval of Bank Markazi. Limits on remittances by physicians vary from 15 to 60 percent of earnings, depending on the location and condition of their work, as defined by the Min- istry of Health. Possession of a valid passport and a work permit is required for the above-mentioned remittances. Persons needing medical treatment abroad may obtain foreign exchange up to the amount specified by the High Medical Council of the Ministry of Health at the official rate. Those patients whose need for treatment abroad is officially certified but who are not authorized to purchase foreign ex- change at the official rate, and those patients who are permitted to obtain foreign exchange at the offi- cial rate but who do not receive the total amount ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 238 ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF IRAN needed to finance their medical treatment may pur- chase the additional foreign exchange needed for medical purposes at the service rate. Foreign exchange allowances for students study- ing abroad are provided at the official exchange rate with the approval of the Ministry of Higher Educa- tion. Allowances vary according to the cost of living in the country of study, up to a maximum of US$1,170 a month; an additional allowance of 60 percent and 30 percent of the basic allowance is provided, respectively, for the spouse and for each child. In certain cases, where this allowance is not sufficient to cover tuition, additional amounts to cover university fees and expenses are provided. Students working abroad and not benefiting from transfers from the Islamic Republic of Iran may re- ceive up to US$150 a month as financial assistance at the "service" rate. Certain categories of students who are not qualified to obtain foreign exchange allowances at the official rate may obtain them at the service rate. An annual foreign exchange allowance of US$500 is granted for business travel at the official rate on approval by the Ministry of Commerce. In addition, up to US$300 once a year is granted for travel, irre- spective of the purpose or destination, at the service rate. Iranian nationals leaving the country must pay an exit fee per trip of Rls 50,000 for the first trip and Rls 100,000 for successive trips. Travelers leaving the Islamic Republic of Iran may take out with them up to Rls 20,000 in Iranian bank notes. The equivalent of US$5,000 may be taken out without declaration at the time of each trip. Foreign currency over this amount may be taken out pro- vided that it was declared at the time of arrival. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of all products are subject to prevailing regulations on foreign trade. The commercial bene- fit tax and customs duty levied on imported raw materials that are used in the production of man- ufactured goods for export are refunded to the ex- porter after the export has taken place. Exporters of non-oil products are allowed to import authorized goods up to the value of goods exported. They may also transfer the declared foreign exchange earn- ings to other individuals for import of certain goods. Export proceeds must be sold to banks authorized to deal in foreign exchange. Authorized banks ac- cept export proceeds normally in currencies quoted by Bank Markazi. With the prior approval of Bank Markazi, other currencies may also be accepted. Proceeds from oil exports are converted at the offi- cial exchange rate, while those from non-oil exports are converted at various multiple rates, depending on the "reference" prices applied and the propor- tion of earnings required to be surrendered (see section on Exchange Arrangement, above). In addi- tion, those exporters surrendering foreign exchange equivalent to the value of exports immediately after approval of the export documentation and those exporters using documentary letters of credit are allowed to retain an additional 2 percent of their export proceeds, which is not subject to surrender requirements. Exports to Israel and South Africa are prohibited. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from the export of in- visibles may be retained in foreign currency ac- counts with authorized banks. Transfers from such accounts do not require prior approval of Bank Markazi. There is no limit on the amount of foreign exchange foreign travelers may bring into the coun- try, but they must sell at least US$150 to US$300 (as specified by the Islamic Republic of Iran's consular officials upon the issuance of entry permits) to the authorized banks. Muslim citizens of other coun- tries and citizens of countries that are party to bilat- eral agreements are exempt from this regulation. Foreign truck drivers, when entering the Islamic Republic of Iran, must convert US$100 worth of convertible currencies into rials; the amount appli- cable to Turkish truck drivers is US$50. Travelers may bring into the country up to Rls 20,000 in Ira- nian bank notes. The equivalent of US$5,000 may be brought into the country without declaration at the time of each trip. Capital Iranian nationals may retain their foreign ex- change earnings, if earned abroad, in foreign cur- rency accounts with domestic authorized banks. Transfers abroad from such accounts do not require the approval of Bank Markazi. Foreign capital in- vestment is supervised by the Organization for In- vestment and Economic and Technical Assistance of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Finance. Re- patriation of foreign capital and dividends can be made at the official exchange rate with the approval of the said organization and Bank Markazi, and in accordance with the Law Concerning the Attraction and Protection of Foreign Capital Investments. Dis- bursements and authorizations of public sector loans take place at the official rate. The net short- term foreign liabilities of the commercial banks are subject to a reserve requirement of 27 percent. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF IRAN 239 Gold No Iranian gold coin is legal tender. Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold, platinum, and silver in the domestic mar- ket. The import and export of gold for monetary purposes is reserved for Bank Markazi. Authorized banks may import gold, platinum, and silver bullion with the prior approval of Bank Markazi. Imports for industrial and dental use are effected by profes- sional organizations at the official rate and subject to supervision by Bank Markazi; such imports are sub- ject to customs duty, the commercial benefit levy, and an import registration fee. The export of gold, platinum, and silver in the form of ingots or coins, except by Bank Markazi, is prohibited. The export of finished articles made of gold, platinum, and silver may be effected in accordance with the relevant regulations. Passengers may, without prior ap- proval of Bank Markazi, bring in jewelry with a value equivalent to Rls 5 million, which will be re- corded in their passports so that the same may be re- exported. Imports of personal jewelry with a value exceeding this amount require the approval of Bank Markazi. The export of Iranian gold coins for numismatic purposes requires prior approval by Bank Markazi. of raw materials and spare parts for the production of 131 items by enterprises affiliated with the public sector, was introduced; these imports had pre- viously been allowed at the "free" market rate. Not for Redistribution IRAQ (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement Nonresident Accounts The currency of Iraq is the Iraqi Dinar, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, at ID 1 = US$3.2169. The official buying and selling rates on December 31, 1989 were US$3.224933 and US$3.208889, respectively, per ID 1. Buying and selling rates for certain other currencies1 are also officially quoted, with daily quotations based on the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in mar- kets abroad. The Central Bank of Iraq undertakes transactions in the listed currencies only with au- thorized dealers. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk in the official or the commercial banking sector. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Board of Administration of the Central Bank; this au- thority has been delegated to the Governor and his Deputy, who act on recommendations submitted by an Advisory Committee on Foreign Exchange. Cer- tain approval authority has been delegated to the Department of Foreign Exchange and Banking Su- pervision of the Central Bank and to licensed dealers. Foreign exchange transactions must take place through a licensed dealer unless otherwise authorized by the Governor. Branches of the Rafi- dain Bank and the Rasheed Bank are licensed dealers. Import policy and the annual program are formulated by the Ministry of Trade. Prescription of Currency Settlements with foreign countries normally must be made in any of the listed currencies or by drawing on a nonresident account in Iraqi dinars, provided that the funds on the nonresident account were obtained originally through credits in any one of the listed currencies. Payments to and receipts from Israel and South Africa are prohibited. Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, and Swiss francs. 240 The opening of a nonresident account requires the approval of the exchange control authorities. Nonresident accounts are divided into ordinary nonresident accounts, which arise from transac- tions in respect of current payments, and special nonresident accounts, which arise from transac- tions in respect of capital transfers. Imports and Import Payments Imports of commodities are normally handled by the socialized sector. All private imports are subject to licenses, except imports of materials constituting basic elements for development projects benefiting from the Law for Major Development Projects, No. 157 of 1973 (for old contracts) or from the Law for Major Development Projects, No. 60 of 1985 (for new projects). Under Resolution No. 767 of October 1, 1987, foreign companies implementing development projects in Iraq are exempted from all import duties and domestic taxes accruing from the implementa- tion of these projects, including income taxes due on earnings of their non-Iraqi workers. These ex- emptions apply to new projects that are contracted after the effective date of Resolution No. 767. The Law for Major Development Projects, No. 60 of 1985, ceased to be effective, except that its provi- sions continue to apply to projects that were con- tracted before Resolution No. 767 took effect. In principle, licenses are issued in accordance with an annual import program. Imports of all goods from Israel and South Africa are prohibited. Imports of some commodities on a protected list are, in princi- ple, prohibited from all sources. To finance the Export Subsidy Fund, a tax of 0.5 percent is levied on imports of capital goods, and a tax of 0.75 percent is levied on imports of consumer goods. All imports subject to import duty are also subject to a customs surcharge according to the available list of classified goods. The Rafidain Bank or the Rasheed Bank makes exchange available upon presentation of the ex- change control copy of the import license, except in some instances where reference has to be made to the Central Bank. Imports financed by foreign ex- change obtained by nonresident Iraqis are given special import licenses. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAQ 241 Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require permission. Exchange is usually granted for educational and medical expenses abroad, freight on exports effected on a c. & f. basis, insurance premiums, royalties, etc. Exchange is not granted to merchants for the insurance abroad of their imports or exports. The Rafidain Bank and the Rasheed Bank are per- mitted, subject to the approval of the Central Bank, to transfer up to 50 percent of annual income ac- crued to Arab and foreign nationals resident in Iraq, unless the particular contract extends this limit up to 75 percent for old contracts or 60 percent for new contracts. Certain nonresident private sector workers who have contracts with public institutions in Iraq are permitted to transfer the amounts pro- vided for in those contracts; those not employed under contracts may transfer abroad a monthly amount of ID 10 for each person who is not insured and ID 20 for each person who is insured and is working in the private sector. Noncontractual workers employed by the Government are entitled to ID 40 a person a month for skilled workers em- ployed in the nationalized sector. Persons under 16 years and over 55 years of age, however, are not allowed to transfer their earnings abroad. The regulations provide, in principle, for a basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad on the basis of the classification of foreign countries into two categories as follows. The basic allowance for travel to a country in the first category is ID 300 a trip for each person 18 years of age or over (ID 150 for persons under 18 years of age) traveling to Arab and socialist countries, Turkey, Cyprus, and Greece. For the second category, which includes all other coun- tries, the basic allowance is ID 500 a trip for each person 18 years of age or over (ID 250 for persons under 18 years of age). The individual exchange allowance for official missions abroad to countries in the first category ranges between ID 30 and ID 60 a person a day depending on status and duration of mission; for countries in the second category, the allowance ranges between ID 40 and ID 75 a day. Students abroad are allocated a fixed amount in Iraqi dinars to be transferred to the country of their residence, except for certain countries (such as In- dia, socialist countries, and North Africa) where students are paid a fixed amount in U.S. dollars. Travelers may take out ID 5 in Iraqi currency notes, which is considered part of the basic travel allowance, and the balance of that allowance, in traveler's checks. Residents on pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia are permitted to transfer the equivalent of ID 250 for personal expenses in addition to all other traveling expenses paid to the local travel agent. Half of this allowance is permitted for persons un- der 18 years. Exchange allowances for pilgrimage are unrelated to other traveling allowances during the year. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel and South Africa and exports of certain goods to all other countries are pro- hibited. The Ministry of Trade has authority to pro- hibit the export of any commodity when supply falls short of domestic demand. All exports are li- censed freely through the General Company for Exhibitions and Trading Services. Exporters gener- ally must undertake to repatriate 60 percent of their foreign exchange proceeds through the Rafidain Bank or the Rasheed Bank and to surrender them within two months of shipment. Exporters may re- tain their export proceeds in foreign exchange ac- counts with the commercial banks and use them to pay for imports that are licensed. Financial support is granted under an export sub- sidy fund established in 1969 for the purpose of assisting non-oil exports provide financial incen- tives to eligible exports. The scheme is intended to introduce Iraqi goods abroad, whether from the private or socialist sector, and to improve their com- petitive position. The financial subsidies are granted upon presentation of the necessary documents. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts in excess of ID 50 from invisibles must be surrendered within three months to a licensed dealer. Travelers may bring in foreign exchange, including currency notes (other than Is- raeli currency), in unlimited amounts, provided that the funds are declared on an exchange control form; amounts not intended to be taken out of the country are exempt from declaration. Travelers may bring in ID 25 in Iraqi notes. Iraqi nationals are allowed to bring in convertible foreign currencies, deposit them with a licensed dealer, and use the funds to purchase goods from duty-free shops. Capital Nonresidents may import capital freely, except from Israel or South Africa, but they must deposit it with the Rafidain Bank or the Rasheed Bank; such deposits may be converted into local currency at the official rate, and repatriation to the country of origin is permitted. Under Resolution No. 1646 of the Rev- olutionary Command Council, enacted in Novem- ber 1980, no foreign (defined as non-Arab) par- ticipation is allowed in the capital of private sector ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 242 IRAQ companies, but citizens of Arab states may partici- pate with Iraqis in projects in the industrial, agri- cultural services, and tourism sectors. All transfers of capital abroad by residents, whether Iraqis or foreigners, require exchange control approval. Iraqi nationals, foreigners, and nonresidents may trans- fer foreign exchange to Iraq and deposit it with a licensed dealer in accounts bearing interest rates comparable to the international rates. Balances on these accounts with interest are freely transferable abroad in foreign currencies, provided that the funds were deposited with licensed dealers within three months of transfer. Iraqi nationals resident abroad (or their legal representatives) may with- draw from their nonresident accounts up to ID 10,000 a year in three installments to cover per- sonal expenses inside the country. Under the Industrial Investment Regulation Law for private and mixed sectors (No. 115 of 1982), certain incentives and guarantees are granted to approved investments of domestic or Arab capital in Iraq. In addition, Arab capital invested in Iraq is accorded preferential treatment in different eco- nomic sectors. Arab farmers having contracts with the Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation are per- mitted to transfer abroad annually up to 50 percent of their individual net return, subject to a limit of ID 500. Arab investors are allowed to transfer capital in a convertible currency through a licensed bank or physical assets that will be used in the enterprises they are planning to establish, provided that used machinery and equipment have at least one half of their productive life left. Investments by Arab na- tionals are encouraged by Arab Investment Law No. 46 of 1988. The law permits (1) Iraqi investors to participate in enterprises in which their capital par- ticipation does not exceed 49 percent, provided that their contribution and profits will be paid in Iraqi dinars and the minimum capital of the enterprise is ID 0.5 million, and (2) Arab investors to transfer annually up to 100 percent of profits to be dis- tributed to them, provided that the profit does not exceed 20 percent of their paid in capital. Gold Under Resolution No. 801 dated October 10,1987, an Iraqi resident, nonresident, or a foreigner may bring into Iraq, free of customs duty, worked and unworked gold, regardless of its weight, provided that it is declared upon importation. Iraqi residents may take out with them worked gold not exceeding 100 grams a person, subject to declaration; such gold may be brought back on their return to the country. Nonresident Iraqis are allowed to take out with them worked gold that they brought with them for personal use when they entered Iraq. The export and import of gold for commercial purposes are not permitted. Changes During 1989 No significant changes occurred in the exchange and trade system. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Ireland is the Irish Pound. Ireland participates with Belgium, Denmark, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and Spain in the exchange rate and intervention mechanism of the European Mon- etary System (EMS). In accordance with this agree- ment, Ireland maintains the spot exchange rates between the Irish pound and the currencies of the other participants within margins of 2.25 percent (in the case of the Italian lira and the Spanish peseta, 6 percent1) above or below the cross rates based on the central rates expressed in European Currency Units (ECUs). The agreement implies that the Central Bank of Ireland stands ready to buy or sell the currencies of the other participating states in unlimited amounts at specified intervention rates. On December 29, 1989, these rates were as follows: Irish Pounds Upper limit Lower limit Specified Intervention Rates Per: 100 Belgian or Luxembourg francs 1.8510 1.7695 100 Danish kroner 10.0087 9.5683 100 deutsche mark 38.1825 36.4964 100 French francs 11.3830 10.8825 100 Italian lire 0.0549952 0.0487799 100 Netherlands guilders 33.8868 32.3939 100 Spanish pesetas 0.609772 0.540858 The participants in the EMS do not maintain ex- change rates for other currencies within fixed limits. On December 29,1989, the official midpoint closing rate for the U.S. dollar was US$1.5563 per £Irl. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. Access to the forward exchange market is regu- lated. Forward cover is permitted for the import and export of goods and services, and forward contracts must correspond in all aspects to the underlying commercial transactions. The minimum and max- imum maturity periods for which forward exchange transactions are permitted are 21 days and 12 months, respectively, except in the case of forward purchases of foreign exchange by banks, where up to 2 years is permitted. The Central Bank intervenes irThe margins of the Italian lira were reduced -to plus or minus 2.25 percent, effective January 8, 1990. 243 in the forward market intermittently. These inter- ventions are primarily intended to influence banks' liquidity positions and not the forward exchange rate. On February 15, 1961, Ireland formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Exchange control is operated by the Central Bank.2 Much of the authority for approving normal payments is delegated to commercial banks autho- rized for this purpose (authorized dealers). Import licenses, where necessary, are issued by the Depart- ment of Industry and Commerce if the goods are of an industrial nature, or by the Department of Agri- culture and Food if they are agricultural in charac- ter; import licenses are also issued by the Depart- ment of Tourism and Transport, and in some cases by the Department of Health or the Department of Justice. Import licensing is not used for exchange control purposes. Import and export controls are administered by the Revenue Commissioners. Prescription of Currency The administration of Irish exchange control is based on the distinction between entities that are permanently resident in Ireland and nonres- idents —that is, residents of other countries. The latter comprise two categories: (1) residents of Euro- pean Communities (EC) member countries, and (2) residents of all other countries. Payments may be made in Irish pounds or in any foreign currency. The proceeds of exports must be received in foreign currency or in Irish pounds from an External Account. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Irish pounds of nonresidents are des- ignated external accounts. All credits in excess of £Ir250,000 to external accounts held by nonbanks with financial institutions require specific approval 2Effective April 1, 1990, exchange controls were liberalized. The liberalization measures were aimed at reducing administrative requirements associated with exchange controls and at permit- ting greater access to some of the newer financial investments. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 244 IRELAND by the Central Bank, except where the credit is in respect of imports of goods or services into Ireland. There are also limits on maximum balances in exter- nal accounts of nonresident banks; balances in ex- cess of £Ir250,000 may not be maintained without prior approval of the Central Bank. External accounts may be credited with payments that are eligible for transfer abroad under a general or specific exchange control approval, with transfers from other external accounts, payments for any for- eign currencies purchased from account holders, the proceeds of Irish currency notes received from abroad in denominations not exceeding £Ir20, pay- ments from within the country up to £Ir250 in value, and interest payable on the accounts; they may be debited for transfers to residents, transfers to other external accounts, the cost of any foreign currency sold to account holders, the transfer of any part of account balances to account holders, and bank charges, if applicable. Authorized banks may operate foreign currency accounts in the names of nonresidents in any for- eign currency; these accounts are generally subject to the same requirements as external accounts. Au- thorized banks may also operate foreign currency accounts in the names of residents under specific central bank approval. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain goods (including textiles, steel, footwear, tires, and ceramic products) originating in certain non-EC countries are subject to either quan- titative restrictions or surveillance measures. Imports from non-EC countries of products cov- ered by the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) of the EC may be subject to various charges, such as levies and monetary compensatory amounts under that policy and to duties under the common customs tar iff. For reasons of national policy, imports of certain goods (e.g., specified drugs, explosives, and fire- arms and ammunition) are prohibited without spe- cial licenses. Prior permission from the Central Bank is re- quired to pay for goods not being imported into Ireland or if payment is not being made in an ap- proved manner. Goods not for use in Ireland must, in general, be paid for with borrowed foreign cur- rency. For permitted imports, permission to make payments to nonresidents is granted automatically. Authority to make payments is delegated to autho- rized dealers. Exchange control forms are required for import payments exceeding £Ir50,000 (as of Jan- uary 1, 1988). Payments for Invisibles Payments to nonresidents require verification. Approval to make payments for most invisibles is delegated to the authorized banks; for other invis- ibles, it is given by the Central Bank. For tourist travel there is a basic allowance in foreign currency for residents of Ireland of £Irl,200 a person for each trip, or when the trip exceeds two months, £Ir5,000. For business travel, up to £Ir5,000 at a rate of £Ir200 a day is allowed for each journey. Limits are also established for allowances for educa- tion and other purposes. Applications for larger amounts are approved, provided that no unautho- rized export of capital is involved. Not more than £Irl,200 of an allowance of foreign currency may be issued in the form of currency notes. Residents may also take with them up to £Irl50 in Irish currency notes. Nonresidents may take with them any for- eign currency notes that they brought into Ireland. Exports and Export Proceeds A system of export licensing is applied to a lim- ited range of goods. Exporters of goods must obtain payment for the goods within six months of ship- ment if their value exceeds £Ir250. When payment is received in foreign currencies, the exchange must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Exchange control forms are required for exports exceeding £Ir50,000 and must be shown to Irish customs at the point of exportation. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles must be re- patriated without delay, and if foreign currencies are received, they must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer, or permission for their retention must be obtained. Any foreign currency held by a person after his return from a trip abroad may be retained for subsequent travel purposes for three months from the date of return. There are no limita- tions on the import of Irish or foreign bank notes, but prior Central Bank approval must be obtained to credit Irish bank notes in denominations exceeding £Ir20 to external accounts. Capital Exchange control approval is required for all transfers of capital to nonresidents. Authority to make certain payments has been delegated to au- thorized dealers; other payments require Central Bank approval. There are no restrictions on asset transfers for Irish residents taking up permanent residence abroad. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND 245 The inflow of capital is not restricted, but inward direct investment requires exchange control ap- proval. The purchase of nonurban land by foreign nationals in some cases requires approval by the Land Commission. Incoming capital received in for- eign currencies must be offered for sale to an autho- rized dealer. The Central Bank approves applications by Irish residents for permission to purchase property for personal use in a member country of the EC with foreign currency purchased from Irish pounds. The acquisition of personal property located outside the EC is permitted, subject to a limit of £Ir50,000 a property and one property for each family unit. Up to 25 percent of the cost may be met by purchasing foreign exchange with Irish pounds, and the re- mainder must be loans in foreign currency. Borrow- ings may be repaid with foreign exchange in equal annual installments over a period of not less than five years. The entire foreign currency proceeds from the sale of property outside Ireland purchased for personal use of a resident must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer when they are not in- tended to be invested in another property or to repay borrowing. The forward currency transactions of commercial banks are subject to limits, which vary from bank to bank, depending on the institution's level of par- ticipation in the foreign exchange market. Effective January 1, 1989, all restrictions on pur- chases of foreign securities with maturities exceed- ing two years were eliminated. Transactions in foreign currency securities with maturities of less than two years are monitored to limit the amount of capital transferred outside Ire- land. All transactions in foreign currency securities must be routed through an approved agent (an Irish bank, stockbroker, or solicitor). Where such se- curities are sold, the proceeds must either be rein- vested in foreign securities or be offered for sale to an authorized dealer within three months. During that three-month period, in the absence of the spe- cific approval of the Central Bank, the proceeds must be held under the control of an approved agent. Domestic institutional investors (e.g., autho- rized insurers, pension funds, and registered unit trusts) were allowed to purchase in 1989 at the cur- rent rate of exchange short-term foreign securities (i.e., with maturities of less than two years at issue) up to a limit of 12.5 percent of their previous year's net Irish pound cash flow. Effective January 1, 1989, all exchange controls applied to the sales of existing holdings of securities issued by the EC, the European Investment Bank, the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) were abolished. Direct investment abroad requires prior approval. Up to 25 percent of the cost of approved outward investments in non-EC countries may be financed by conversion from Irish pounds, and the balance through foreign borrowing. Use of Irish pounds is allowed, however, for all approved new direct investments by Irish residents in EC member countries. Purchases by nonresidents of Irish registered se- curities must be funded with foreign currency or Irish pounds from an external account or the sale proceeds of other Irish securities; purchases in ex- cess of £IrlOO,000 require notification to the Central Bank. Remittances of cash gifts or personal loans are normally permitted up to £Ir3,000 a donor a calen- dar year. Applications by Irish residents to make cash gifts to EC residents, in excess of the normal allowance, are approved. Foreign currency may be borrowed by residents for any purpose. The approval of the Central Bank must be obtained when the borrowing is not for the financing of trade. Lending of Irish currency to non- residents is not normally permitted, except to the extent that the nonresidents are parties to commer- cial transactions with residents. Overdraft facilities may be provided by the banks to members of diplo- matic and consular missions in Ireland. Provided that the company is not a channel for portfolio in- vestment, a subsidiary or branch of a company con- trolled directly by interests in EC countries may obtain from Irish banks, subject to exchange control approval, all the financing it requires for its opera- tion in Ireland. In the case of companies controlled from a non-EC country, working capital may be borrowed locally. Gold Residents may freely hold, buy, borrow, sell, or lend gold coin in Ireland. Dealings in gold bullion are restricted, and no dealings take place in Ireland. In accordance with a regulation of the EC Council dated October 27,1986, Ireland does not permit the putting into free circulation of gold coins minted after 1960 that originated in the Republic of South Africa. Although there are no other import restric- tions, residents require specific exchange control permission to purchase gold coin or bullion outside Ireland. Specific exchange control permission is also required for the export of gold coin and bullion outside Ireland. Specific permission to buy or export gold coin or bullion normally is given only for bona ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 246 IRELAND fide numismatic or industrial purposes, respec- tively. Residents of Ireland are not permitted to hold gold abroad. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Israel is the New Sheqel (plural, Sheqalim), the external value of which is linked to a basket consisting of the following five major curren- cies: the deutsche mark, the French franc, the Jap- anese yen, the pound sterling, and the U.S. dollar. Prior to 1989, the authorities did not maintain mar- gins in respect of exchange transactions; with effect from January 3, 1989, actual daily rates are estab- lished by the Bank of Israel within margins of 3 per- cent around the rate fixed in relation to the basket. On December 29, 1989, the noon midpoint ex- change rate of the new sheqel in terms of the U.S. dollar was NIS 1.9630 - US$1. Authorized banks are permitted to deal in foreign exchange, and a levy of 1 percent of the transaction value is imposed on purchases of foreign exchange by the public, including those involving foreign currency- denominated PATAM accounts (see below). An ex- change rate insurance scheme covering export re- ceipts is in operation (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below). Forward exchange transactions are permitted. Purchases and sales of currency options issued by the authorized dealers are permitted, provided that they are intended to cover exchange rate risk arising from authorized trade and capital transactions and are conducted through the authorized dealers. Administration of Control Exchange control is the responsibility of the Con- troller of Foreign Exchange and is administered by the Bank of Israel, in cooperation with other govern- ment agencies, and is carried out through autho- rized banks. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected in the currency and manner prescribed by the exchange control authorities. count into local currency at the market rate of exchange. There are no restrictions on the opening by a nonresident of a local currency account; such funds may be used locally in permitted transactions, in- cluding transfers between nonresidents. The sales proceeds of real estate and other investments may be transferred abroad in their entirety if the original investment was made through an authorized dealer with foreign currency or State of Israel Develop- ment Loan bonds. Resident Accounts in Foreign Currency Residents may maintain foreign currency de- posits with authorized banks in Israel in either non- resident deposit accounts, which may, subject to conditions, be held by exporters and recent immi- grants to Israel, or PATAM (resident foreign cur- rency deposit) -Restitution accounts, which may be held only by recipients of restitution payments and certain disability pensions. Otherwise, resi- dents may deposit foreign exchange they receive legally from abroad in PATAM accounts. In addition, residents may maintain in certain PATAM accounts foreign currency purchased prior to August 3, 1989 against sheqalim. Banks are re- quired to redeposit 100 percent of PATAM demand and time deposits with the Bank of Israel. Since Au- gust 3, 1989, the permit allowing Israel residents to purchase foreign currency for a PATAM deposit has been revoked. Instead, residents may open PATZAM (new sheqel deposit linked to foreign cur- rency) accounts with a maturity of longer than one year. PATAM-Restitution accounts are also demand or time deposit accounts in convertible currencies with authorized banks, which must redeposit 90 percent of these foreign currency funds with the Bank of Israel. Funds deposited in restitution accounts are free of taxation. PATAM-Restitution accounts are permitted to be used up to a limit of US$1,800 as additional travel exchange allocation. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents' funds are held either in foreign currency accounts or in local currency accounts. The opening of nonresident foreign currency accounts does not require prior approval. The holder may freely effect transfers from his foreign currency ac- count. He may also convert funds held on the ac- Imports and Import Payments A few imports are prohibited from all sources. Imports of iron and steel products from South Af- rica are prohibited (imports effected under con- tracts entered into before September 17, 1987 are, however, permitted). With some exceptions, im- ports are free of licensing and administrative or 247 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 248 ISRAEL quantitative restrictions. Some imports on a Re- stricted List are subject to approval; this list includes most agricultural products, beverages, certain tex- tiles, explosives and inflammables, and specified items of machinery and metal products. The import of soybeans, which was once under government procurement, has been liberalized and any food processing plant can import them directly. Foreign exchange to pay for authorized imports is granted automatically by the banks upon presentation of relevant documents (import documents, bills of lad- ing, and letters of credit). Advance payments for imports are permitted up to 35 percent. Foreign exchange is also provided automatically for repay- ment of suppliers' credits. A value-added tax of 15 percent is levied on almost all imported and domestically produced goods, other than fresh fruits and vegetables. A 2 percent duty is levied on imports from any origin. Payments for Invisibles Foreign exchange for payments abroad on ac- count of invisibles is provided automatically upon proof of the nature of the transaction. The exchange allowance for tourist travel is the equivalent of US$2,000 a person for each journey, regardless of age. The business travel allowance is US$150 a day, up to a maximum of US$3,000 a trip (in addition to the standard allowance of US$2,000). The allowance can be taken out in the form of cash, traveler's checks, credit cards, or other foreign exchange in- struments. Foreign exchange use by means of credit cards is included in the travel allowance. Resident travelers may take out Israeli bank notes not exceed- ing the equivalent of US$50 a person a trip. Israeli residents over 2 years of age traveling abroad are subject to a travel tax of MS 250 on departure. (One half of the standard rate remains in effect for travel to Romania, and travel to Egypt remains exempt from tax.) Payments for hotel accommodation, land transport, and other related services under foreign package tours, along with other imports of services, are subject to the value-added tax of 15 percent. Residents may make family support and gift remit- tances abroad up to US$1,000 a year. The maximum exchange allowance for students studying at institu- tions of higher education abroad is US$500 a month. Nonresident travelers leaving Israel are permitted to take out Israeli bank notes up to the equivalent of US$100, and to repurchase through an authorized dealer, at the port of departure, foreign currency up to the equivalent of US$100. The right of a tourist to buy foreign currency, on presentation of documents showing previous conversion of foreign currency into Israeli currency, is limited during a visit to US$5,000 for a person over 18 years of age and to US$2,000 for a person under 18 years. Commercial banks are authorized to sell abroad unlimited amounts of Israeli currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports do not require licenses, although for some commodities export licensing is retained for sanitary control. Exports of oil and defense equip- ment (and signing of defense contracts) to South Africa are prohibited. Export proceeds, which may be received in foreign currencies only, must be sur- rendered or held in a PATAM account. Exporters may retain in a bank deposit abroad or in a special exporter account in Israel an amount equivalent to 10 percent of their turnover in the preceding year. For inputs directly imported by an exporter, there is a system of rebates of customs duties, wharf charges, and other related charges. The Israel Foreign Trade Risks Insurance Com- pany (FTIC) provides an export insurance facility to cover unfavorable movements in domestic currency costs as measured by movements in the weighted average rate of the new sheqel against the basket of five currencies to which the external value of the new sheqel is linked (see section on Exchange Ar- rangement, above). The scheme covers exporters' value added. In return for a premium based on the value added of his exports, an exporter receives cover against any real appreciation of the new she- qel in relation to the basket of currencies. The pre- mium rate is established on the basis of average expected inflation in the partner countries and the relationships among the forward exchange rates of the currencies constituting the basket. Exporters would receive payments from the FTIC if the real depreciation was less than expected, whereas they would make payments to the FTIC if it was greater. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds from invisibles must, in gen- eral, be surrendered to an authorized dealer, or kept in foreign exchange in PATAM accounts. Any resi- dent is free to accept specified convertible curren- cies from tourists in payment for customary tourist services and commodities other than commercial exports, securities, and real estate. For 30 years after entering Israel, new immigrants are exempt from the requirement to surrender their foreign exchange to authorized dealers, and they may hold these foreign currencies freely with autho- rized banks in Israel or with banks abroad. There ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL 249 are no limits on the amounts of Israeli bank notes or foreign currency that may be brought in by travelers. Capital Subject to approval, foreign exchange brought into Israel for the purpose of investment in the form of loan and equity capital may be granted preferen- tial treatment in accordance with the Law for the Encouragement of Capital Investment, which grants a limited withholding tax of 25 percent on income resulting from these investments. Ap- provals granted under the law are classified as "ap- proved enterprises/' "approved investments," or "approved loans." Approved enterprise status is granted to economically viable enterprises (1) in the fields of industry, tourism, and agriculture (a separate law applies to agriculture); (2) established in priority areas; or (3) contributing to improve- ments in the balance of payments. Approved invest- ment or approved loan status may be granted to any enterprise in the above-mentioned sectors; how- ever, loans may only be shareholders' loans. The period of the loan must not be less than seven years, and the rate of interest must not be more than 8 per- cent a year. Certain restrictions apply to foreign currency bor- rowing from abroad by residents. A freeze is in effect on all such direct foreign borrowing with aver- age maturity of less than 18 months by nonbank residents, other than suppliers' credits and loans obtained by residents engaged in export activities. The annual rate of interest on loans obtained abroad may not exceed LIBOR plus 1.5 percent, net of tax. Under the official export credit regime (governing preferential but not subsidized access to foreign currency financing for the production period of ex- ports) the exporter may obtain credit from any source. Guarantees of such export financing by Is- raeli banks are permitted; the interest rate under the scheme consists of LIBOR plus 1 percentage point as the "base" plus a risk premium of 0-2 percentage points. Proceeds accruing from the repatriation or liqui- dation of foreign assets are treated in the same way as other proceeds in foreign currency. Residents who own trust funds are permitted to invest abroad up to 10 percent of their portfolio of financial assets (up to 50 percent in the case of funds specializing in foreign currency investments). Residents are not normally permitted to retain abroad real estate, money, securities, or the income from these assets. Residents may not buy foreign securities abroad, with the exception of specified types of Israeli firms' securities issued abroad with the approval of the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Resident exporters and airline and shipping companies may maintain foreign bank accounts. New immigrants may retain their foreign assets for 30 years. Transfers abroad of a capital nature by residents other than new immi- grants require a special permit from the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Emigrants are permitted to transfer their Israeli assets abroad up to the equiv- alent of US$2,000 a year. Nonresidents are permitted to purchase real es- tate and shares in Israel. In order to repatriate the principal or profits on these investments, proof is required by an authorized dealer that they were purchased with foreign currency through an autho- rized dealer. Direct loans in any form from Israeli residents to nonresidents are subject to licensing. Investments abroad by Israeli residents are sub- ject to a value-added tax of 7.5 percent. Gold Gold bullion for industry may be imported by an importer holding an import license. Gold bullion and coins for investment, or certificates conferring a right to gold bullion, must be held in a gold custody account with an authorized dealer; beginning from January 16,1984, residents have not been permitted to buy gold bullion or coins for investment purposes. The following bullion coins are at present in- cluded in the list of gold coins for investment: (1) Krugerrand of South Africa; (2) 50 dollar Maple Leafs of Canada; (3) 50 pesos of Mexico; (4) 100 corona and 4 dukat coins of Austria; (5) sovereigns of Great Britain; (6) 10 dollar and 20 dollar Liberty coins of the United States; and (7) 20 franc napoleon coins of France. Other gold coins and medallions may be bought, sold, or held by an Is- raeli resident without restriction. These coins may be imported and exported in the same manner as other goods. Imports of gold included in the above categories are subject to a value-added tax of 15 percent. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement January 3. Not for Redistribution ITALY (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Italy is the Italian Lira. Italy par- ticipates with Belgium, Denmark, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Ireland, Lux- embourg, the Netherlands, and Spain in the ex- change rate and intervention mechanism of the Eu- ropean Monetary System (EMS). In accordance with this agreement, Italy maintains spot exchange rates between the Italian lira and the currencies of the other participants within margins of 6 percent above or below the cross rates based on the central rates expressed in European Currency Units (ECUs).1 The agreement implies that the Bank of Italy (the central bank) stands ready to buy or sell the curren- cies of the other participating states in unlimited amounts at specified intervention rates. The partici- pants in the EMS do not maintain the exchange rates for other currencies within fixed limits. How- ever, in order to ensure a proper functioning of the system, they intervene in concert to smooth out fluctuations in exchange rates, the intervention cur- rencies being each other's and the U.S. dollar. Rates for 20 foreign currencies2 are quoted daily. On December 29, 1989, the rate for the U.S. dollar was Lit 1,270.5 per US$1. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. The monetary authorities do not, in principle, intervene in the forward exchange market; forward premiums and discounts are normally left to the interplay of market forces. Authorized banks are allowed to engage in spot and forward exchange transactions in any currency and can, without au- thorization, buy foreign currency futures at foreign exchanges. A reserve requirement equal to 25 per- cent of the increase in net foreign currency deposits is applied to authorized banks' foreign currency deposits. Forward cover is freely permitted for com- mercial and financial transactions when effected through authorized banks. These banks are subject Affective January 5, 1990, these margins were reduced to 2.25 percent (i.e., the same margins as applied by other partici- pants of the EMS) when the lira was realigned within the EMS. 2Currencies quoted are Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Greek drachmas, Irish pounds, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Por- tuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, U.S. dollars, and ECUs. These currencies are referred to in the Italian regulations as the conto valutario currencies. to the following regulations: (1) their foreign ex- change position on a daily basis may not exceed 5 percent of the average of their spot foreign ex- change assets at the end of the previous three months; (2) they may have a net creditor external position in foreign currencies only up to the limit permitted for the overall foreign exchange position; (3) they may not have a net creditor external position in lire (i.e., their lending in lire abroad may not exceed their fund-raising in lire from nonresidents); and (4) forward transactions may be offset against spot operations in the opposite direction only up to the spot-against forward ceiling, allotted to each bank by the Italian Foreign Exchange Office and increased by not less than 50 percent in relation to the situation prevailing on September 30,1988. Au- thorized banks may also write foreign exchange options for sale to residents and nonresidents, pro- vided that such operations are matched globally by transactions in the opposite direction according to currency, amount, and maturity. Residents are per- mitted to conduct currency options from authorized banks for all foreign transactions but may conduct forward or currency option transactions in foreign exchange only with residents. Italy formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2,3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the Italian Exchange Office (Ufficio Italiano dei Cambi, or UIC). All sales and purchases of exchange must be effected through banks authorized for this purpose. On October 1,1988, a new foreign exchange control law entered into force. It is based on the principle that all commercial and financial transactions by residents with nonresidents are free unless they are specifically restricted by the law. As of the same date, residents are free to carry out foreign transac- tions, with the following exceptions: (1) residents are not allowed to hold funds in bank accounts abroad and they must surrender foreign currencies to the authorized banks;3 (2) nonbank residents are not allowed to extend credit lines to nonresidents or 3However, foreign currency acquired in connection with com- mercial and financial transactions can be held in accounts with domestic banks for up to 120 days. 252 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 252 ITALY to purchase money market instruments abroad with a residual maturity of less than 180 days;4 and (3) residents are required to channel all foreign transactions through banks authorized by the Bank of Italy to deal in foreign exchange, and to keep in deposit with them their foreign securities acquired abroad. The Government may impose restrictions on foreign transactions on a temporary basis to con- tain short-term pressures on the balance of pay- ments or instability in the foreign exchange market. However, the expiration dates for all such measures would be specified at the time of the announcement of the measure. Payments to and from the Republic of San Marino and Vatican City are made in internal lire and are therefore not subject to exchange control. For statistical and monitoring purposes, foreign currency transfers and foreign exchange transac- tions must be channeled via authorized intermedi- aries (the Bank of Italy, the Italian Foreign Exchange Office, authorized banks, and, subject to certain limitations, the Postal Administration). Prescription of Currency Settlements with foreign countries are normally made in convertible currencies or in lire on Foreign Accounts. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents are allowed to maintain Foreign Ac- counts with authorized banks in lire and in foreign exchange. Foreign Accounts in lire may be credited with trans- fers from other Foreign Accounts, with lire from current and capital payments, and with the pro- ceeds from sales of convertible currencies. They may be debited, upon the holder's request, for pur- chases of any of these currencies in the ordinary market, for transfers to any other Foreign Account, for payments to residents of Italy for current and capital transactions, and for drawings in cash by the holder of the account or his nominee. Foreign Accounts in foreign exchange may be cred- ited with foreign exchange receipts from abroad, transfers from other Foreign Accounts (in foreign exchange), payments from residents for authorized transactions, and receipts from the sale of assets. Imports and Import Payments Imports are governed by the Decree of Decem- ber 24, 1987 (No. 589), which entered into effect on 4Effective March 2, 1990, this limit was eliminated. January 1, 1988. The import regulations vary with the country of origin. Countries are grouped into three major areas: Zone A, which is subdivided into subzones A/1 (European Communities (EC) coun- tries, Guadeloupe, French Guyana, Martinique, and Reunion), A/2 (overseas countries and territo- ries, member countries of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA), and other countries associated with the EC), and A/3 (third countries); Zone B, which comprises member countries of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA), Albania, the People's Republic of China, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea; and Zone C (Japan). The import control procedures distinguish between goods that may be freely imported without quan- titative restrictions and goods that require a special license. Import liberalization is virtually complete for subzones A/1 and A/2, and very few quantitative restrictions remain for subzone A/3. Many types of goods from Zones B and C are restricted. For im- ports from countries in Zone B, as well as from Yugoslavia, the country of origin must also be the country of shipment. Imports from non-EC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) of the EC are subject to variable import levies that have replaced all previous barriers to imports. Com- mon EC regulations are also applied to imports from non-EC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products. For all authorized imports, the authorized banks, upon request of the interested operators who must fill out a form for monitoring and statistical pur- poses, provide foreign exchange and effect pay- ments.5 International postal money orders may be used for import payments, subject to a limit for each transaction (of Lit 5 million). Balances held by resi- dents in Foreign Exchange Accounts in domestic banks for foreign exchange purchases for commer- cial and financial transactions abroad are subject to a 120-day limit. Payments for Invisibles The authorized banks may sell foreign exchange for payments for invisibles listed in Annex III of the Rome Treaty, provided that the necessary form, where required, is submitted. Residents may use international postal money orders for payments, up to a maximum amount of Lit 5 million. 5For transactions up to Lit 10 million, the operator is required to make only a verbal declaration. For operations exceeding Lit 10 million but less than Lit 20 million, forms must be filled out. For operations exceeding Lit 20 million, documents must be submit- ted together with forms. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY 253 There are no limits on expenditures for tourism, business, medical treatment, and education. Resi- dents traveling to foreign countries may export Ital- ian bank notes up to Lit 1 million, and carry with them credit cards and payment instruments in for- eign currencies and external lire without limit, pro- vided that any amount in excess of Lit 2.5 million has been acquired from the authorized banks. Resi- dents traveling abroad may write nontransferable checks in favor of nonresidents, drawing on their domestic bank accounts up to Lit 10 million for related expenses. Nonresidents can freely take out foreign ex- change up to the equivalent of Lit 5 million without showing proof that foreign exchange has been brought into Italy. They can also take out Lit 1 mil- lion in Italian bank notes; they may export larger amounts by providing proof of acquisition in Italy or previous importation. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to any country of products on a special list (tabella esport) require export licenses; other ex- ports do not require authorization. Resident export- ers are required to channel all foreign transactions through authorized banks and can hold currency acquired in connection with exports in accounts with domestic banks only up to 120 days. For ex- ports exceeding Lit 10 million in value, a form is required; for exports exceeding Lit 20 billion in value, the form must be accompanied by export documents. All export proceeds must be surrendered to au- thorized banks within 60 days of effective receipt. Proceeds in U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Jap- anese yen, Australian dollars, and externally con- vertible European currencies may be retained by authorized banks on behalf of the recipients in For- eign Exchange Accounts for up to 120 days, during which period such balances may be used for permit- ted transactions or sold to authorized banks.6 In cases where authorized banks have not received adequate information to enable them to release the funds, the balances may be posted to Ordinary Waiting Accounts (conti di attesa) for a period of up to 60 days from the date of surrender. If the necessary information is not received during the 60-day wait- ing period, the proceeds must be returned abroad or assigned to the UIC upon completion of the trans- action and will be converted into lire at the lowest exchange rate quoted during the waiting period. Export proceeds may also be received by interna- tional postal money order, and in foreign bank notes that are accepted in the country of issue for credit to bank accounts, balances in which are convertible at market rates. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from current invisibles are subject to the same collection, retention, and surrender require- ments as receipts from exports. Shipping and insur- ance companies and forwarding agencies may keep Operating Accounts (conti autorizzati) in U.S. dol- lars, Canadian dollars, Japanese yen, Australian dollars, and externally convertible European cur- rencies; unused balances must be surrendered peri- odically. Residents may retain foreign bank notes not exceeding the equivalent of Lit 2.5 million. Per- sons may bring in any amount in foreign or domes- tic bank notes. Capital Residents are free to undertake, through autho- rized banks, most financial transactions, including direct investments and purchases and sales of any foreign securities, except bonds and money market instruments with a residual maturity of less than 180 days,7 real estate investments, and loans. For- eign securities, except securities with a value of Lit 5 million or less, have to be deposited with an Italian bank or with a bank abroad for an account of an Italian bank. Residents are free to borrow abroad and to lend to nonresidents. Foreign investments in Italy, of any kind, includ- ing both direct and portfolio investment and the purchase of real estate, are free, and no restrictions are applied to their repatriation. Gold Residents may freely hold and negotiate gold in any form in Italy, with the exception of unrefined gold imported under ministerial license for indus- trial purposes. The monetary authorities may freely acquire unrefined gold abroad. Authorized banks may acquire unrefined gold abroad, with the autho- rization of the Ministry of Foreign Trade, to sell to Italian firms. Exports of wrought and semimanufac- tured gold, other than jewelry, are subject to licens- ing. Imports of unrefined gold are not subject to value-added tax. The exportation of gold coins that are legal tender in a foreign country is freely allowed against payment. Imports of other gold coins for numismatic purposes are free but subject to value- added tax at 19 percent. Effective March 2, 1990, this time limit was abolished. 7Effective March 2, 1990, this exception was eliminated. ©International Monetary Fund.
