Not for Redistribution MEXICO (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Mexico is the Mexican Peso. There are two exchange markets: the controlled market and the free market. In principle, the ex- change rate in the controlled market is adjusted daily on the basis, inter alia, of the following factors: (1) the demand and supply of foreign exchange in the controlled market; (2) the objective regarding an adequate level of international reserves; (3) the movement of domestic and foreign prices; and (4) movements in other exchange rate relation- ships.1 Transactions at the controlled market rate include (1) merchandise export receipts (with some exceptions); (2) payments by in-bond industries for wages, salaries, leasings or rents, fiscal obligations, expenses relating to insurance, and the purchase of Mexican goods and services, other than fixed as- sets; (3) royalties for the use of foreign technologies and patents; (4) payments of principal, interest, and related expenses resulting from financial and suppliers' credits by the public and private sectors; (5) payments for imports with some exceptions; (6) expenses in relation to the Mexican foreign ser- vice and contributions regarding Mexico's member- ship in international organizations; and (7) other transactions specifically authorized by the Secre- tariat of Finance and Public Credit (SHCP). Eligible participants in the controlled market may choose to complete the transaction at a retail rate, agreed between participants and the banks, or at the "equilibrium exchange rate," which is deter- mined for the controlled market each day at a fixing session (in the Bank of Mexico), in which represen- tatives of the major banks exchange bids for pur- chases and sales of foreign exchange; the Bank of Mexico may also submit bids in these sessions. On December 28, 1989, the equilibrium exchange rate in the controlled market for the U.S. dollar was Mex$2,641 per US$1, and the buying and selling rates in the same market were Mex$2,627 and Mex$2,647 per US$1, respectively. Within the free market, no limitations apply to the access to, ownership, or transfer of foreign ex- change. On December 28, 1989, the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the free market were Mex$2,667 and Mex$2,692 per US$1, respectively. 1 Beginning January 1,1989, the peso is being depreciated daily against the U.S. dollar by preannounced fixed amounts. The Bank of Mexico provides, through the Trust Fund for the Coverage of Foreign Exchange Risk (FICORCA), an instrument for forward cover of for- eign exchange for the repayment of certain foreign debt obligations in respect of debt contracted or rescheduled on a long-term basis with foreign fi- nancial entities and suppliers. On January 5, 1987, the Bank of Mexico began to operate a short-term foreign exchange risk coverage market through which commercial and financial operations are cov- ered against exchange rate fluctuations. The scheme applies only to the U.S. dollar, and the coverage is based on the equilibrium exchange rate prevailing on the date of contract. All Mexican credit institutions are authorized to operate in the free market either directly or through their exchange houses. Mexican banks are pro- hibited from receiving domestic currency deposits from foreign financial institutions abroad or from non-Mexican exchange houses, except when such funds represent the counterpart of foreign currency sold to a Mexican bank for the purpose of a borrow- ing operation, or when authorized on a case-by-case basis by the Directorate of International Operations in the Bank of Mexico. Financial institutions located in the areas bordering the United States are permit- ted to open checking accounts denominated in U.S. dollars for Mexican residents. On November 12,1946, Mexico notified the Fund that it was prepared formally to accept the obliga- tions of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Foreign exchange policies are established by SHCP and the Bank of Mexico. The exchange control system is administered by the Bank of Mexico through Mexican credit institutions, which carry out most of the transactions in the controlled market. Prescription of Currency Apart from the exceptions described below, there are no obligations prescribing the method or cur- rency of payments to nonresidents, neither in the free nor in the controlled market, but obligations deriving from the sale of foreign exchange in the controlled market must be made in the currencies 315 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 316 MEXICO approved by the Bank of Mexico. In accordance with the payments agreements with Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela, controlled market payments to these countries must be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Bank of Mexico and the central bank of the country concerned, within the framework of the multilateral clearing system of the Latin American Integration Association (LAIA). Similar arrange- ments exist with Costa Rica, Cuba, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Yugoslavia. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses from the Secretariat of Commerce and Industrial Promotion (SECOFI) are required for 263 of the 11,856 items in Mexico's general import tariff, with the exception of temporary imports of raw materials and intermediate goods for export industries. For the items subject to licensing, ap- plications for import licenses may cover the appli- cant's import needs for nine months on average, and can be extended for an additional three months. Import needs are estimated at 20 percent above previous actual imports but may be increased when justified. New licenses are issued only if the appli- cant can demonstrate that at least 70 percent of earlier licenses have been effectively used. For some commodities, "open-end" import licenses may be granted, allowing imports to be effected during a period of six months to one year, subject to an over- all limit. Depending on the importer's performance, the license may be renewed repeatedly. All imports must be accompanied by an export- er's declaration of shipment. Imports by public en- tities and governmental agencies are subject to prior approval by the SECOFI. Since July 1, 1988, the im- port tariff structure has been based on the harmo- nized product description and coding system of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). Imports from member states of the LAIA and other Latin American countries are subject to preferential tariffs. A free trade zone regime is granted for cer- tain regions in the country until June 30, 1991, and until August 31, 1995, for the newly established zone with Guatemala. This regime allows imports into these regions without customs tariffs as long as the imported goods are not similar to those pro- duced domestically in the same regions. In the controlled market, importers may acquire foreign exchange for the full value of merchandise already imported and for which payment has not yet been made. Importers must register a commit- ment of use (or devolution) of foreign exchange (CUDD) to obtain foreign currency for advance pay- ments; they have a period of 180 days to show evi- dence of use of the foreign exchange for payment of imports and associated expenses or to return the foreign exchange if no adequate substantiation of its use is provided. Full advance payment for all im- ports is allowed if the value of goods does not ex- ceed US$10,000, or if payment is made through letters of credit; in the latter case, there is a 60-day period in which to show evidence of use of foreign exchange. For imports exceeding US$10,000 in value, only 20 percent advance payment is permit- ted. Advance payment for associated expenses is permitted up to maximum authorized percentages (6 percent f.o.b. value for North American imports, and 8 percent f.o.b. value for other regions). Confir- mation by suppliers is required for individual trans- actions exceeding US$10,000. Exporters are allowed to retain foreign exchange proceeds up to 100 per- cent of their requirements for advance payments of imported inputs. These facilities are also extended to the imported inputs, already within the country, of their domestic suppliers. Payments for Invisibles Except for the items specified below, payments for invisibles are made through the free exchange market. The payments made through the controlled exchange market consist of: (1) principal and inter- est payments on public and private sector debt with foreign financial entities, foreign suppliers, and Mexican banks; (2) fees related to credits from for- eign financial entities, up to 3/4 of 1 percent of the total amount of each credit; (3) expenses of the Mexican foreign service, contributions, and allot- ments for Mexico's membership in international or- ganizations; (4) expenses related to foreign trade; (5) royalties and obligations deriving from juridical acts in force as of June 1,1984 and recorded with the National Registry of Technological Transfer, with payments to be made through authorized Mexican banks; and (6) expenses on account of scholarships granted by the National Council of Science and Technology (CONACYT) and those approved by CONACYT or the Bank of Mexico for studies in for- eign countries. The contracting of insurance for persons in Mex- ico, or on property of Mexican ownership, or where the risks are on the account of persons in Mexico, or may occur in Mexico, is permitted only with Mexi- can companies, except when Mexican firms deem it convenient not to execute such transactions, in which case the prior authorization of SHCP is re- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO 317 quired. The provisions are not applicable to reinsurance. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports do not require licenses. Exportation of a few specified items is prohibited. All merchan- dise export receipts in excess of US$5,000 a week are subject to surrender requirements in the controlled market, within a standard period of 90 days. Hand- icraft exports of up to US$8,000 per operation are exempt from the surrender requirement. Special procedures apply for the surrender of export pro- ceeds beyond the standard limit of 90 days. If a sale of foreign exchange occurs beyond the required period without authorization, the applicable ex- change rate is only a certain percentage of the rate of the selling day, which varies according to the delay in surrendering the foreign exchange. Exporters of jewelry and precious metals must surrender their proceeds through specifically authorized credit institutions. Exporting enterprises are authorized to open in Mexican banks special accounts denominated in Mexican pesos; but only proceeds from exports can be deposited in such accounts. Interest payable on these deposits is equivalent to the rate of deprecia- tion of the controlled exchange rate against the U.S. dollar, plus the corresponding Eurodollar deposit rates. Mexican banks are also authorized to accept deposits in U.S. dollars by Mexican firms and grant loans in foreign currency for the production, ship- ment, storage, and long-term financing of exports. Such deposits can be constituted only in U.S. dol- lars and do not earn an interest rate higher than LIBOR plus 1 percent. Individual deposit accounts under this scheme must be for a minimum of US$5,000, with the exception of deposits made by enterprises in the free trade zones and border areas. Payments are made abroad in foreign currency. Under the Program for Integral Promotion of Ex- ports (PROFIEX), a drawback system of import duty payments by exporters and their domestic suppliers is in operation. With effect from June 6,1985, the Federal Govern- ment provides a facility called "Certificates of the Right to Import Merchandise for Export" (DiMEx), through which exporters with at least 30 percent value added may import, without permit or license requirement, up to 30 percent of the value of their exports; excluded from the scheme are 297 items of the general import tariff, representing 2.5 percent of total import items. Exporters are also eligible to purchase imported inputs at the controlled market rate, as are im- porters. In addition, they may use their export pro- ceeds to pay for imports, associated expenses, and recorded financial debt and suppliers' credits. Under an understanding on export subsidies and countervailing duties concluded between Mexico and the United States on April 23,1985, Mexico has been granted, until 1991, the benefit of the injury test in countervailing duty investigations, in return for which it has undertaken to phase out export subsidies. Proceeds from Invisibles In-bond industries are required to sell foreign exchange through the controlled market for the equivalent in Mexican pesos of the payment they make for items specified in the Exchange Control Decree, including payment of wages, salaries, leas- ings or rents, the purchase of Mexican goods and services other than fixed assets, local and federal taxes, insurance premiums, interest and other ac- cessory payments pertaining to financing payable in Mexican pesos, as well as any other operational expenditure within Mexico. This regime does not apply to foreign exchange earmarked for payment of credits granted to third parties by foreign finan- cial institutions for the construction of buildings, or industrial parks whose use or enjoyment has been granted to such in-bond industries, provided it has been agreed that the amount of the benefits from such use or possession be applied to liquidating the aforementioned credits. In-bond industries must sell their foreign ex- change no later than the last business day of the month in which such expenditures are made. In addition, they must present to the Bank of Mexico, and to SECOFI within the first 15 business days of each month, information as to the dates and amounts of foreign exchange sold to the country's credit institutions during the month immediately preceding, as well as the amounts of Mexican pesos they disbursed to pay each of the specified items. In-bond industries must effect these foreign ex- change transactions through Mexican credit institutions. Capital Foreign investment, including the transfer of funds relating to increment of capital stock as well as payment of dividends, is excluded from the coverage of the controlled foreign exchange market. Accordingly, such activities are effected through the free market and are not subject to any restrictions, having only to conform to the norms contained in the applicable laws and regulations. Loan proceeds ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 318 MEXICO repayable abroad in foreign currency and obtained from foreign financial institutions or Mexican credit institutions are channeled through the controlled exchange market, except when said proceeds are used for the servicing of specified long-term exter- nal debt or for import payments. The Federal Gov- ernment has ownership and control over certain strategic areas, such as petroleum, basic pe- trochemical production, radioactive minerals, elec- trical and nuclear energy, specified mining ac- tivities, railroads, mail and banking services, and other activities so stated by Mexican law. In addi- tion, foreign investment is forbidden in the follow- ing activities: insurance and surety bond com- panies, investment funds, stockbroker firms, money exchange establishments, radio and televi- sion, the public transportation system, and forestry, as well as any other areas specified as such by the Federal Government. Restrictions on foreign capital participation in new direct foreign investment were liberalized sub- stantially in May 1989. Foreign investors may hold a majority share in new firms (in sectors other than those restricted to the State and national com- panies) as long as new investments meet the follow- ing conditions: (1) they must not exceed a max- imum amount set periodically by the National Foreign Investment Commission (CNIE); (2) the fi- nancing that they require must be obtained outside the country (in the case of foreign companies estab- lished in Mexico, the capital requirement may be financed from their own resources); (3) they must be located outside the areas of greatest industrial concentration; (4) the accumulated foreign ex- change flows that they generate must balance over the first three years of operation; (5) they must create permanent employment and establish ade- quate training programs; and (6) they must use appropriate technology and observe legal provi- sions regarding ecological standards. Foreign inves- tors are authorized to hold a 100 percent share in new or existing in-bond enterprises producing for export markets. Foreign investments are permitted in the Mexican stock market through specially de- signed trust funds, but participation is not allowed in the administration of the companies involved. Direct foreign investments in Mexico must be re- corded with the CNIE, and applications by foreign individuals or enterprises to acquire more than 49 percent of the capital of a Mexican company require the prior authorization of the CNIE. Invest- ment proposals to which the CNIE has not re- sponded within a period of 45 days after application is submitted are considered to have been approved. The rules favoring the trust funds that enable foreign investors to participate in tourist projects have been simplified. Gold Goldsmiths or manufacturers may acquire non- monetary gold through authorized Mexican credit institutions at the controlled exchange rate for the elaboration of products earmarked for export. There is a value-added tax of 15 percent on sales of non- monetary gold. Purchases and sales of monetary gold by Mexican credit institutions are exempt from the tax. Monetary gold exports are exempted from foreign exchange surrender requirements, up to a maximum of 200 grams. Gold may be freely bought or sold in Mexico at the free market exchange rate. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement January 1. The rules governing the establishment of the peso's exchange rate were modified, whereby it would be depreciated daily against the U.S. dollar by preannounced fixed amounts. August 31. Loans from international financial or- ganizations were transacted at the controlled ex- change market rate. Imports and Import Payments January 11. It was announced that products sub- ject to tariff rates of 0-5 percent would be subject to a rate of 10 percent. June 28. Importers were required to register with the National Registry of Importers and Exporters. December 11. Changes to regulations affecting the importation of new automobiles were announced. The new regulations would be implemented begin- ning January 1, 1991. During 1991 and 1992, auto- mobile imports would be allowed up to a limit equivalent to 15 percent of domestic sales. All im- ports must contain Mexican value added of at least 36 percent. Changes to regulations affecting the importation of light lorries would enter into effect in 1993, and those for heavy lorries in 1994. Exports and Export Proceeds June 28. Exporters were required to register with the National Registry of Importers and Exporters. July 27. A joint commission for the promotion of non-oil exports, with the participation of the official and private sectors, was established. ©International Monetary Fund.
