Not for Redistribution PANAMA (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Panama is the Panamanian Bal- boa, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar at B 1 = US$1. The U.S. dollar is legal tender and circulates freely in Panama; locally issued currency is repre- sented by balboa coins and several commemorative coins. Commercial banks quote buying and selling rates for certain other currencies based on the buy- ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. There are no taxes or subsidies on pur- chases or sales of foreign exchange. On November 26,1946, Panama notified the Fund that it accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sec- tions 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Most import and export licenses are issued by the Price Regulation Office, a semiautonomous institu- tion of the Panamanian Government. The Price Reg- ulation Office is responsible for the implementation of restrictions on imports of commodities that com- pete with national production and on certain ex- ports. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry de- termines the import quotas for commodities listed in trade agreements; the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Development, jointly with the Price Regulation Office, determines the import quotas for certain agricultural commodities. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency require- ments. Imports and Import Payments Import quotas are maintained on some 20 prod- ucts, including oil, timber, salt, fishmeal, milk, and sugar. Some of these are not licensed. Import licens- ing applies to some products subject to quotas and to imports of various foodstuffs. Imports by the public sector are subject to special requirements. Payments abroad may be made freely. In addition to import duty, a tax of 7.5 percent of the f.o.b. value is levied on private sector imports of all dutiable goods other than specified phar- maceutical products and foodstuffs, for which the rate is 2.5 percent and 3.5 percent, respectively; books and certain agricultural inputs are exempt. Most imports are also subject to a tax of 5 percent calculated on the sum of the c . i .f. value and all other import taxes and charges; among the exemptions are fuels, lubricants, and related products, as well as foodstuffs, specified medicinal and pharmaceuti- cal products, and imports into the Free Zone. Exports and Export Proceeds Export taxes are levied on gold, silver, platinum, manganese, other minerals, sugar, bananas, co- conuts, scrap metals, pearls, animal wax, nispero gum, ipecac root, and rubber. Exports of certain foodstuffs, firearms, and ammunition are pro- hibited. Certain nontraditional exports (with a mini- mum of 20 percent value added in Panama) are eligible for tax credit certificates. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments for and proceeds from invisibles are not restricted. A travel tax of 4 percent is levied on air and sea tickets bought in Panama or on such tickets purchased for travelers starting their trip in Panama. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or non- residents. A significant number of foreign- controlled banks are authorized to conduct business only with nonresidents. A banking holiday was de- clared on March 4,1988, and restrictions were main- tained on demand and savings deposits with- drawals and on interbank deposit balances after the reopening of banks on May 9, 1988. Although pro- gressively eased, restrictions on savings deposits and interbank balances were in effect at the end of 1989. The restrictions on demand deposits were eliminated on January 1, 1989. Gold Panama has issued two commemorative gold coins with face values of B 100 and B 500, which are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may freely hold gold in any form, at home or abroad, and 370 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PANAMA 371 may freely negotiate gold in any form with residents or nonresidents, at home and abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry car- ried as personal effects by travelers are subject to license if made by residents other than the mone- tary authorities; import licenses are issued freely by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, and export licenses are granted by the Ministry of Finance and Treasury. Exports of unworked gold produced in Panama are subject to an export duty of 1 percent ad valorem, and exports of gold coins (other than U.S. coins, which are exempt) are subject to a duty of 0.5 percent. Changes During 1989 Imports and Import Payments October 1. The customs tariff rates on some 130 items were reduced to 2.5 percent from an average of 27.5 percent. Capital January 1. The restrictions on withdrawals of de- mand deposits were lifted. October 1. New incentives for foreign investment processing zones were announced. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PAPUA NEW GUINEA (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Papua New Guinea is the Papua New Guinea Kina. The exchange rate of the kina in terms of the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, is adjusted daily on the basis of its relationship to a weighted basket of currencies representing Papua New Guinea's major trading partners. On Decem- ber 29, 1989, the official buying and selling rates quoted by the Bank of Papua New Guinea for the U.S. dollar were US$1.1641 and US$1.1625, respectively, per K 1. The commercial banks, the only authorized foreign exchange dealers, publish rates for all current transactions with their customers, within a maximum spread of 2 percent between the buying and selling rates. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. Under the current forward exchange market reg- ulations, exporters and importers can hedge their exchange rate risks arising from exports or imports by selling foreign exchange forward to or buying foreign exchange forward from the commercial banks. The commercial banks in turn hedge their forward positions with firms through forward deals with the Bank of Papua New Guinea. Under this arrangement, the Bank of Papua New Guinea sets the daily forward rates both for its own transactions with banks and for banks' transactions with firms. Major mineral exporters use other means of hedg- ing their exchange rate risks, and the forward mar- ket is thus usually dominated by importers. The Bank of Papua New Guinea therefore normally has a net forward liability to the commercial banks, which covers the banks' net forward liability to firms. Under the current arrangement, the forward market is effectively separated from the spot mar- ket. The commercial banks are permitted to hedge their forward purchases and sales in the normal manner through their balance sheets. Forward rates do not therefore reflect hedging costs, that is, inter- est rate differentials between Papua New Guinea and other countries. The Bank of Papua New Guinea sets the forward rates without regard to interest rates and assumes all the risks of the for- ward contracts. Papua New Guinea formally accepted the obliga- tions of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from December 4, 1975. Administration of Control Foreign exchange control is administered by the Bank of Papua New Guinea under the Central Bank- ing (Foreign Exchange and Gold) Regulations, Chapter 138. Overall policy is determined by the Government with the advice of the Bank of Papua New Guinea and the Ministry of Finance. The Bank of Papua New Guinea has delegated considerable powers to the commercial banks operating in Papua New Guinea, which have been appointed autho- rized dealers in foreign exchange and gold. Export licensing is administered by the Department of For- eign Affairs and Trade. Prescription of Currency Contractual commitments, which are expressed in a foreign currency, to persons resident outside Papua New Guinea must be met by payments in foreign currency.1 Export proceeds may be received in any foreign currency. Nonresident Accounts The Bank of Papua New Guinea controls all credits to nonresident bank accounts; funds cred- ited to such accounts may be withdrawn without further formality. Nonresidents must have approval to maintain foreign currency accounts. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a limited number of goods are re- stricted for health, security, or protective reasons. Imports of a number of items, including canned meat, sugar, pork, chicken and hens, fowls, and certain fresh fruits and vegetables, are prohibited for protective purposes. A number of items, includ- ing laundry bar soap, plywood, and specified fruits and vegetables (e.g., broccoli, cauliflower, garlic, and celery), are subject to import quotas and al- lowed to be imported through specified ports of entry; temperate fruits and onions are subject to import quotas on a nationwide basis. Other items, including poultry other than chicken, hens, and fowls, and reconstituted wood products, are subject to licensing; these licenses are issued on a quarterly basis. Quotas are adjusted quarterly, reflecting the 1 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than the kina. 372 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PAPUA NEW GUINEA 373 extent to which local production can meet domestic demand. Quotas are typically imposed for three- year periods, and quota allocations are made on a pro rata basis with purchases of domestically pro- duced goods. Authorized dealers have the authority to approve applications for import transactions that are not sub- ject to quotas or licensing requirements without referring to the Bank of Papua New Guinea. The tariff regime consists of the following: (1) essential items, including food staples (rice, and tinned fish and tinned meat other than those produced domes- tically) and medical and educational supplies, are duty free; (2) 5-9 percent for basic goods, including some consumer goods and raw materials; (3) 25- 30 percent for intermediate goods, including goods with satisfactory domestic substitutes; and (4) 50- 75 percent for luxury goods, including television sets, jewelry, cosmetics, cameras, video recorders, and nonessential food and beverage items. Payments for Invisibles Approval is readily given for most payments for invisibles, provided that supporting documentation is produced. The remittance overseas of life insur- ance premiums on new policies written after De- cember 31, 1975 in the names of permanent resi- dents covering strictly the death risk element is permitted with the approval of the Bank of Papua New Guinea. The remittance of endowment as- surance premiums is prohibited. Applications for foreign exchange for tourist travel in excess of the equivalent of K 8,000 an adult and K 3,000 a minor a year and K 4,000 for each business trip are referred to the Bank of Papua New Guinea for consideration, and they are approved in cases of bona fide need. Travelers may not take or send out of Papua New Guinea domestic currency in excess of K 200 in notes and K 5 in coins; however, domestic coins issued for numismatic purposes may be taken out freely. Overseas visitors are free to take out any currency that they brought in and declared on arrival. Exports and Export Proceeds Residents of Papua New Guinea may export goods without exchange control formality on condi- tion that they comply with the terms of the general authority issued by the Bank of Papua New Guinea. The essential conditions of this authority are that payment for goods exported is received within six months of the date of export and that the proceeds are sold to an authorized dealer in Papua New Guinea. When exporters are not in a position to comply with the conditions of the general authority, they must apply to the Bank for specific authority. No authority is needed for certain categories of goods, including passengers' personal effects. Ex- port licenses are required for specified goods (e.g., logs, pearls, fisheries and marine products, wood chips, sandalwood, rattan, coffee, cocoa, and copra) under the Export (Valuation and Control) Act. Exports of most unprocessed products are sub- ject to export levies. There is a 10 percent export tax on all logs and timber,2 and, since June 1989, a ban has been applied on the export of more valuable species of timber in log form. Exports of fish are subject to a tax of 10 percent. Proceeds from Invisibles Approval is required for the disposal of foreign currency proceeds other than by sale to an autho- rized dealer in Papua New Guinea or for its reten- tion. (Residents are not permitted to retain foreign exchange earnings from any source without the approval of the Bank of Papua New Guinea.) Over- seas visitors may bring in any amount of currency for travel expenditure. Capital Outward transfers of overseas-owned capital (i.e., proceeds from liquidation of direct invest- ments) are normally allowed. Direct investments outside Papua New Guinea by companies and other organizations operating in Papua New Guinea are subject to certain limitations. The approval of the Bank of Papua New Guinea is required for the ac- quisition and disposal of foreign securities by per- manent residents. When an investment is for port- folio reasons, the amount that may be invested is limited to K 15,000 a person a year. (Children under the age of 18 are not eligible to receive this al- lowance.) Investment may only take the form of marketable securities and not of cash deposits. Ap- provals carry the condition that income from the investment must be returned to Papua New Guinea as received, and details of investments held and income received must be submitted annually to the Bank of Papua New Guinea. Portfolio investments by companies are not permitted. Persons who have been declared to be temporary residents by an au- thorized dealer or the Bank of Papua New Guinea may repatriate their surplus earnings without limit. Prior clearance from the tax authorities is required for these transactions if the amount exceeds 2The export tax on logs and timber took effect on January 1, 1990. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 374 PAPUA NEW GUINEA K 10,000 in any calendar year. Residents may bor- row, with the approval of the Central Bank, on rea- sonable terms, and external obligations may be ser- viced within an annual allowance of K 15,000; that is, interest and amortization payments must not exceed K 15,000 a year. Approval by the Bank of Papua New Guinea is required for all new or increased foreign investment in Papua New Guinea. In some cases the Bank of Papua New Guinea refers such applications to the Ministry of Finance. Foreign investments other than those in banking and insurance are also sub- ject to approval by the National Investment and Development Authority. Approval from the Bank of Papua New Guinea is also necessary for the ac- knowledgment of indebtedness, partly so that the right to receive a payment may be conferred on a nonresident and partly to ensure that the terms are reasonable. In practice, the requirement that off- shore borrowing by private sector entities in Papua New Guinea may not exceed the debt/equity ratio of 3:1 is normally strictly enforced, except for com- panies involved in mining and oil exploration ac- tivities or in cases where sound economic reasons exist. Commercial banks may undertake offshore borrowing for on-lending to exporters, provided that assumption of exchange risk is not involved. A minimum moratorium period of one year is re- quired for repayments on foreign debt following loan disbursement. Gold Dealings in gold in Papua New Guinea were de- regulated, with effect from January 1, 1987, when royalties and withholding tax payable on sales of alluvial gold were removed and replaced with a 5 percent ad valorem export tax. Exports and im- ports of gold by individuals are not permitted. Changes During 1989 Imports and Import Payments April 1. The basic customs tariff rate was raised from 7.5 percent to 8.5 percent during 1989, and it was raised to 9 percent on January 1, 1990. Imports of poultry other than chicken were no longer subject to quotas, but were made subject to licensing. December 15. It was announced that effective Jan- uary 1, 1990, the duties on a range of agricultural and fishery products and raw materials for the man- ufacturing industries would be reduced from the current level of 8.5 percent to 5 percent. Not for Redistribution PARAGUAY (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Paraguay is the Paraguayan Guarani. The authorities do not maintain margins in respect of foreign exchange transactions, and ex- change rates are determined largely on the basis of demand and supply conditions in the exchange market. Although the Central Bank intervenes when necessary to smooth out undesirable fluctua- tions, it does not interfere with any underlying mar- ket trends. Private and public sector transactions in respect of merchandise imports and exports, ser- vices, and private capital transactions are carried out through the authorized commercial banks or exchange houses. On December 29, 1989, the aver- age rate prevailing in this market was about Gl,218 per US$1. Public debt-service payments and pay- ments for government services are channeled through the Central Bank at the rate prevailing on the day the transactions are effected. A tax of 0.5 percent is levied by the Central Bank on sales of foreign exchange to the Government for the payment of imports of goods and services. Au- thorized commercial banks charge a commission of 1 percent on all sales of foreign exchange to im- porters, the proceeds of which are then transferred to the Central Bank. For operations channeled through the multilateral clearing arrangements of the Latin American Integration Association (LAIA), banks charge a commission of 1 percent on all sales of foreign exchange to the Central Bank and pay a commission of 0.5 percent on purchases of foreign exchange. Capital inflows relating to projects ap- proved under Decree Law No. 19/89 on Investment Incentives for Economic Development are exempt from the above charges. The commercial banks are not required to trans- fer all of their daily gross foreign exchange receipts to the Central Bank but maintain a daily net position of no more than US$500,000. They are required to report their daily transactions to the Central Bank. Under a forward cover arrangement against ex- change rate risk, the Central Bank undertakes to sell to authorized commercial banks, within a 240-day period, foreign exchange purchased from them at the rate prevailing on the date of the purchase trans- action, subject to a commission at an annual rate of 8 percent. A similar arrangement is available to ex- porters of soybeans and cotton, subject to a com- mission at the annual rate of 4 percent.1 Administration of Control The Central Bank determines foreign exchange policy and supervises, together with the Superin- tendency of Banks, the foreign exchange transac- tions carried out by the banks and the exchange houses. Arrears are maintained with respect to ex- ternal payments. Prescription of Currency Payments between Paraguay and Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Dominican Re- public, Ecuador, Mexico, Peru, Uruguay, and Vene- zuela are made through accounts maintained with the Central Bank of Paraguay and the other central banks concerned within the framework of the multi- lateral clearing arrangements of the LAIA. Clearing takes place every four months. There are no other prescription of currency requirements. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain commodities require authori- zation. These include table wine in bulk, natural grape must concentrate, rice in the husk or with any degree of processing, gasoline, diesel oil, gas oil, kerosene, wire, nails, dry cell batteries, and po- tatoes, garlic, and onions during local harvest sea- sons. Imports of petroleum and petroleum products may be made only through the national petroleum company, PETROPAR.2 All importers are required to be registered at the Central Bank. Taxes ranging from 3 percent to 70 percent are levied on most imports depending on the customs specifications, which are based on the Brussels No- menclature. Taxes are collected by the banks at the time of delivery of documents for customs clearance or when the import payment is made, whichever is earlier. The following are the principal import items exempt from tariffs: imports for religious, charita- ble, cultural, or educational purposes; imports for the Government; furniture acquired through inheri- tance; all imports exempted according to interna- tional treaties; and the accompanied baggage of in- ternational passengers or nationals returning to establish residence in Paraguay. Also exempted are agricultural and industrial machinery and equip- ment imported through the Spanish free zone in irThe arrangement was abolished, effective February 28, 1990. 2Effective January 19,1990, imports of certain petroleum prod- ucts, including LPG and aviation fuel, were liberalized. 375 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 376 PARAGUAY Paraguay; agricultural machinery and equipment for the National Wheat Program; books and periodi- cals; and imports under Decree Law No. 19/89. All commodities originating from neighboring coun- tries are subject to a lower 10 percent tariff on the c.i.f. value. Goods used as inputs in the tourist sector are subject to a 7 percent tariff on the c .i .f. value. Alcohol-powered automobiles, tractors, and motorcycles are subject to only 60 percent of the surcharge established for vehicles with equivalent specifications using other fuels. Imports of a number of commodities that might jeopardize national security, public order, or public health are prohibited. The Ministry of Finance is entitled to lift import restrictions on basic foodstuffs, seeds, and cement when domestic pro- duction shortfalls are such that domestic demand cannot be met through internal supply. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles are carried out through the authorized commercial banks or ex- change houses without restriction. Travelers may take out any amount in foreign or domestic cur- rency. There is an ad valorem sales tax of 5 percent on international airline tickets. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of logs and rough beams and some other unprocessed forest products are prohibited, as are exports of rawhides, horses, wild animals, sheep, goats, pigs, and rabbits. Certain other exports re- quire prior authorization in order to ensure ade- quate supplies for domestic consumption and to meet the needs of domestic industries. All other exports are free from licensing requirements, but some require a certificate issued by the National Institute of Technology and Standardization of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, and others require a certificate issued by the Ministry of Agri- culture and Livestock. All exporters are required to be registered at the Central Bank. The proceeds of exports must be col- lected within 120 days after completion of the bank- ing formalities related to the shipping documents; the foreign exchange proceeds must be converted and surrendered at banks authorized to engage in foreign exchange transactions at the exchange rate prevailing on the day of the transaction. Proceeds from Invisibles Except for foreign exchange inflows from the bi- national entities (which have to be transferred in full to the Central Bank), there are no surrender re- quirements for proceeds from invisibles. Travelers may bring in any amount in foreign or domestic currency. Capital All inward and outward transfers must be chan- neled through the commercial banks or exchange houses. Repatriation of earnings of enterprises and commercial banks is allowed through the free ex- change market. Under Decree Law No. 19/89, the Government grants exemptions from taxes, customs, and import surcharges to proposed in- vestments, provided that these are duly registered and approved. Gold Under Decree Law No. 18/52, the Central Bank may prescribe the maximum amount of gold (and foreign exchange) that may be held by residents; this requirement does not apply to amounts held by the Central Bank or by institutions authorized to deal in foreign currencies. In practice, residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, in Paraguay or abroad, and exchange houses may freely deal in gold coins, gold bars, and gold leaf with residents and nonresidents. Exports and imports of gold by nonbank residents and industrial users in any form other than jewelry require the prior approval of the Central Bank; payments for gold imports by industrial users must be made through authorized banks. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement February 27. Not for Redistribution PERU (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Peru is the Peruvian Inti. The exchange rate system consists of the following rates: (1) the controlled exchange rate (MUC); (2) the free market exchange rate for foreign bank notes deter- mined in the banking system; (3) the rate for foreign exchange retained by exporters (35 percent) in the form of Freely Disposable Foreign Exchange Certifi- cates (CLDs) applicable to eligible import and invis- ible payments; and (4) the free parallel market rate. In the MUC market, the exchange rate for the inti is pegged to the U.S. dollar and determined by the Central Reserve Bank. Since June 8, 1989, a crawling-peg system has been applied. On Decem- ber 29,1989, the MUC rate was II. 5,261.40 = US$1, and the average buying/selling rate in the free paral- lel market was I/. 12,940 = US$1. Exchange transac- tions may be conducted in 15 currencies other than the U.S. dollar on the basis of their exchange rates in terms of the U.S. dollar in the international market.1 Exchange transactions taking place at the MUC and the free exchange market rates are as follows. The MUC exchange rate is applied to (1) 35 percent of surrendered export proceeds; (2) the payment of credits from the Fund for Nontraditional Exports (PENT) for up to 35 percent of the f .o .b value of the export; (3) the sale of foreign exchange to students abroad for installation and travel expenses; (4) the sale of foreign exchange to people of low income to travel abroad for medical treatment; (5) 72 percent of the f .o .b. value of imports;2 (6) all transactions effected by the petroleum companies; and (7) the servicing of lines of credit to the public sector. The most important exchange transactions effected through the free market exchange rate are (1) re- maining imports; (2) service payments other than public debt service; (3) remittances of profits by branches of international transportation enter- prises; (4) inward private capital flows (up to De- cember 29, 1990); (5) receipts of foreign exchange from reimbursements for prepaid freight charges on exports; (6) income from insurance claims; Belgian francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, and Swiss francs for external trade transactions; for nontrade transactions, operations may also be effected in Austrian schillings, Canadian dollars, Norwegian kroner, Swed- ish kroner, and Venezuelan bolivares. 2On January 11, 1990, this percentage was reduced to 67 be- cause 44 categories of goods, principally capital goods, were made eligible for importation at the MUC exchange rate. (7) receipts from liquidation of foreign exchange insurance certificates issued before December 31, 1988; (8) capital contributions to legal entities; (9) receipts of foreign exchange from external trans- fer except those derived from exports or their prefi- nancing; and (10) foreign exchange received by par- astatals and private agencies in social welfare and cultural fields from International Technical Cooper- ation Institutions. Interest on foreign exchange re- ceived by financial institutions on their required reserves must also be sold to the Central Reserve Bank at the free exchange rate. All exchange transactions other than those effected through the parallel market must be con- ducted through the banking system. An exchange tax of 1 percent is levied on foreign exchange pro- ceeds from exports of goods and services, and on purchases of foreign exchange for imports of goods and services. Commercial banks may charge a com- mission of 0.25 percent on transactions. Enterprises are not allowed to hold foreign ex- change balances abroad, with limited exceptions, and must sell foreign exchange to the banking sys- tem within ten working days of receipt. Export and loan proceeds of the public sector and loans ob- tained for the prefinancing of exports must be sur- rendered to the Central Reserve Bank. Exporters of nontraditional exports availing them- selves of subsidized PENT (nontransferable ex- change certificates) credits are eligible for 180-day PENT certificates against the surrender of foreign public exchange proceeds of preshipment and postshipment credits received from abroad, pro- vided that such foreign credits do not exceed 72 per- cent of the contemplated export value. Extensions of up to 360 additional days of the validity period of the certificates are permitted. PENT certificates remain in the custody of the Central Reserve Bank and bear interest at LIBOR, plus 5 percentage points for the duration of the foreign export financing; they are applied directly by the Central Reserve Bank toward the cancellation of part of the PENT credit to the exporter. Upon surrender of export proceeds, the Central Reserve Bank issues a second set of ex- change certificates for the direct cancellation of the PENT credit not covered by PENT certificates. The holding of bank accounts in foreign curren- cies in the Peruvian financial system is allowed, but the financial system may not extend credit based on these accounts. 378 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU 379 On November 25, 1989, the system of advance sales of forward exchange was introduced. Advance sales of foreign exchange take place through an auction conducted by the Central Reserve Bank, with a floor established by the Central Reserve Bank based on a premium over the current MUC ex- change rate. Foreign exchange may be delivered in 30, 60, or 90 days.3 Peru formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Administration of Control Export licenses are issued by the Institute for Foreign Trade (ICE). Prior import licenses are issued by the ICE and are required only for goods imported at the MUC exchange rate, except medical and agri- cultural products. There also exists a list of goods (72 tariff lines, mainly consisting of foods tuffs, in- puts for agroindustry, pharmaceutical and petro- leum products, educational books, and public sec- tor imports) classified by ministry, requiring approval of the relevant ministry and eligible to be imported at the MUC exchange rate. In addition, prior approval by the Central Reserve Bank is re- quired for payments for nonfactor services. The Im- port Supervision Commission is the ultimate ad- ministrative authority that considers applications for prior import licenses that are not granted at a lower level and rules on the exclusion of importers from the National Register of Importers. It also ex- ercises general surveillance over the flow of imports and their effects on domestic production and is em- powered to make recommendations to the Import Valuation Commission. Exchange houses are authorized to purchase foreign exchange and traveler's checks from resi- dents and nonresidents and sell foreign exchange for tourism abroad and for repurchases by nonresidents. Borrowing abroad by the public sector, as well as borrowing abroad by the private sector with a gov- ernment guarantee, is subject to prior approval by Supreme Decree, on the recommendation of the Committee of the External Debt. Public enterprises are required to register their short-term indebted- ness with the General Directorate of Public Credit (GDPC) and to obtain GDPCs approval for re- newal, rollover, or consolidation of such debt. More- over, as of January 1983, the enterprises must sub- mit their annual short-term borrowing programs to GDPC for approval. The National Commission on Foreign Investment and Technology (CONITE) su- pervises foreign direct investment in Peru and the use of foreign trademarks, patents, and licenses, as well as the related royalty payments. Most pay- ments for invisibles require the approval of CONITE. Foreign Exchange Bank Certificates (FEBC) may be used for domestic investment purposes with the approval of CONITE. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency All exchange market operations must be effected in one of the 15 prescribed convertible currencies, but exchange certificates may be issued by the Cen- tral Reserve Bank only in U.S. dollars. Payments between Peru and Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Mex- ico, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Venezuela must be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru and the other central banks concerned, within the framework of the multilateral clearing system of the Latin Ameri- can Integration Association (LAIA). Imports and Import Payments Import prohibitions apply to 539 commodities out of the approximately 5,266 eight-digit items of the Peruvian customs nomenclature (NABANDINA). These commodities include agricultural products, footwear, textiles, and security-related materials. All imports, except those that do not exceed an annual value of US$2,000, require import licenses. Import licenses are required for imports from coun- tries of the Andean Pact only for statistical pur- poses, and the importer must be listed in the Na- tional Register of Importers. Imports of raw materials and intermediate goods for the produc- tion of nontraditional exports are exempted from import duties, and a specific import license is not required, provided that the appropriate ministry determines that such imports qualify under the Temporary Admission Regime.4 Milk powder and wheat may be imported only by the National Enter- prise for Input Marketing (ENCI); and crude petro- leum and petroleum derivatives, only by PE- TROPERU, a state-owned enterprise. Advance payments are not permitted except for capital goods financed with external funds and up to 20 percent of the f.o.b. import value. With some specified exemptions, imported goods are subject to a uniform value-added tax of 15 per- cent of the c . i .f. value of imports (in addition to the 3The system was eliminated on January 11, 1990. 4In 1989 imports under this regime amounted to US$47 million. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 380 PERU import duty); exempted from the value-added tax are agricultural products, certain minerals and fuels, medicines, fertilizers, pesticides, agricultural equipment and tractors, aviation equipment and ships in excess of 1,000 tons, and items for personal use (including automobiles up to 2,000 cubic cen- timeters). A selective consumption tax (also in addi- tion to the import duty) is levied on luxury items, ranging from 15 percent to 100 percent of the c . i .f. value. The maximum import duty is 84 percent ad valorem, and the unweighted average rate is 47 per- cent. In addition, many imports are subject to the following taxes: (1) a surcharge of 24 percent; (2) an additional import tax for the promotion of nontradi- tional exports of 1 percent of the c .i .f. value; (3) a maritime freight tax of 20 percent of the ocean freight charges; and (4) a 2 percent surcharge on the value (f .o .b .) of all imports, with the exception of food and medicines, for the benefit of the National Defense Fund. However, certain goods originating in Andean Pact countries may be imported duty free. Public sector imports must, in principle, be shipped in Peruvian vessels. Payments for Invisibles Payments for almost all invisibles other than debt service must be made at the free market rate and are not subject to payments authorization. Remittances of foreign exchange for dividends, profits (includ- ing depreciation allowances), royalties and patent fees by enterprises operating in Peru are suspended until July 31, 1990; technical assistance fees are ex- cluded from this suspension. Dividends and royal- ties of petroleum and mineral companies and the servicing of medium- and long-term debt con- tracted after July 28, 1985, are excluded from the suspension. Deposits in national currency equiv- alent to the amortization and interest payments on medium- and long-term loans and other credits af- fected by the suspension is required to be made to the Central Reserve Bank on the dates that pay- ments fall due. With the permission of the Central Bank, Foreign Exchange Bank Certificates (FEBC) may be redeemed to make provisions for meeting certain debt-service obligations. Remittances of net profits, including depletion and depreciation allowances, that are exempted from the suspension require approval of CONITE and from the Central Bank or the Ministry of Economy and Finance; and a prior tax clearance. In accor- dance with Andean Pact rules, the remittance of profits on foreign capital invested in Peru is, in principle, limited to 20 percent of the investment a year, although a higher percentage may be permit- ted for investments that generate substantial em- ployment, are situated in underdeveloped areas, or help to diversify exports.5 All payments for royalties, patents, trademarks, and licenses require the prior approval of CONITE, the Central Bank, or the Ministry of Economy and Finance. Foreign-owned enterprises may not enter into new contracts to pay royalties to a foreign par- ent company or its affiliates. The maximum interest rate on a new loan from a foreign parent company or its affiliate may not exceed by more than 3 percent the prevailing interest rate for first-class assets in the money market of the country in whose currency the transaction is conducted. Foreign investment by petroleum and mining companies is subject to spe- cial contracts with the Peruvian Government. The sale of foreign exchange for business travel abroad, other than official business, is limited to US$220 a person a day of travel up to a maximum of US$4,400 a trip to North America and Europe; US$250 a person a day of travel, up to a maximum of US$5,000 a trip to Asia; and US$150 a person a day up to a maximum of US$3,000 a trip to other coun- tries. Expenditures on tourist travel abroad are lim- ited to US$5,000 or its equivalent in other currencies a person a calendar year and must be paid for through the parallel market. A tax of US$100 is levied on travel abroad.6 Approval by the Foreign Exchange Committee of the Central Reserve Bank is required for purchases of foreign exchange for payments that have not been considered by the exchange regulations. Indicative limits on foreign exchange sales are established in some cases. The Central Reserve Bank, through its Foreign Exchange Committee, may authorize pur- chases of exchange in excess of the specified limits in justified cases. Exports and Export Proceeds Export prohibitions apply to 65 items, mainly rare wildlife and plants, cotton, rubber, and mineral ores. Exports of gold have been prohibited since 1986. Export licenses are required for 87 other com- modities. The Banco Minero del Peru is the princi- pal exporter of uncut precious stones and pearls, and MINPECO has a monopoly over exports of silver and other refined metals produced by the public enterprises; since August 1985 PETROPERU has a mo- nopoly over exports of petroleum products. Exports 5Companies exporting at least 80 percent of their production to countries outside the Andean Pact and mining companies are exempt from this limit. Effective January 1, 1990, the tax is US$30. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU 381 of certain commodities specified by the ICE are sub- ject to prior license. Export proceeds as well as ex- port prefinancing loans must be surrendered to the Central Reserve Bank within five working days of expected date of receipt. Traditional exports must be sold against an irrevocable letter of credit confirmed by a bank established in Peru. In special cases, and with the authorization of the Central Reserve Bank and the General Directorate of Foreign Trade, ex- ports may be sold against sight drafts, provided that payment is received within 180 days of shipment. Upon surrendering their export proceeds, export- ers receive three types of foreign exchange certifi- cate denominated in U.S. dollars: (1) Foreign Ex- change Certificates for an amount equal to 45 percent of the f.o.b. value of the realized export, which may be converted into domestic currency at the MUC exchange rate and have a maturity period of 10 days; (2) Freely Disposable Foreign Exchange Certificates for an amount equal to 35 percent of the f .o .b. value of the realized export, which may be converted into domestic currency at the MUC ex- change rate prevailing on the day of conversion, have a maturity period of 180 days, are freely trans- ferable, and may be used to purchase an equivalent amount of foreign exchange to make payments for eligible imports and invisibles; and (3) Convertible Foreign Exchange Certificates, (CCs) for an amount equal to 20 percent of the realized export, which have a maturity period of 60 days, and may be de- posited in a foreign currency account in a commer- cial bank, officially providing for their redemption in foreign currency. Exporters of most nontraditional products are granted transferable tax credit certificates (cer- tificados de reintegro tributario, or CERTEX) equivalent to between 15 and 35 percent of the f .o .b. value. An additional 10 percent is granted for exports from outside the Lima-Callao area.7 Exports of local handicrafts recognized as such by the ICE are eligi- ble for CERTEX benefits at a rate of 35 percent. CERTEX certificates may be used by the exporter in payment of his tax obligations or may be sold to other taxpayers, who may use them for the same purpose. Nontraditional products are also eligible for export credits through PENT. Some textile ex- ports to the United States are not eligible for either CERTEX or PENT. The Export Credit Insurance Com- pany of Peru (SECREX) administers an export credit guarantee program, and the Central Reserve Bank 7Exporters cannot receive CERTEX certificates for more than 35 percent of the f .o .b. value of exports, except in the case of fresh fruits, certain nontraditional textile products, and some sea products. (since December 1983) provides or arranges export finance for nontraditional exports. To be eligible for the incentives granted for nontraditional exports, exporters must be listed in the Register of Enter- prises Exporting Nontraditional Products; each en- try in the list is valid for two years. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from most invisibles are sold in the free exchange market. Capital Outward capital transfers require approval. For transfers derived from foreign direct investment, the approval of CONITE is required; for most other transfers, the appropriate agency is the Central Re- serve Bank. Minimum maturities and grace periods for different categories of external loans contracted or guaranteed by the public sector have been estab- lished on the contracting of new public or publicly guaranteed external debt (with certain exceptions) having an original maturity of more than one but less than ten years. Loan amortization payments of the private sector are authorized by the Central Reserve Bank, and those of the public sector, by the General Directorate of Public Credit. Debt-service payments on private sector debt were suspended for a two-year period starting July 29, 1986, subject to certain exceptions (see section on Payments for Invisibles, above). This suspension was subse- quently extended to July 1990. There is a limit on the servicing of external public debt equivalent to 10 percent of receipts from exports of goods and services. This limitation does not apply to the ser- vicing of short-term debt, reserve liabilities, debt owed to the governments of Latin American coun- tries and regional organizations, payments in kind, or debts incurred since July 29, 1985. Within the overall limit, debt-service payments are generally made mainly to those creditors from whom net inflows are expected. Short-term trade credits with banks that have not signed a refinancing agreement are to be rolled over on maturity until signature of agreement. Local cur- rency funds for the servicing of these debts are to be placed on deposit in special accounts at the Central Reserve Bank on the maturity date of the original obligation. With the permission of the Central Re- serve Bank, funds in these special accounts may be lent out domestically as loans denominated in for- eign currency, with a maturity of less than one year at the free market exchange rate. In compliance with the foreign investment re- gime approved by the countries of the Andean Pact, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 382 PERU new foreign investments must be authorized and registered with the appropriate agency, in most in- stances, CONITE. If a foreign company incorporated in Peru wishes to benefit from the duty-free pro- gram of the Cartagena Agreement, it was required to have agreed to the gradual acquisition by national investors of shares in the company, so as to trans- form it into a mixed or national company during a maximum period of 30 years following the entering into effect of this regime. For this purpose, the required participation of national investors in the capital of these enterprises have been not less than 15 percent in the first three years; this participation must be raised to at least 30 percent after 10 years, to at least 45 percent after 20 years, and to at least 51 percent at the end of the 30-year period. Mixed companies are defined as those in which national investors hold between 51 percent and 80 percent of the capital, and national companies are those in which at least 80 percent of the capital is owned by national investors. Investment in the mining sector is governed by the General Mining Law. Companies holding min- ing concessions may enter into mining contracts with the Government providing for special incen- tives and guarantees or may constitute mixed enter- prises with government participation of at least 25 percent. The Government may grant to mining concessionaries (initiating large-scale investment programs) tax incentives and guaranteed avail- ability of foreign exchange for transfers for (1) recovery of investment; (2) interest payments if the rate does not exceed the prevailing rate for simi- lar loans in the financial market from which the loans originate; (3) payments for justified services; and (4) reasonable profit remittances, together with guaranteed access to the most favorable exchange rate. Mixed mining enterprises may receive all the benefits and incentives that may be granted by spe- cial contract and, in addition, special tax reductions. Gold The export of gold in the form of precious metals is the monopoly of the Banco Minero del Peru, but gold exports have been suspended since 1986. The authorities do not make foreign exchange available for imports of gold other than by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users. Domestic sales and purchases of gold may be carried out by industrial and profes- sional users, provided that they hold licenses issued by the Banco Minero del Peru, but only MINPECO is authorized to make the initial purchase of newly mined gold and other precious metals. The Central Bank may purchase domestically produced gold with CLDs, CCs, and MUC certificates in the same proportions as those given to exporters surrender- ing foreign exchange. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement June 8. A crawling peg system was introduced, and the Central Bank announced that, effective June 9, it would inform commercial banks about the prevailing exchange rate on a daily basis. November 25. Procedures were established for ad- vance sales of foreign exchange. The sales would take place through an auction (although the Central Bank would establish a floor based on a premium over the current MUC exchange rate), and foreign exchange would be deliverable in 30, 60, or 90 days.
