Not for Redistribution POLAND (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Poland is the Zloty (100 groszy = 1 zloty). The exchange rate between the zloty and the currencies of countries other than members of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA),1 Albania, and the Democratic People's Re- public of Korea is determined on the basis of a weighted basket of currencies, each of which ac- counts for at least 1 percent of Poland's external current account settlements with the convertible currency area. The currency composition of the bas- ket and the currency weights are defined on a monthly basis in light of current account transac- tions in convertible currency. The value of the zloty in terms of the basket is adjusted periodically on the basis of the difference between foreign and domes- tic prices for traded goods and with a view to secur- ing the profitability of at least 80 percent of exports.2 In the course of 1989, the external value of the zloty was lowered 24 times against the basket of currencies. As a result, the value of the U.S. dollar rose from Zl 502.55 at the end of 1988 to Zl 6,500 at the end of 1989.3 The National Bank of Poland (NBP) quotes ex- change rates for the European Currency Unit (ECU), the SDR, and the currencies of 29 countries4 considered market economies; although it does not deal in the notes and coins of a limited number5 of the currencies, it stands ready to effect transactions in all of them. Buying and selling rates are set with margins of 0.5 percent around the middle rate, ex- cept for notes and coins, for which the margins are set at 2 percent. Rates are generally set at least once 1The participants in the CMEA are Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslo- vakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and Viet Nam. 2For these purposes, profitability is considered to have been achieved when the ratio of the export transaction price of a particular product to its domestic price (both expressed in a common currency) is equal to or greater than unity. 3On January 1, 1990, the zloty was depreciated fur ther to Zl 9,500 per US$1. 4Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Cana- dian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Greek drachmas, Indian rupees, Italian lire, Ira- nian rials, Irish pounds, Japanese yen, Kuwaiti dinars, Lebanese pounds, Libyan dinars, Luxembourg francs, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Portuguese es- cudos, Saudi Arabian riyals, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, U.S. dollars, Turkish liras, and Yugoslav dinars. 5Indian rupees, Iranian rials, Irish pounds, Kuwaiti dinars, Libyan dinars, and Saudi Arabian riyals. a week, normally on Thursdays, to become effective when they are published on the following Monday. Rates for currencies other than the U.S. dollar are based on the quoted rate for the U.S. dollar and the dollar rates for the relevant currencies in interna- tional markets on the day the rates are set. The buying and selling rates for spot transactions in U.S. dollars on December 29, 1989 were Zl 6,467.50 and Zl 6,532.50, respectively, per US$1. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk operating in the official or the commercial banking sector. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of the currencies of market economies. The Council of Banks sets maximum allowable commis- sions and charges on foreign exchange transactions in line with international practice. These levies are paid in zlotys (foreign currency) by domestic (for- eign) customers. During 1989 foreign exchange for import payments was also auctioned separately by Bank Handlowy, the Export Development Bank, and Bank PKO, S. A. The exchange rates established in the last auctions in 1989 were Zl 4,635 (price over the official rate of exchange), Zl 5,560, and Zl 6,691, respectively, per US$1. Since March 15, 1989, a pri- vate foreign exchange market consisting of foreign exchange banks and licensed foreign exchange bu- reaus (kantory) has been in operation. The ex- change rates in this market are determined by sup- ply and demand conditions. On December 29,1989, the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the free market were Zl 9,200 and Zl 9,800, respectively, per US$1 at the PKO Savings Bank. Most of Poland's trade and financial settlements with CMEA member countries are effected in trans- ferable rubles through the International Bank for Economic Cooperation (IBEC). The clearing ruble is used for most settlements with Albania and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea and for some settlements with Democratic Kampuchea and the Lao People's Democratic Republic. Official ex- change rates for transferable and clearing rubles are set by the National Bank of Poland and published each Monday. Exchange rates for transferable and clearing rubles are set at the same level, and are adjusted periodically, with a view to ensuring the profitability of at least 80 percent of exports to the socialist countries. During 1989, the zloty was de- preciated less rapidly against the transferable ruble (TR) than against the basket of convertible curren- cies, and the exchange rate of the zloty moved from 393 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 394 POLAND Zl 230 per TR1 at the end of 1988 to Zl 1,650 per TR1 at the end of 1989.6 As a result, the cross rate of the TR depreciated to TR 3.636 per US$1 from TR 2.185. Buying and selling rates for transferable and clear- ing rubles are quoted with a spread of 0.5 percent around the middle rate. On December 29,1989, the buying and selling rates for the zloty against trans- ferable and clearing rubles were Zl 1,641.75 and Zl 1,658.25 respectively, per one ruble. The NBP also quotes weekly exchange rates for the zloty against the currencies of other CMEA member countries, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. These rates are based on multilateral and supplemental bilateral agreements with the socialist partners and are used for noncom- mercial settlements (e.g., diplomatic representation expenses, international travel, scholarships, etc.). Buying and selling rates (including for notes and coins) are set with margins of 0.5 percent around the middle rate. A 30 percent surcharge is applied on the sale of these currencies for private trips abroad; the rate of surcharges applicable to trips to Czechoslovakia and Hungary is 150 percent, and to other member countries of the CMEA, 50 percent.7 Administration of Control The authority to make basic changes in the Ex- change Regulation Law lies with the Parliament. Implementing regulations are promulgated by the Minister of Finance in the form of general foreign exchange permits or by the President of the NBP in the form of individual permits. General permits are issued for all residents and nonresidents, or for a specified group thereof. Procedures for issuing in- dividual permits are established by the president of the NBP in cooperation with the Minister of Fi- nance. The authority for the enforcement of the foreign exchange regulations rests with the Minister of Finance, who exercises related functions mainly through the President of the NBP. However, deci- sions concerning individual foreign exchange per- mits are subject to appeal to the Supreme Admin- istrative Court (SNA). Residents must repatriate foreign exchange within two months of receipt or within two months after returning to Poland. There are surrender re- quirements on a portion of export proceeds and pensions from abroad and for foreign visitors. On 6On January 1, 1990, the zloty was depreciated further to Zl 2,100 per TR 1. 7Effective January 1, 1990, in selling foreign exchange for pri- vate trips to CMEA countries, a 29 percent surcharge was applied to the exchange rate for the ruble and a surcharge of 100 percent to the exchange rates of other CMEA member countries. the basis of these surrenders, and in implementing the annual balance of payments plan adopted by Parliament without exceeding the ceiling on the state's foreign debt, the Minister of Finance draws up an annual foreign exchange allocation plan for imports. Residents must channel foreign transac- tions through a foreign exchange bank. Residents other than foreign citizens must report their prop- erty holdings abroad to the NBP. The same applies to nonresidents with property in Poland. Foreign exchange control is exercised by the Min- ister of Finance and the bodies responsible to him, the NBP, the foreign exchange banks, customs of- fices, the border guard, and post offices. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Po- land has multilateral and bilateral payments agree- ments are made in the currencies and in accordance with the procedures set forth in those agreements.8 If there are no specific agreements, or if trade takes place outside the scope of the agreements, settle- ment is made in a convertible currency. Resident and Nonresident Accounts Resident Accounts Polish residents (natural and juridical persons) can hold foreign exchange in the form of currency, stocks, bonds, etc. Four types of foreign currency accounts are available: (1) convertible currency ac- counts "A"; (2) foreign exchange accounts for for- eign settlement, "ROD"; (3) Bank PKO, S.A. de- posit certificates; and (4) socialist currency accounts "S." (1) Accounts "A" are held by natural persons and can be freely credited with convertible currency brought in or transferred from abroad and/or de- posited without the requirement of a declaration of 8 At the end of December 1989, Poland had bilateral payments agreements with Albania, Bangladesh, Brazil, the People's Re- public of China, Colombia, Ecuador, India, the Islamic Republic of Iran, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Re- public of Korea, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, Lebanon, and Nepal. Poland also had trade agreements with bilateral payments features for certain commodities with Argentina, Ban- gladesh, Malta, Pakistan, and Yugoslavia. Except for bilateral agreements with Albania, the People's Republic of China, India, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, and Nepal, settle- ments under bilateral agreements were in U.S. dollars. Settle- ments with the People's Republic of China were in Swiss francs; with India, in Indian rupees; with Nepal, in pounds sterling; and in clearing rubles with Albania, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, and the Lao People's Democratic Republic. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution POLAND 395 the sources of the funds. Account holders may use the funds freely to effect transfers abroad, to buy goods and services, to finance tourist travel abroad by them or other persons, to withdraw in the form of foreign currency or foreign exchange coupons (Bank PKO, S.A. coupons) for use in hard currency stores, and to effect gifts to family members or other persons. The funds on deposit cannot be used to effect settlements between individuals, but funds withdrawn in foreign currency can be resold in the private foreign exchange market. Withdrawals in zlotys, converted at the prevailing exchange rate, are freely permitted. Interest, paid in foreign ex- change, is earned at the following annual rates: for accounts maintained in French francs, pounds ster- ling, and U.S. dollars, 4 percent on call deposits, 8 percent, 9 percent, and 10 percent, respectively, on one-, two-, and three-year term deposits; and for accounts maintained in deutsche mark and Swiss francs, 3 percent on call deposits, 7 percent, 8 per- cent, and 9 percent, respectively, on one-, two-, and three-year term deposits. (2) Foreign exchange accounts for foreign settle- ments, "ROD," are held by juridical persons and can be credited with foreign exchange retained against exports in convertible currencies. Account holders may use the funds freely to purchase production- related and investment goods imported from the convertible currency area, either for their own use to make certain specified debt-service payments; to pay for patents; to pay for business trips; to cover marketing expenses; and to purchase goods pro- duced domestically subject to the approval of the Ministry of Finance. In addition, funds of up to 1 percent and 5 percent of annual net revenues can be used for imports to support social services for the employees of the account holder and for socially useful purposes not related to the account holder's business activity, respectively. The funds cannot be used for settlement between enterprises, but they may be offered for sale at periodic auctions held by the Export Development Bank. Interest is paid in foreign exchange at the annual rates of 3 percent, 4 percent, and 5 percent, respectively, on one-, two-, and three-year deposits. Deposits on current accounts do not earn interest. (3) Bank PKO deposit certificates are issued by the Bank PKO, S.A. in convertible currencies. The sources of funds need not be declared. Interest pay- able in foreign currency after each six-month period is earned at the following annual rates: 3 percent, 8 percent, and 9 percent, respectively, on one-, two-, and three-year deposits. The deposit certifi- cates are issued in U.S. dollars in denominations of US$100 and US$500.9 (4) Accounts "S" can be credited with socialist country currencies derived from wages, property sales, inheritances, etc., and with transfers from other accounts S. Funds in these accounts are freely transferable abroad (to other socialist countries) and may be freely withdrawn. Deposits of call money earn interest at 3 percent a year, and one- year term deposits earn interest at 4.5 percent a year. Resident individuals and enterprises may hold foreign exchange accounts abroad with the express permission of the NBP. Such permission is granted only on "proof of necessity." Nonresident Accounts Nonresident juridical and physical persons are free to keep both convertible currency and zloty accounts. (1) Nonresidents may maintain convertible cur- rency accounts (accounts "C") at the NBP, the Bank Handlowy, and the Bank PKO, S.A., or one of the commercial banks. These accounts can be credited with funds brought in or transferred to Poland, with transfers from other accounts C and with convert- ible currency amounts legally acquired in Poland. Deposits are freely transferable abroad, and may be used for purchases from hard currency stores and to make gifts to residents. The funds earn interest in foreign currency. Interest rates on accounts C of natural persons are fixed by banks and are paid at an annual rate in the range of 3 percent to 5 percent for demand deposits, and in the range of 7 percent to 11 percent for term deposits (depending on the account currency, the time limit, and the rates on international money markets). Interest rates on ac- counts C of juridical persons are fixed at the same rates, except demand deposits, which do not earn interest. (2) Nonresidents are free to open and hold zloty accounts. Depositors must declare the source of the zlotys when making deposits into such accounts. This declaration requirement aims to ensure that payments into the accounts result from contracts or other operations that comply with the provisions of the foreign exchange law. Apart from zlotys legally earned in Poland, these accounts may also be cred- 9These deposit certificates are distinct from Bank PKO cou- pons, which can be used to buy "internal exports" in hard cur- rency stores and other designated sales outlets. The Bank PKO, S.A. stands ready to sell (buy) these coupons to (from) Polish residents in return for zlotys at rates close to the exchange rate in the private foreign exchange market. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 396 POLAND ited with foreign exchange converted to zlotys at the official exchange rate. Permits for conversion back to foreign exchange or for foreign exchange transfers abroad are normally granted. These accounts do not pay interest; however, nonresidents may also de- posit their earnings on savings bank books, on which interest is paid. Deposits on zloty accounts may be transferred to other nonresidents or resi- dents. Such transfers require a foreign exchange permit, except gifts for residents. Permits for trans- fers to nonresidents are granted only for transfers to family members. Permits for transfers to residents are granted without any restriction. Imports and Exports All imports and exports are subject to a licensing requirement. Licenses are issued by the Ministry of Foreign Economic Cooperation, by its "full-powers" agent employed by the economic unit applying for the license, or by local chambers of commerce. The customs authority issues licenses not exceeding Zl 100,000 in value for gifts and souvenirs. Only economic units with permanent trading rights are eligible to have a licensing agent of the Ministry of Foreign Economic Cooperation in residence. There are two types of licenses: general and indi- vidual licenses. General licenses apply to an esti- mated 80 percent of exports and imports (in value terms). Eligible items include all imports and ex- ports that are centrally balanced, transactions under long-term cooperation agreements, imports for re- exports, imports needed for production financed by ROD accounts, raw material imports for export pro- duction, imports for internal export, and all non- centrally-balanced exports in convertible currencies that are settled in cash. Individual licenses apply to an estimated 20 percent of exports and imports and cover special transactions, such as those settled on credit terms, barter transactions, transactions under bilateral agreement, leasing, or where general li- censes are denied. General licenses are normally issued for a period of one year but may be issued for a period up to three years in appropriate cases. These licenses are issued to most foreign trade enterprises and units engaged in foreign trade, except very small units that are engaged in a wide range of products. The license stipulates the list of permissible products and applicable limits (in terms of quantity and value) in the case of centrally balanced exports and imports; no additional licenses are required if the limits are exceeded by less than 5 percent. For trans- actions that are not centrally balanced, the require- ment depends on the items in question. For certain consumption items, no limits are set. For intermedi- ate products, estimates of domestic demand that should be met are provided as a guideline. The Ministry of Foreign Economic Cooperation must render its decision on the issuance of a license within ten days after an application is filed. No further license from the foreign exchange authority is required for export or import and the perfor- mance or use of related services. Trade in certain goods is prohibited for social reasons under the penal code. Individual licenses are readily granted at no cost, provided that the relevant regulations are observed and that the transactions are in line with national plan allocations. Contracts do not become valid, nor may payment orders be drawn, until a license has been issued, except for intergovernmental agree- ments and instantaneous contracts, such as those made on a metals exchange. A license application must be filed with the appropriate authority within seven days after agreement on a contract is reached. A license remains valid until the final delivery date for the goods, or until the date of final payment; in specific cases, the validity period of a license may be extended. For data collection purposes, the eco- nomic unit must forward a general authorization and a license to the Foreign Trade Information Cen- ter within two days of their respective issuance; the documents are returned to the units within ten days of their registration by the Center. On the basis of the registered documents and the utilization rec- ords that the units are required to keep, the customs administration monitors whether goods are traded according to valid documents. It also has the au- thority to inspect all relevant documents and to issue instructions for eliminating irregularities. In the event of changes in the contracted provi- sions, the economic unit must notify the relevant authorities (the Ministry of Foreign Economic Coop- eration or its agent, and the Information Center) of the necessary changes in the license within seven days of receipt of the documentation, stating the reason for the changes. In the event of a change of more than 5 percent in the foreign currency price, or mistakes or errors in data, a new license must be issued, which automatically and simultaneously re- scinds the former version. If a license is not fully utilized, the economic unit must declare this to the appropriate authorities within 14 days after confir- mation of this fact. Such a declaration is not required if the underutilization amounts to less than Zl 50,000, or does not exceed 5 percent of the price or volume stated in the license. Settlement in for- eign exchange is authorized and effected upon re- ceipt, and according to the terms, of valid docu- ments for settlement. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution POLAND 397 There are no import quotas. Foreign exchange allocation plans, which are prepared by the Plan- ning Commission in consultation with the Ministry of Foreign Economic Cooperation, Ministry of Fi- nance, and the NBP, are approved by the Council of Ministers on an annual basis. The annual plan de- termines import needs by commodity groups and value for centrally financed imports. These are bal- anced against financing according to priorities, with raw and intermediate products being the most im- portant. For decentralized imports, the annual plan specifies the global ceiling. Under the plan for 1989, 38 percent of convertible currency imports were to be financed centrally; these imports, largely inter- mediate products purchased in line with the needs of the annual plan, are distributed to the enterprises by the State. Another 35 percent were to be financed by use of the enterprises' own ROD accounts, and 21 percent by foreign exchange auctions in which centrally provided foreign exchange and balances retained in ROD accounts were sold at freely deter- mined exchange rates. The balance, 6 percent, was reserved for imports for re-export and internal exports. In 1989, Bank Handlowy auctioned US$447.8 mil- lion of centrally supplied foreign exchange to enter- prises for imports of specified basic commodities. Following the withdrawal of phosphates in April 1989, which became eligible again for cen- trally financed foreign exchange at the official rate, the commodity list for 1989 comprised 51 items. The foreign exchange auctioned by Bank Handlowy was for delivery up to six months forward and could be used only by the successful bidders for the com- modities indicated or had to be resold to Bank Handlowy. The Export Development Bank (EDB) auctioned US$350.4 million in 1989, including about US$80 million of centrally supplied foreign ex- change. With the suspension of central provision of foreign exchange on July 1, 1989, the EDB was lim- ited to intermediate foreign exchange held in ROD accounts during the remainder of the year. In 1989, the Bank PKO, S.A. auctioned US$76.3 million of centrally supplied foreign exchange for imports by domestic trading organizations without foreign ex- change proceeds of their own. In addition, a small amount of clearing balances was auctioned in 1989. All commercial imports, regardless of country of origin or provenance, are subject to an ad valorem import tariff. For most favored-nation (MFN) coun- tries, the average tariff rate is 8 percent, with rates of 0-10 percent for raw materials and unprocessed products, of 10-25 percent for investment goods, and of 30 percent for industrial consumer goods. For imports originating in countries not enjoying MFN status, the rates of duty are twice as high except for cases in which the MFN rate is zero, where a 25 percent rate is imposed. Imports from developing countries are granted preferential treat- ment under the scheme of General System of Pref- erences. Also, imports from 42 developing coun- tries, tropical products from chapters 6 to 24 of the customs tariff, and many goods from chapters 32 and 94 that are of interest to developing countries enter the country duty free. A separate customs tariff applies to noncommercial imports.10 However, in general, residents may import reasonable quan- tities of goods for noncommercial use free of customs duty. Quantity limits may be set on a product-by-product basis. There are some special regulations pertaining to border trade with the U.S.S.R. Export subsidies—financed through the Export Development Fund from import duties, net collec- tions from price corrections on imports from CMEA member countries, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, and part of the profits from the sale of centrally supplied foreign exchange at EDB auctions—are paid at a range of 10-30 per- cent for some thirty items (including agricultural products, light industry, and metallurgical prod- ucts) exported to the convertible currency area and at rates of 50 percent and 100 percent for agricultural exports to CMEA member countries, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. Imports are subject to stamp duties and turnover taxes at rates similar to those on domestic goods. Exports are free from turnover taxes. Duties and turnover taxes on imports for export production are refunded. Economic units are entitled to relief from income tax based on the proportion of their exports in total sales (with domestic sales valued net of turnover taxes). The rate of relief is 0.4 percentage point for each percentage point of export share up to a maximum share of 75 percent. Most trade with CMEA member countries, Al- bania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is conducted under bilateral trade and pay- ments agreements negotiated annually within the framework of five-year bilateral trade and payments agreements. Imports from these countries may be exempted from customs duties. Unless specifically exempted, all foreign currency receipts from exports must be declared, repatriated within 2 months of receipts, and surrendered in 10On January 1, 1990, this tariff was unified with the tariff for commercial imports, and surcharges were imposed on a number of items. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 398 POLAND part to the Polish foreign exchange banks within 14 days after receiving notice that foreign exchange has been deposited in the exporters' account in Poland. Nonresidents may take out of Poland, free of customs duty, souvenirs with a value of up to a specified amount in local currency. However, they may export goods bought in hard currency stores up to the value of foreign currencies declared at the point of first entry and adjusted for reasonable liv- ing expenses. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments for invisible expenses arising from mer- chandise transactions, including insurance and transportation costs, are permitted freely if related to trade transactions that have fulfilled licensing requirements. All other invisible transactions are carried out under either a general or an individual permit. Foreign exchange for such payments is made available automatically once the transaction has been authorized. In principle, permission for tourist travel to coun- tries other than members of the CMEA, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is granted only if means of support abroad is assured. This requirement can be met in one of the following ways: (1) living expenses while abroad are covered by nonresidents; (2) living expenses while abroad are covered from the resident's own funds, held in an A or an S account or acquired in the private foreign exchange market; or (3) travel is with an authorized tourist group. Travelers may take out of Poland the equivalent of US$500 in convertible cur- rencies without official permission. Documentary proof of origin is necessary for amounts exceeding this limit. For official and business travel, separate al- lowances are established by the Ministry of Finance to reflect reasonable costs. Business travelers may take out up to the equivalent of US$10,000 from accounts maintained by the enterprises that employ them for the purchase of goods and services associ- ated with their business activity or travel expenses. Business travelers to CMEA countries, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea may take out up to the equivalent of TR 1,000 for their travel expenses. Nonresident travelers to Poland are expected to fulfill minimum living expenses by converting a required amount of foreign exchange (equivalent to US$15 a day) into zlotys. When leaving Poland, tourists from convertible currency area countries can reconvert zlotys up to the equivalent brought into Poland, provided the amount is not more than the amount originally converted into zlotys less the required conversion amounts. Without a permit from the foreign exchange authority, residents may bring into or take out of the country domestic cur- rency in an amount not exceeding Zl 250,000 a per- son, of which the largest coin qualifying as legal tender in Poland is Zl 50. Nonresidents from CMEA countries, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea may bring into or take out of the country zlotys up to the amount certified by their domestic banks. Special exchange regulations apply to invisible transactions with CMEA countries: residents visit- ing CMEA countries are entitled to an allowance of Zl 80,000 a person every two years, and one half of this amount for each child up to the age of 7 years. In addition, funds in S accounts may be used. A por- tion of the travel allowance may be given in the currency of the country to be visited in amounts determined by that country's regulations. For the rest, travelers must acquire traveler's checks in the currency of destination. All conversions are effected with a 30 percent surcharge. On condition of reciprocity, residents may remit pensions and annuities in convertible foreign ex- change at the official exchange rate to nonresidents that are entitled to such payments on the basis of a ruling from the social security administration. Busi- ness entities may use their ROD accounts to pay wages and salaries to nonresident employees. Sim- ilarly, individuals may use their A or S accounts to pay for membership in organizations abroad, costs of court or arbitration proceedings up to the equiv- alent of US$10,000 a case, and taxes, customs du- ties, or administrative fees payable abroad. Under certain circumstances, foreign exchange may be made available for study abroad. Students' living expenses and tuition fees abroad must be covered by scholarships or financial support from nonresi- dent relatives. Transfers abroad by nonresident workers in Po- land, other than in the context of employment in joint ventures, are determined on the basis of agree- ments between domestic and foreign institutions or enterprises. Nonresident employees of joint ven- tures may transfer abroad up to 50 percent of their income. On condition of reciprocity and subject to an an- nual limit of Zl 3 million a person, residents are permitted to make certain remittances to CMEA countries, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. Such remittances include wages and salaries paid to employees of diplomatic, com- mercial, and other official missions of these coun- tries, or paid on the basis of international agree- ments or labor contracts, stipends, per diems, or ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution POLAND 399 other payments connected with employment or ed- ucation in Poland, honoraria, damages, pensions, annuities, insurance premia, legacies, alimony up to Zl 50,000 a month and family allowances up to Zl 20,000 a month. Profits on direct investment by nonresidents, other than those from joint ventures, can be transferred abroad up to a maximum annual amount of 10 percent of invested capital. If the investment yields a convertible currency export-to- import surplus in any fiscal year, up to 50 percent of the surplus can be transferred abroad, provided the transfer does not exceed 50 percent of net profits after taxes. The Minister of Finance may permit a transfer in excess of 50 percent of the surplus. On liquidation, the investor can transfer abroad the proceeds from the sale of the remaining assets sold in foreign currency. For joint ventures incorporated under the 1988 Law on Economic Activity with Par- ticipation of Foreign Parties, there are no limits on the transfer abroad by nonresidents of profits accru- ing from export proceeds net of import costs. Capital Parliament annually sets an upper limit on Po- land's permissible external indebtedness. Within this limit, foreign borrowing takes place on the basis of intergovernmental agreements and in various forms of bank and commercial credits. Under the provisions of the banking law, the NBP, Bank Hand- lowy, Bank PKO, S. A., and the Export Development Bank are empowered to borrow abroad, on short to long term, and to extend foreign credits. The Minis- ter of Finance sets limits on the foreign borrowing of the banks. With approval from the Minister of Finance, so- cialized enterprises may take financial loans from foreign banks. Subject to approval by the Minister of Foreign Economic Cooperation, in consultation with the Minister of Finance, socialized enterprises are allowed commercial credits granted by foreign banks or suppliers to finance imports. To borrow abroad, a socialized enterprise also requires the consent df the domestic bank that holds its basic account. The Government has established general direc- tives for extending commercial credits relating to foreign trade activities. Socialized enterprises may extend such credits only with approval from the Minister of Foreign Economic Cooperation, who prescribes the contractual conditions in each case. Negotiable export documents are discountable by foreign banks. A general permission exists for the financing of exports of goods (other than fuels and raw materials) and services up to the equivalent of US$500,000 with repayment terms up to 360 days. Such a permission also exists for the financing of imports with a value of up to the equivalent of US$500,000 and repayment terms up to three years. In both instances, the Foreign Debt Servicing Fund (FOZZ) needs to be notified within 14 days of the financing terms. Until the entry into effect of the Law on Economic Activity with Participation of Foreign Parties on Jan- uary 1,1989, direct foreign investments in Poland in the field of small-scale industry were allowed under the law of July 6,1982 (Polonia companies). A permit was required from the chief administrative office of the area ("voivodship") where the investment was to be located. The permit, which was valid for up to 20 years, was issued after the investor had lodged a "founding deposit" in convertible currency with the Bank PKO, S.A. in an amount equivalent to US$50,000. A foreign investor was obliged to import inputs in kind in the form of machinery and equip- ment, materials, and technology. The value of such goods could not be lower than the minimum found- ing deposit, which yielded interest according to the normal bank rate for C accounts and could be with- drawn after certification by the voivodship office that the investment project was complete. Upon liquidation of investment, a foreign investor could transfer abroad the proceeds from the sale of assets sold in foreign currency. A nonresident investor in a Polonia company could obtain zloty credits from the Bank PKO, S.A. for the financing of both current production destined for the domestic market and for exports and investment outlays associated with such production; such credits could not exceed 30 percent of working capital for current produc- tion. Investment credits were limited to a maximum of 30 percent of the estimated cost of the project for investments. A nonresident investor was exempt from income tax payments for three years, provided that one third of the tax liability was invested in Poland. The maximum tax rate for nonresident in- vestors was 80 percent, but tax allowances were granted if production was directed to final domestic consumption or for export, as well as when new investment projects were undertaken. In the latter case, allowances of up to 50 percent of the cost of the project were granted. In practice, the effective tax rate averaged 60-65 percent of income. For export production, the investor received the general ex- emption from custom duties on imports related to such production. Polonia companies may remit abroad each year 10 percent of invested capital plus the difference between exports and imports up to the amount of their profits in zlotys. Since January 1, 1989, all new foreign invest- ments in Poland have been governed by the Law on ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 400 POLAND Economic Activity with Participation of Foreign Par- ties of December 23, 1988, which replaced the 1986 Law on Companies with Foreign Capital Participa- tion. Existing Polonia companies could opt to avail themselves of the provisions of the new foreign investment law. Joint ventures founded under the law can have majority foreign participation and a foreign general manager. The statutory income tax rate is 40 percent but the joint venture is eligible for tax relief on exports, which can reduce the effective tax rate to 10 percent, and a tax holiday of three years.n For joint ventures in priority sectors, the tax holiday can be extended by up to an additional three years at the discretion of the Council of Ministers. Joint ventures can retain 85 percent of export pro- ceeds and sell balances retained in EDB auctions.12 The minimum capital requirement is the equivalent of US$50,000, and remittances abroad are limited to the difference between exports and imports up to the amount of the foreign partners' profits in zlotys. Foreign investment by residents, either to estab- lish subsidiaries or affiliates, or to acquire an inter- est in a foreign enterprise, must be approved by the relevant Minister, as well as by the Minister of Fi- nance in his capacity as the foreign exchange authority. All categories of capital transfers, including gifts, by resident natural persons require a foreign ex- change permit. However, for certain categories, such as inheritances, transfers are authorized on the basis of agreements and reciprocity with other countries. An annual limit of Zl 1 million is applied to all capital transfers. Emigrants to other countries must obtain an individual permit from the NBP to take out their convertible currency deposits with domestic banks. Other financial assets may be de- posited in a nonresident zloty account. Except in the form of an inheritance, nonresi- dents may acquire real estate or other immovable property in Poland only with the permission of the foreign exchange authority. Gold Resident individuals may hold gold in any form. Trading in gold, other than jewelry, is subject to permission from the foreign exchange authorities. Polish and foreign nationals may take abroad gold coins that bear value in foreign exchange. They may also bring into Poland coins made from precious metals that are legal tender in Poland. Only one nEffective January 1, 1990, the tax relief was eliminated. 12Effective January 1, 1990, both the retention privileges and the EDB auctions were abolished. enterprise, Jubiler, has general permission to buy and sell in gold in any form. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement During 1989, the zloty was depreciated 24 times against a basket of convertible currencies, resulting in an exchange rate of Zl 6,500 = US$1 at the end of 1989, and 21 times against the transferable ruble, resulting in an exchange rate of Zl 1,650 = TR 1 at the end of 1989. Foreign exchange for import pay- ments was auctioned occasionally by Bank Hand- lowy, the Export Development Bank, and Bank PKO, S.A. March 15. A private foreign exchange market, consisting of foreign exchange banks and licensed foreign exchange bureaus (kantory), began oper- ation. Administration of Control March 15. A new foreign exchange law came into effect, replacing the foreign exchange law of November 22,1983. It established foreign exchange surrender requirements for exporters, for individ- uals receiving pensions from abroad, and for for- eign tourists. Exporters were allowed to sell re- tained foreign exchange in auctions to other enterprises. The parallel exchange market was le- galized, and foreign exchange bureaus were al- lowed to buy foreign exchange from resident and nonresident individuals and sell it to resident indi- viduals at freely determined exchange rates. Imports and Exports January 1. A new ad valorem customs tariff for commercial imports, with uniform rates for Areas I and II and based on the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System, entered into effect. The valuation basis for imports was the trans- action value, converted at the official exchange rate applicable on the date of declaration of the goods at customs. The duty rates for investment goods were lowered from 20-40 percent to 10-25 percent, whereas rates for raw materials and unprocessed goods remained about unchanged at 0-10 percent. The largest differentiation was maintained for agri- cultural imports, with low rates for basic inputs and higher ones for foods tuffs. High duty rates (of about 30 percent) were maintained for industrial consumer goods. As a result of these changes, the average tariff for MFN countries was reduced to 8 percent from 10.5 percent. Under the new tariff, rates for non-MFN imports were double the ones for ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution POLAND 401 MFN imports, with a rate of 25 percent ad valorem for those with an MFN rate of zero. March 1. The Export Development Fund (EDF) started operation, and the equalization settlement system was abolished. The resources of the EDF were customs duties (from Areas I and II), price corrections on imports from Area I, and a share of profits from the sale of centrally provided foreign exchange at auctions of the Export Development Bank. These resources were to be used to subsidize exports provided that subsidies for exports to Area I were limited to the amount of funds collected on price corrections on imports from Area I. March 14. Under a resolution from the Council of Ministers, enterprises were given 14 days to resell to a foreign exchange bank the portion of export pro- ceeds that may not be retained under the surrender regulations. September 19. A trade-liberalization agreement was signed with the EC envisaging reciprocal tariff reductions for agricultural goods and the phased elimination of quantitative restrictions on industrial goods during 1992-94. In early November 1989, the EC agreed to abolish the import quotas on industrial goods as of January 1, 1990, increase the foreign trade concessions, and accord Poland the GSP (Gen- eralized System of Preferences) status. In late November, the EC exempted Poland from quotas on such sensitive items as cars and shoes. October 5. The customs tariff rates on noncom- mercial imports were raised on average threefold. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles March 15. With the legalization of the parallel exchange market under the new foreign exchange law, foreign exchange at the official rate ceased to be provided for travel abroad, and the 200 percent sur- charge on the provision of convertible currencies for that purpose was abolished. Capital January 1. A new joint-venture law (Law on Eco- nomic Activity with Participation of Foreign Parties of December 23,1988) entered into effect, replacing the Law on Companies with Foreign Capital Par- ticipation that had been in effect since July 1, 1986. Under the new law, joint ventures could have ma- jority foreign participation and a foreign general manager. The statutory income tax rate was estab- lished at 40 percent (compared with the previous rate of 50 percent), and the initial tax holiday was extended to three years from two years. For joint ventures in priority sectors, the tax holiday may be extended by up to an additional three years at the discretion of the Council of Ministers. Joint ventures were eligible for income tax reliefs and foreign ex- change retention on exports at the rate of 85 percent. The minimum capital requirement was the equiv- alent of US$50,000, and joint partners were permit- ted to transfer abroad their profits up to the dif- ference between exports and imports. November 9. An agreement to protect foreign in- vestment was signed between Poland and the Federal Republic of Germany. With respect to Ger- man investment in Poland, the transfer of profits and dividends was allowed as follows: From January 1, 1993, 15 percent of 1992 profits. From January 1, 1994, 25 percent of 1993 profits. From January 1, 1995, 35 percent of 1994 profits. From January 1, 1996, 50 percent of 1995 profits. From January 1, 1997, 75 percent of 1996 profits. From January 1,1998,100 percent of 1997 profits. The sales or liquidation proceeds of German invest- ments made before the effective date of the treaty could be repatriated as follows: In the year of sale (at the earliest, on January 1, 1993), 20 percent. In the second year, 30 percent. In the third year, 50 percent. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Portugal is the Portuguese Es- cudo, the exchange rate of which is adjusted monthly1 in relation to a basket of currencies, weighted according to their importance in Portu- gal's international merchandise trade. Depreciation objectives for the effective exchange rate of the es- cudo are announced periodically by the authorities. During 1989, the monthly rate of devaluation was 0.25 percent in order to reach an annual rate of depreciation of 3.0 percent. On December 29, 1989, the official basic rate for the U.S. dollar was Esc 149.841 per US$1. Official exchange rates for the U.S. dollar and other currencies2 are determined during the fixing session, in which the Bank of Portugal and the authorized banks participate. These rates are a reference for the banks' bid and offer rates, which are freely set. A tax of 0.9 percent on all sales of foreign exchange is collected by the commercial banks. Commercial banks may deal in foreign exchange with the Bank of Portugal, among themselves, with other domestic nonbank economic agents, and with banks abroad. Spot or forward foreign exchange operations are carried out at freely negotiated ex- change rates, and the maximum period allowed for forward transactions is one year. Foreign exchange operations between banks and nonbank economic agents are always linked to purchases or sales of foreign exchange with escudos as a result of imports or exports of goods, services, current invisibles, or capital movements. There are no restrictions on for- eign exchange deals among banks in Portugal and banks abroad except forward purchases of escudos from nonresidents, which are not authorized. There are no restrictions on foreign exchange deals in the interbank foreign exchange market. Foreign ex- change transactions of commercial banks with the Bank of Portugal are, in principle, limited to the spot market. The degree of foreign exchange risks that banks are authorized to take must fall within the limits established by the Bank of Portugal for the 1 Since 1977, except from December 1985 to April 1986. 2Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Cana- dian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, European Currency Units (ECUs), Finnish markkaa, French francs, Greek drachmas, Italian lire, Irish pounds, Japanese yen, Macao patacas (which are pegged to the Hong Kong dollar at a parity rate of P 1.03 = HK$1), Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds ster- ling, South African rand, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, and Swiss francs. foreign exchange positions of banks in terms of for- eign currencies. On January 1, 1988, the Bank of Portugal became a participant in the European Monetary Coopera- tion Fund (EMCF), enabling it to participate in the mechanism for the creation of official ECUs through swaps of 20 percent of its gold and dollar reserves. These swaps are renewable every three months so as to ensure that contributions to the EMCF repre- sent at least 20 percent of the reserves of the Bank of Portugal. Portugal formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from September 12, 1988. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Bank of Portugal on behalf of the Ministry of Finance, with the assistance of the commercial banks autho- rized for this purpose. Foreign trade policy is formulated and imple- mented by the Ministry of Commerce and Tourism. The Direcgao-Geral do Comercio Externo in this Ministry is responsible for administering trade con- trols, and for issuing import and export licenses, declarations, and certificates. Prescription of Currency Transactions with Turkey are settled on a monthly basis through a clearing account maintained in U.S. dollars. Export transactions with other countries may be settled from a nonresident account with a resident bank in the quoted currencies (see footnote 2) or in U.S. dollars. Payments to nonresidents may be made by crediting escudos to a nonresident ac- count. The Portuguese escudo may be accepted as the currency of settlement for exports of goods, services, and capital transfers to Portugal. Nonresident Accounts In 1988, the Bank of Portugal issued new regula- tions concerning nonresident accounts in escudos and in foreign currencies. The interest paid on emi- grants' savings accounts and joint accounts with residents is the same as that paid by credit institu- tions on residents' deposits having the same matu- rity. Interest rates on time deposit accounts in for- eign currencies are established by agreement between the credit institution and the emigrant. 402 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL 403 The interest earned on all types of emigrants' de- posits is taxed at the rate of 7.5 percent a year. 1. Nonresident Accounts in Escudos The opening of nonresident accounts in escudos is free. They must be non-interest-bearing demand accounts, and exceptions must be especially autho- rized by the Bank of Portugal. Nonresident accounts in escudos may be cred- ited, without the prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal, with (1) the amount of escudos corre- sponding to transfers from abroad or sales of for- eign currency and other means of payments de- nominated in foreign currencies; (2) the amount of escudos corresponding to payments to nonresi- dents of Portuguese imports of goods and services as well as outflows of private capital duly authorized by current legislation; and (3) transfers from other nonresident accounts in escudos. Nonresident accounts in escudos may be freely debited for (1) transfers abroad resulting from the purchase of foreign currency with escudos; (2) payments to residents for Portuguese exports of goods, services, current invisibles, and private cap- ital outflows, duly authorized by current legislation; and (3) transfers to other nonresident accounts in escudos. For credit operations not specified above, the authorization of the Bank of Portugal is required. The granting of credit in the form of overdrafts on the accounts described above requires the authori- zation of the Bank of Portugal. 2. Nonresident Accounts in Foreign Currency Opening and transactions of nonresident ac- counts in foreign currency —demand accounts and time accounts up to one year —are not restricted. Time accounts of more than one year require special authorization from the Bank of Portugal. Interest rates are freely negotiable. Accounts may be de- nominated in any foreign currency acceptable to the banks. 3. Emigrants' Accounts Portuguese emigrants may open three types of deposit accounts: emigrants' savings accounts (time accounts in escudos); joint accounts with residents (deposit or time accounts in escudos); and time deposit accounts in foreign currency. a. Emigrants' savings accounts may be credited with the equivalent amount in escudos of remit- tances from abroad received through the banking system or in the form of an international postal order, with the equivalent in escudos of external means of payment sold to credit institutions by emi- grants, with transfers from other accounts of the same owner (emigrants' savings accounts or ac- counts in foreign currency), and with interest due on such deposits. These accounts may be debited without restriction. b. Joint accounts with residents are similar to resi- dents' deposit accounts and can be in the form of either demand or time deposits. These accounts may be credited with funds from abroad (similar to crediting emigrants' savings deposits) or with funds from domestic sources. These accounts may be debited without restriction, except for transfers to emigrants' savings accounts or abroad. Transfers abroad are subject to the regulations that apply to current transfers. c. Time deposit accounts in foreign currencies may be credited with remittances from abroad, with sales of external means of payment by emigrants, and with transfers from other accounts in foreign currency of the same owner and with interest due. These accounts may be debited without restriction. Interest income from all types of emigrants' de- posits is taxed at the rate of 3.3 percent a year. Resident Accounts in Foreign Currency The opening of resident accounts in foreign cur- rency requires special authorization from the Bank of Portugal, unless the holder is a bank. Without prior authorization, commercial banks may open, at home or abroad, demand accounts or time accounts up to one year in any currency at freely negotiated interest rates. Imports and Import Payments Import declarations are issued for statistical sur- veillance purposes and are granted automatically in four to five days. Imports of certain products are prohibited or are allowed only under specific condi- tions, mainly for reasons of health, public order, and the prevention of commercial fraud. Any physical or juridical entity may be an importer. For imports free of quantitative restriction, the importer is required to present the import contract and Form 8 of EC (European Communities) Single Customs Declaration to obtain the foreign exchange necessary to settle the contract. For agricultural products covered by a common market organiza- tion, the EC may require an import certificate. For imports subject to quantitative restrictions, an im- port license is required. The validity of the import declaration is 6 months for customs clearance pur- poses, and the settlement period is 12 months. Pay- ments after one year of customs clearance require the approval of the Bank of Portugal. According to the Act of Accession of Portugal to the European Communities, imports of some agri- cultural products are subject to temporary restric- tions when originating in EC and third countries. Several industrial products are subject to quantita- tive restrictions only when originating in third ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 404 PORTUGAL countries. A more extensive restricted list, which applies to Japan, includes manufactured raw mate- rials, some textile fibers, and a small number of finished products, including motorcycles. Payments for Invisibles Payments to foreign countries for current invis- ibles must be made through credit institutions au- thorized to operate in foreign exchange and are generally free of quantitative restrictions, although prior verification by the Bank of Portugal or other credit institutions properly authorized is required. For most transactions, ceilings are specified for the amounts of foreign exchange that authorized credit institutions may grant freely. For payments to countries with which Portugal does not maintain special clearing arrangements, the authorized credit institutions may grant foreign exchange up to the equivalent of Esc 30 million a transaction for most types of invisibles. For tourism and other private travel, they have been allowed to grant any amount in foreign currency since March 1, 1989. However, whenever requested by the customs authorities, travelers residing in Portu- gal must produce documents proving acquisition of foreign currency on a regular basis in excess of the equivalent of Esc 500 million. In addition, tourists may take out of the country Esc 10,000 in domestic currency for each trip.3 The export of larger amounts of domestic or foreign currency requires the prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal. Ap- plications must be submitted to the Bank of Portugal for exchange for payments of items not referred to above and for payments in excess of the above- mentioned limits. Under the provisions of the Foreign Investment Code, individual remittances of profits and divi- dends and the repatriation of proceeds of liquida- tion of direct foreign investment in Portugal are free of restrictions, although prior declaration to the Bank of Portugal is required. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports, which are not subject to quantitative restrictions under EC regulations, are free of restric- tions. The export of a few commodities may be re- stricted, mainly to ensure adequate supplies to do- mestic industries and to avoid depletion of local 3The use of credit cards abroad has been liberalized. However, legislation in force envisages the possibility of reimposing restric- tions on the use of credit cards by the Bank of Portugal whenever deemed necessary. Also, payments of travel and accommodation expenses abroad for tourism purposes have been liberalized if paid through a Portuguese travel agency. resources. These exports require an export license as do iron scraps. Exports without concomitant for- eign exchange inflow require prior authorization from the Bank of Portugal. Exporters are required to sell to an authorized bank the total amount of their export proceeds within specified periods. The period for settlement of merchandise exports is, as a rule, fixed at six months from the date of customs clearance. Pay- ment of commission expenses abroad and freight, insurance, or other charges is subject to the regula- tions that govern payments for invisibles. Proceeds from Invisibles Portuguese residents may freely receive pay- ments in escudos and in foreign currency for invis- ibles from residents of countries with which Portu- gal does not have special clearing arrangements. Such receipts must be effected through credit in- stitutions and do not require prior authorization from the Bank of Portugal. Receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Authorized banks are not permitted to receive or to pay domestic or foreign bank notes or coins for settlement of external transactions. There are no limits on the amount of domestic currency notes resident and nonresident travelers may bring into the country. Capital As of January 1, 1986, the effective date of Portu- gal's accession to the EC, foreign exchange regula- tions distinguish between capital transactions with residents of EC member countries and residents of non-EC member countries, although in most cases the distinction is not relevant in practice. Most pay- ments will be free of restrictions after a transitional period of four to seven years, depending on the type of transaction. Foreign direct investments in Portu- gal are permitted in all sectors except those that, under the general law, are closed to private enter- prise corporations. Since July 1986, the new foreign investment regulations stipulate that new direct in- vestment projects are subject only to prior declara- tion to the Portuguese Foreign Trade Institute and will be considered approved if the Institute does not reply within 60 days. However, foreign direct in- vestment in the form of long-term loans must be verified in advance by the Bank of Portugal. In both cases, in 1988 new foreign direct investment by EC residents of less than ECU 2.1 million was automat- ically approved, and this amount will be increased by ECU 0.3 million a year until 1990, when foreign direct investments will be free of restrictions. The ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL 405 transfer of the proceeds of liquidation of foreign direct investment including capital gains is free of restrictions. Foreign direct investments in EC countries by Portuguese residents require special authorization until 1993, when they will be free of restrictions. However, since November 1988, investments in EC and other member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) are liberalized up to Esc 50 million. Real estate may be freely purchased in Portugal since January 1, 1986, except for housing already built and land for agricultural purposes, which must be authorized by the Bank of Portugal until 1991. The proceeds of their liquidation could be freely transferred up to ECU 140,000 in 1988, and this ceiling will be increased by ECU 20,000 a year until 1991. Purchases of real estate in EC countries by Por- tuguese residents will be free of restrictions as of 1993. Purchases by nonresidents of domestic se- curities quoted in the stock exchange have been free of restrictions since January 1, 1986. Purchases by Portuguese residents of securities quoted in the stock exchange and issued by EC residents will continue to require special authorization from the Bank of Portugal until 1991. However, residents are allowed to invest in foreign securities listed in stock exchanges of OECD member countries within the following limits: (1) investment and pension funds, 20 percent of their total portfolio; (2) insurance com- panies, 10 percent of their technical reserves; (3) banks and financial institutions, 10 percent of their total portfolio; (4) nonfinancial corporations, 5 percent of their total portfolio; and (5) individuals, Esc 4 million. Subscription of securities issued by the European Investment Bank, the European Eco- nomic Community (EEC), the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM), and the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was free of re- strictions up to ECU 21 million in 1988, and this ceiling will be increased by ECU 3 million a year until 1991, when such purchases will become free of restrictions. Most trade credits and personal capital transfers have also been free of restrictions since January 1, 1986. Other types of capital transactions must have prior authorization from the Bank of Portugal and, in the case of capital transactions exceeding Esc 5 million and with a maturity of more than one year, the approval of the Minister of Finance is also required. The revisions of Portugal's reservations concern- ing the OECD (Organization for Economic Cooper- ation and Development) Code of Liberalization of Capital Movements have generally extended liberal- ization of capital transactions with the OECD coun- tries, which is similar to that extended to the EC member countries. Gold Residents may hold gold in any form in Portugal. The purchase, sale, import, export, or re-export of bullion or coins and unworked gold, when carried out between Portugal and foreign countries, must be authorized in advance by the Bank of Portugal. There is a free market for gold in Macao, in which both residents of Macao and nonresidents who are not resident in Portugal may freely trade among themselves in bars, leaves, and coins. Imports and exports of gold, unless made by or on behalf of the Macao monetary authorities, require licenses issued by the Commissioner for Economy.
