Not for Redistribution TURKEY (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Turkey is the Turkish Lira. The Turkish authorities do not observe margins in re- spect of exchange transactions, and Turkey follows a flexible exchange rate policy under which the ex- change rate for the Turkish lira against the U.S. dollar is determined in the daily fixing sessions held in the Central Bank. Commercial banks, special fi- nance institutions, authorized institutions, and the Central Bank can participate in the daily fixing ses- sion by giving two-way quotations with spreads between the purchase and sale prices not exceeding 1 percent for a sum of US$200,000. Once the Turkish lira exchange rate for the U.S. dollar is determined in the fixing session, exchange rates for other currencies are set on the basis of their cross rate relationship with the U.S. dollar in inter- national markets. These rates then become the offi- cial exchange rate of the following day and are used in the Central Bank's transactions and for official, statistical purposes. Commercial banks, special fi- nancial institutions, and foreign exchange dealers, in their foreign exchange transactions not exceeding US$10,000, may set their exchange rates with max- imum deviations from official exchange rates of 1 percent for sales of foreign currency notes and 0.2 percent for sales of foreign exchange. Further- more, exchange rates set by these institutions for purchases of foreign currency notes and foreign exchange cannot exceed their respective sale prices. In commercial and noncommercial foreign ex- change transactions exceeding US$10,000, the ex- change rate is determined freely by the commercial banks. The commercial banks are also free to establish their own buying and selling rates in the interbank market. Foreign exchange transactions between the Central Bank and the commercial banks take place through the interbank market. On December 29, 1989, the Central Bank's official buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were LT 2,311.37 and LT 2,316.00, respectively, per US$1. On December 29, 1989, the average rate in the interbank market for the U.S. dollar was LT 2,310.84 per US$1. A Foreign Exchange Risk Insurance Scheme (FERIS) is designed to provide domestic borrowers with an exchange rate guarantee for approved for- eign borrowing. Foreign borrowing under the scheme is on-lent in Turkish liras at a domestic variable interest rate determined on a monthly basis. The difference between the Turkish lira ex- change rate charged on the foreign borrowing and any bank commission is credited to the scheme. The difference between the lira cost at the time it is contracted and the lira cost of repayments is covered from resources of the scheme. Commercial banks can freely deal in forward transactions within the predetermined limits im- posed by the Central Bank. Forward transactions are permitted, with terms ranging from 15 days to 6 months, except for interbank forward transactions for which the minimum time limit is 1 day. Forward exchange rates are freely established between the banks and their customers in accordance with inter- national practices. Banks enter into swap transac- tions with the Central Bank with terms of quarterly periods up to 12 months. Banks use this facility mostly to provide Turkish liras. Turkey formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2,3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from March 22, 1990. Administration of Control Exchange and trade controls are the responsibil- ity of the Prime Ministry, to which the Under- secretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade is at- tached. Administration of exchange controls has been delegated to the Central Bank, which regu- lates all matters related to foreign exchange opera- tions. All commercial banks have been authorized by the Undersecretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade to engage in foreign exchange operations on their own account, including allocating foreign ex- change for imports not subject to prior permit. In the case of imports subject to prior permit, autho- rized commercial banks directly allocate foreign ex- change and issue import licenses upon receiving the approved import permit from the Under- secretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade. Export registration is carried out by trade organizations, according to instructions from the Undersecretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade. The Under- secretariat also issues export licenses but may delegate this authority to the relevant trade organizations. Prescription of Currency Settlements under bilateral payments agree- ments are made in U.S. dollars. Certain commercial transactions with Albania, Algeria, Bangladesh, 503 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 504 TURKEY Czechoslovakia, the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, Malta, Morocco, Poland, Romania, Sudan, Tunisia, and the U.S.S.R., and with the other members of the Economic Cooperation Or- ganization (ECO) are made through special ac- counts denominated in U.S. dollars. Settlements with all other countries are made in convertible currencies. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may open accounts denominated in foreign exchange with authorized commercial banks. Such accounts are disposable at the discre- tion of the holders. Imports and Import Payments All goods are freely importable except those ex- plicitly prohibited or subject to prior permit. Only imports of narcotics, stereopten, weapons, foreign coins made of silver and other metals (excluding foreign coins made of gold), and ammunition are prohibited without a special permit from the au- thorities. Imports of other goods are divided into two categories. The first category contains goods subject to licenses issued by the Undersecretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade, consists of 37 items, mainly raw materials, spare parts, intermediate goods and tools for industry, and electrical equip- ment. The second category of imports covers goods not subject to prior licensing that can enter the country only after payment of a specific levy (in addition to customs duties) to certain extra budge- tary funds ("funds list"). The magnitude of the levy varies between items, and its structure has been changed from time to time. The importation of all goods not included on ei- ther of the above lists is freely permitted after pay- ment of customs duties. However, imports of used and reconditioned, defective, substandard, soiled, or poor quality goods may be made only with spe- cial permission from the Undersecretariat of Trea- sury and Foreign Trade; when such goods are needed for, a project, permission may be given by the State Planning Organization. Imports from countries where foreign trade is nationalized may be carried out by public sector companies or foreign trade-incorporated companies, provided they ex- port to these countries. All imports by the public sector have to be authorized by the Undersecretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade. All commercial imports require import licenses, which are valid for six months. The validity may be extended by an authorized commercial bank for up to 12 additional months and can be fur ther extended by the Undersecretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade. Import licenses are issued to registered im- porters, industrialists, state economic enterprises, and government departments. In the case of freely importable items, including those on the "funds list," no special permit is required for any autho- rized person to apply for an import license to any bank. The import license permits the necessary for- eign exchange payments to be made and permits goods to be cleared through customs. Payments for imports may be made against letters of credit, docu- ments, or goods (i.e., upon customs clearance), or by way of acceptance credits. Partial prepayments are authorized under certain conditions. Guarantee deposits, which must be made by the importer before the import license is issued, are refunded after the goods are cleared through customs and the foreign payment has been made. These deposits do not earn interest. The general guarantee deposit rate is 5 percent of the foreign exchange requested, which applies to imports by commercial importers. This was raised to 15 percent on October 14,1988, but was reduced to 5 percent in 1989. Imports for the Izmir International Fair, cer- tain imports of the public sector, private sector im- ports financed by foreign exchange from importers' own accounts, imports of investment goods for the manufacturing industries, electrical energy, books and other publications, portions of imports paid for with a foreign credit with more than a one-year term, fuel oil, natural gas, wheat, sugar, coal, fertil- izer, vegetable oils, medicine, x-ray photographs, imports of specially equipped cars for the disabled, and imports covered by an incentive certificate for regions with a development priority are exempted from the guarantee deposit requirement. Exporters who make use of their own foreign exchange ac- counts to pay for imports that are not subject to prior authorization are also exempted from the guarantee deposit requirement; in addition, they are ex- empted from this requirement for up to the equiv- alent of 30 percent of the foreign exchange held in such accounts for imports that are subject to prior authorization. Regulations concerning imports without alloca- tion of foreign exchange by the banking system mainly affect imports of goods for personal or pro- fessional use by travelers domiciled in Turkey, and temporary imports by Turkish workers employed abroad and maintaining foreign exchange accounts with the Central Bank. Customs duties are based on the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System. The rates range mostly up to 10 percent on raw mate- rials, between 10 percent and 30 percent on inter- mediate and semifinished products, and between ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY 505 30 percent and 50 percent on finished goods. Higher rates apply to certain consumer goods con- sidered luxuries. Imported goods are also subject to (1) a municipal tax of 15 percent of the applicable customs duty; (2) a stamp duty of 10 percent of the declared value; and (3) a quay duty of 5 percent on the sum of c .i .f. value, customs duty, municipal tax, and customs clearance expense. Payments for Invisibles Residents may freely make payments for invisible transactions relating to all services to nonresidents at home or abroad. All residents may travel abroad with a maximum of US$3,000 a person without proof of exchange allocation by commercial banks, and banks are per- mitted to sell to residents up to US$3,000 a person without restriction. Outbound travelers are subject to a tax equivalent to US$100, payable in Turkish liras, regardless of whether there are related pur- chases of foreign exchange; the tax is reduced by one half for travelers 18 years of age or younger. Individuals engaged in border trade with the per- mission of the governor of the province concerned and immigrants and refugees traveling abroad are required to pay the tax in Turkish liras equivalent to US$25 and US$50, respectively. Exempted from payment of this tax are (1) all foreign nationals; (2) first-time pilgrims to Mecca; (3) Turkish workers employed abroad and their families; (4) crews of ships and planes, and truck drivers; (5) those living in border areas and who may leave the country by Administrative Permits; (6) those going abroad for medical treatment and their escorts; (7) private stu- dents going abroad for education purposes; and (8) civil servants (and their families) sent abroad on permanent assignment. Travelers are permitted to take out up to the equivalent of US$3,000 in Turkish lira notes and coins; nonresidents may take out without restriction the unspent portion of the foreign exchange that they brought in. Provided that the foreign exchange was declared at the time of entry, nonresident trav- elers may reconvert liras into foreign currency upon presentation of documents showing that foreign ex- change had previously been sold to an authorized dealer in Turkey. Turkish workers employed abroad and persons domiciled abroad may freely take abroad with them foreign exchange in excess of US$3,000 or its equivalent, provided that they de- clared such amounts on arrival. Exports and Export Proceeds Commercial exports fall into the following catego- ries: (1) exports subject to permission of the Under- secretary of Treasury and Foreign Trade, including temporary exports; transit trade; re-exports; expor- tation of already imported goods in their original form; exports made to substitute already exported goods that could not be delivered to, or had been rejected by, their buyer and have been brought back or committed to be brought back or permitted for sale under other conditions since their return is not considered economical; forward sales; barter trade and related transactions; exports from free zones inside or outside Turkey or from duty-free ware- houses that are not subject to license or registration against convertible foreign exchange; and exports to be realized by the construction companies that are awarded construction, installation, and erection work abroad; (2) exports subject to the license is- sued by the Undersecretariat of Treasury and For- eign Trade or the authorized professional institu- tions, applicable to the following 11 items (rice, fodder, crude vegetable oils, oil seeds, all live or dead hunting animals or their meats, furs and em- balmments, all kinds of hides and leathers—raw, semifinished, or finished leathers, or sole leathers—live cattle and sheep, opium poppy heads, licorice roots, and fertilizers except chemical fertilizers); (3) exports subject to registration, in- cluding exports on consignment or on joint account (fresh fruits except citrus, fresh vegetables includ- ing onions and potatoes, wine except from EC coun- tries, Turkish delight and candies, meat products, all kinds of fresh and frozen water products except crawfish, gift articles except carpets, kilims, and prayer rugs), exports on credit, exports related to bilateral agreements, and exports of certain prod- ucts to specific countries that are determined by the Undersecretariat and required to be registered as "Free Export Declarations"; and (4) free exports (ex- ports not based on any permission, license, or regis- tration) requiring registration as "Free Export Decla- rations." Barter trade is prohibited, except for authorized public sector agencies and export com- panies with export earnings of at least US$50 million a calendar year. The surrender requirement for foreign exchange receipts from merchandise exports is 70 percent. Retained foreign exchange may be deposited in for- eign exchange accounts with commercial banks, kept abroad, or disposed of. The maximum period allowed for the surrender of at least 70 percent of export proceeds is 180 days from the date of export shipment. Under an export tax rebate scheme, direct and indirect taxes paid are refunded for certain exported goods consisting mostly of industrial goods. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 506 TURKEY Proceeds from Invisibles Residents may accept foreign currency from non- residents for transactions processed in Turkey. For- eign exchange earned by residents in exchange for services they have rendered to nonresidents or on behalf of them in Turkey or abroad (including con- tracting services) as well as foreign exchange corre- sponding to expenses incurred in the name and on behalf of nonresidents can be disposed of freely. Capital Nonresident individuals and corporations wish- ing to invest in Turkey must import the required capital in the form of foreign exchange or in kind and must obtain a license from the Foreign Capital Department of the State Planning Organization. Consistent with the prevailing foreign investment policy, proposals in almost all sectors of business are approved, provided that a minimum of 50 per- cent of foreign capital is brought in by foreign inves- tors. Exempt from this requirement are certain in- vestments made in accordance with the provisions of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Invest- ments or the Petroleum Law. The proceeds of sales and liquidation of foreign capital by banks and fi- nancial institutions may be transferred abroad and must be reported to the Central Bank. Resident individuals or corporations may invest abroad up to the equivalent of US$25 million in cash or in kind with authorization from the Undersecretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade. Higher amounts must be approved by the Council of Ministers. Nonresi- dents may transfer abroad without restriction pro- ceeds from sales of real estate purchased with for- eign exchange remitted from abroad. Purchases and sales of Turkish securities quoted in the stock ex- change by nonresidents and purchases of foreign securities by residents are free, provided that the transactions are carried out by authorized agents. Commercial banks may open "Foreign Exchange Accounts" for residents or nonresidents. Funds in such accounts may be freely disposed of by the holders, and interest rates and other conditions on the above accounts are freely negotiable between the parties. Commercial banks are free to conduct foreign exchange transactions according to their needs. In addition, banks are obligated to hold for- eign exchange liquidity against letters of credit com- mitments, acceptance credits, pre-export financing, and foreign exchange loans guaranteed by banks with a maturity of up to six months, as well as direct foreign exchange borrowing by the banks. The ratio of all foreign currency-denominated assets to the sum of foreign currency deposits plus foreign ex- change overdrafts and foreign exchange loans re- ceived from abroad is subject to an exchange rate risk ratio requirement. This ratio is calculated on the basis of three categories: the U.S. dollar, the deut- sche mark, and the U.S. dollar equivalent of other convertible currencies. The exchange rate risk used in relation to foreign exchange position manage- ment is 85 percent (minimum) and 115 percent (maximum) for the first two categories, and 90 per- cent (minimum) and 110 percent (maximum) for the third category. The minimum utilization ratio of for- eign currency deposits is 50 percent (i.e., banks must extend 50 percent of foreign currency deposits as foreign credit). Gold The Central Bank of Turkey is authorized to im- port gold into Turkey and conduct purchase and sale transactions with the public without restriction. A gold market is established in the Central Bank, in which gold conforming to international standards is sold to the banks and authorized institutions in ex- change for foreign currency. Banks and authorized institutions in turn sell gold to the public in ex- change for Turkish liras. The import and export of processed precious metal stones and goods for com- mercial purposes are not restricted. However, the Prime Ministry determines the qualifications of the authorized companies to conduct business. Trav- elers may bring into or take out of Turkey their personal precious metals or stones valued at up to US$15,000. Exports or imports of metals or stones exceeding this value are subject to declaration. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement June 16. Residents of Turkey were permitted to purchase foreign exchange up to the equivalent of US$3,000. There are no limits on the number of transactions from commercial banks or private financial institutions. September 14. Adult ethnic Turks arriving from Bulgaria with a 15-day tourist visa were required to have the equivalent of at least US$1,050 in convert- ible currencies; children under the age of 18 were required to have the equivalent of at least US$750 in convertible currencies. November 18. The ceiling on foreign exchange that travelers are permitted to take abroad without proof of exchange allocation by commercial banks was raised to US$3,000. Exports and Export Proceeds February 15. The establishment of the Eximbank program of post-shipment credits was announced. (Disbursements began in March.) March 1. The Turkish Eximbank established a US$150 million facility to support exports of Turkish consumer goods to the U.S.S.R. The facility was initially funded by borrowing from domestic com- mercial banks and was refinanced through external borrowing. Credits are to be repaid in two years at a rate of 20 basis points over LIBOR. In July, an addi- tional US$150 million facility for nonagricultural ex- ports was announced. The Turkish Eximbank announced the establish- ment of the Short-Term Whole Turnover Insurance Program. The program is designed to promote the export of Turkish goods on credit by insuring Turk- ish exporters on market terms against commercial and political risks. June 1. The maximum term on Eximbank preship- ment credits was raised to 180 days from 120 days, and the interest charge on 90-day credits was lowered by 2 percentage points to 37 percent. The ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 508 TURKEY credit limit for individual firms was raised to LT 4 billion from LT 500 million. June 13. New legislation, clarifying the duties and powers of the Undersecretariat of Treasury and For- eign Trade in line with the Treasury's charter, was introduced, and the requirements for export li- censes were eliminated. June 20. The Central Bank announced that it would reimburse Turkish exporters holding out- standing claims on Iraq arising from exports on credit. Under the credit program suspended in 1988, the Central Bank provided partial credit coverage with the remainder being made available by the exporting firm. July. A US$100 million Eximbank facility for ex- ports to Algeria was announced. (Utilization is to begin in August.) August 2. A 2 percent marketing premium based on the value of exports in 1989 was introduced for major exporters (foreign trade companies with ex- ports of at least US$100 million in 1988 that pledge to export at least US$100 million in 1989). The pre- mium will be paid from the Support and Price Stabi- lization Fund and administered by the Turkish Eximbank. August 11. The surrender requirement was lowered to 70 percent from 80 percent, with the maximum period allowed for the surrender of 180 days from the date of export shipments. October 1. The transfer requirement for commer- cial banks for receipts of foreign exchange was lowered to 22 percent from 23 percent. (On Novem- ber 2, the requirement was further lowered to 20 percent.) October 28. It was announced that the "Special Export Rediscount Credits Program" would be phased out and replaced by the "Foreign Trade Capital Companies Rediscount Credit Program." The new program will be virtually identical to the previous program, except that the subsidized credits, which will be equal to 5 percent of the value of exports of the previous 12-month period, will carry a maturity of only 90 days. November 12. Legislation was drawn up, establish- ing a 1 percent marketing premium similar to that established in August for major exporters. The pre- mium would be available to exporters whose real- ized exports exceeded US$10 million in 1988 and 1989. Capital June 19. Amendments to the Corporation Tax Law and Income Tax Law, exempting "investment funds subject to limited tax liability," were adopted. For- eign investment funds approved by the Treasury were allowed to set up securities portfolios, the in- come from which would be tax free. August 11. Applications by residents of Turkey to make direct investments overseas of up to US$25 million or its equivalent were subject to approval (by the Undersecretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade). The export of capital exceeding this amount was subject to approval by the Council of Ministers, upon recommendation of the Undersecretariat of Treasury and Foreign Trade. August 11. Foreign residents were allowed to pur- chase or sell any type of Turkish securities regis- tered on the stock exchange through intermediary institutions operating on the market and to transfer the income or proceeds from sales of these se- curities abroad through banks and authorized fi- nancial institutions, provided that such proceeds would not be transferred abroad. If the securities had not been purchased with funds transferred from abroad, the proceeds from the sales of se- curities would be allowed to be utilized freely in Turkey. September 13. The foreign exchange risk ratios that determine the maximum and minimum ratios of foreign currency-denominated assets and liabilities commercial banks may hold were widened to 85-115 percent from 90-110 percent. Gold April 10. The Central Bank established facilities for selling gold to commercial banks for foreign exchange and for the interbank trading of gold against foreign exchange. Commercial banks in turn are permitted to sell gold to domestic residents in exchange for domestic currency. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Uganda is the Uganda Shilling, the external value of which is determined on the basis of a trade-weighted basket of currencies. On December 29, 1989, the official buying and selling rates were U Sh 364.08 and U Sh 378.80, respec- tively, per US$1. Buying and selling rates for other currencies are determined on the basis of the cross rates between the U.S. dollar and the currencies concerned in the international market. In its foreign exchange dealings, the Bank of Uganda charges a commission of 0.4 percent buying and 0.6 percent selling. Authorized commercial banks in Uganda deal in all specified currencies1 at rates quoted by the Bank of Uganda or, for a currency not quoted, at rates calculated according to prevailing cross rates. Authorized banks may, subject to exchange control approval, deal forward with customers in sterling, U.S. dollars, and other currencies, provided that there is an underlying approved import or export contract. Authorized foreign exchange dealers im- pose a service charge of not more than 0.5 percent. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange risk. Administration of Control The Bank of Uganda administers exchange con- trol on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Import and export control is administered by the Ministry of Commerce. The Minister of Commerce has powers to prohibit imports and exports. Arrears are main- tained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency The Bank of Uganda holds reciprocal accounts with the central banks of Kenya and Tanzania, which are settled in U.S. dollars. Authorized pay- ments, including payments for imports, by resi- dents of Uganda to residents of foreign countries other than Israel and South Africa may be made in Uganda shillings to the credit of an External Ac- count in Uganda, or in any other currency that is Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish and Faeroese kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Por- tuguese escudos, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, U.S. dollars, and all currencies of the former Sterling Area other than the Uganda shilling. appropriate to the country of residence of the payee. Receipts from such countries may be ob- tained in Uganda shillings from an external account in Uganda or in any convertible currency. Payments to Israel and South Africa are prohibited. Certain settlements with Burundi, Rwanda, and Zaire are channeled through special accounts. Uganda main- tains bilateral trade and payments agreements with Algeria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Egypt, the German Democratic Republic, the Democratic People's Re- public of Korea, the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, and Yugoslavia. External Accounts Accounts in Uganda shillings held by residents of foreign countries who are living in Uganda are des- ignated external accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments by residents of Uganda, with transfers from other external ac- counts, and with the proceeds from sales of any foreign exchange currency and gold by nonresi- dents of Uganda to authorized dealers. They may be debited freely for payments to nonresidents, for transfers to other external accounts in Uganda, and for purchases of foreign currencies from authorized dealers. Nontransferable funds of persons not resident in Uganda are credited to blocked accounts main- tained with commercial banks. Subject to prior ap- proval, balances on blocked accounts may be used for the purchase in Uganda of specified bonds and shares issued in Uganda; the redemption proceeds of government bonds so acquired are transferable beginning five years from the date of purchase. Subject to individual permission, such balances may also be used for payments to residents not related to export transactions. Convertible Currency Accounts Private Ugandan nationals or institutions with funds abroad may be authorized to operate Con- vertible Currency Accounts with commercial banks in Uganda. Intending operators of such accounts are required to disclose the sources of the funds and to put up a minimum of the equivalent of US$5,000 to open the account. These accounts can be freely debited, and other governing regulations are similar to those for the regime of External Accounts (see above). The minimum balance in each such account 509 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 510 UGANDA must be US$3,000, below which the account is liable to closure by the Bank of Uganda. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Israel and South Africa are pro- hibited. Most imports are controlled through the import licensing and foreign exchange allocation systems. A monthly foreign exchange budget is pre- pared by a Ministerial Committee on Foreign Ex- change Allocation. Foreign exchange allocations to various ministries and departments must be backed by documents showing approval of the Central Tender Board, an original budget authorization, and the signature of the Secretary of the Treasury or a duly designated officer. Once an importer has received a foreign exchange allocation, an import license is granted automatically. An approved for- eign exchange allocation must be purchased from the Bank of Uganda within 21 days by a commercial bank, and the importer must make a (interest bear- ing) margin deposit of 100 percent of the shilling value of the foreign exchange allocation with that bank. A modification of the above procedures is applica- ble to imports in sectors eligible for the Open Gen- eral License (OGL) system. Under this system, which was introduced in November 1987, foreign exchange is made freely available for imports of inputs by specific enterprises in five key industries (soap, tobacco, beverages, textiles, and cement). In practice, because the demand for imports under the OGL system exceeds the foreign exchange made available for this purpose, eligible firms are granted approval only for a specific total value of imports during a six-month period. Requests to draw on these amounts are considered in conjunction with the monthly foreign exchange budget formulation. The Central Bank may object to the granting of foreign exchange for such imports either because the quoted import price or the import volume is considered excessive. Foreign exchange for OGL imports is obtained from import support funds pro- vided by the World Bank, the EC, and bilateral donors. Under a special import program (SIP) (intro- duced in December 1988), monthly allocations of foreign exchange are made to certain categories of imports on a first-come first-served basis. In order to receive such exchange allocations, an advance deposit of 100 percent is required, and it cannot be financed with credit obtained from commercial banks. The SIP was liberalized in June 1989, permit- ting additional imports and some service payments. By the end of October 1989 the SIP was inoperative due to lack of foreign exchange. Import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Commerce, and a commission of 0.5 percent of the license value is levied. In addition, the importer must prepay customs duties and sales taxes applica- ble to the prospective imports. The Ministry of Commerce also issues licenses for private sector imports financed from the importers' own foreign exchange resources without an official allocation. In these cases, the Ministry examines the application to ensure that price and quantity are reasonable. Import shipments are subject to inspection by inter- national agencies to ensure that the invoice price corresponds to the actual value. Anyone wishing to import goods valued in excess of US$20,000 is required to submit pro forma in- voices from three different suppliers, except in the case of repeater and proprietary imports. Normally, imports must be purchased directly from the coun- try of origin. Documentary evidence showing that the goods have been imported into Uganda must be forwarded to the exchange control authorities within four months of the date of payment in the case of goods shipped by surface transportation, and within two months for goods brought into the country by air. Cash imports are permitted only on a c. & f. basis. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are subject to approval by the Committee on Invisible Imports of the Bank of Uganda, in the context of the monthly foreign ex- change budget. Payments to Israel and South Africa are prohibited. For business travel a daily allowance of US$100-!40 a person is granted, up to an annual limit of US$2,000 a person. The maximum yearly travel allowance for purposes other than business is US$500 a person. Expatriates working in Uganda may obtain allocations for travel outside Uganda at the time of their overseas leave, subject to the terms of the original contract. Foreign exchange is not normally released for nursery, primary, and second- ary education abroad. Allowances for postsecond- ary education abroad are based on estimates of tuition fees, board and lodging, and incidental ex- penses; foreign exchange is not normally provided when a comparable level of instruction is provided in Uganda. Facilities exist whereby salaried foreign nationals may remit to their country of origin up to one third of their gross monthly earnings to cover family maintenance, savings, etc., provided that they are on a contract of employment that includes a firm commitment to leave Uganda upon expiry of the contract. At this time, they may also remit a fur ther US$5,000. Allowances for medical and ad- vertising expenses are considered on a case-by-case ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA 511 basis. Applications to remit profits, dividends, and interest payments are approved on a case-by-case basis. Payments by the private nonbank sector for all other invisible transactions and for certain capital transfers are subject to a combined limit specified below in the section on Capital. The export of Uganda bank notes and coins by travelers is pro- hibited, except that travelers may take out U Sh 300. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel and South Africa are prohibited. All exports require licenses from the Ministry of Commerce and may be restricted to ensure suffi- cient supplies for consumption in Uganda. The Cof- fee Marketing Board has a monopoly over the export of coffee; and the Lint Marketing Board, over the export of raw cotton. Parastatal organizations are also involved in the export of the following com- modities: the Produce Marketing Board in the ex- port of maize, beans, soybeans, sesame seeds, and peanuts; the Uganda Leather and Tanning Industry for hides and skins; and Uganda Hardware for tim- ber. Export licenses for these products, however, are also granted to other exporters, subject to deter- mination by the relevant organization that price and quality are reasonable and domestic supplies are adequate. Export proceeds in specified currencies (see foot- note 1) must be collected within four months for goods shipped overseas and within two months for goods exported to neighboring countries or by air to any destination and, except for certain nontradi- tional agricultural exports, as described below, sold to an authorized bank for Uganda shillings. The authorized bank must in turn surrender these pro- ceeds to the Bank of Uganda within three business days; failure to do so entails payment of interest at a rate of 5 percent above the LIBOR or prime rate in the country where the funds are held. Coffee and cotton are subject to an export duty. Exporters of all agricultural products other than coffee may retain all or part of the foreign exchange proceeds. Exporters wishing to exercise this option are granted an import license at the time they re- ceive an export license of equivalent (or greater) value, for use in conjunction with imports financed within 180 days of the receipt of the export license. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see footnote 1) must be sold to an authorized bank within 48 hours. The import of Uganda bank notes and coins by travelers is prohibited, except that returning residents may bring in U Sh 300 a person. Travelers may freely bring in bank notes denomi- nated in specified currencies and foreign currency traveler's checks. Capital Capital transfers to all countries require individ- ual exchange control approval, and those to Israel and South Africa are prohibited. Foreign assets must be deposited with an authorized depository, except that residents of Uganda may be granted exemption in respect of specified former Sterling Area assets held prior to June 11,1965. Residents of Uganda leaving permanently may normally trans- fer their assets up to the equivalent of US$10,000 for each family unit from their declared assets. Amounts in excess of this are placed in a Blocked Account and invested in Government of Uganda securities. The principal is transferred af ter a period of five years; the accrued interest is also released but not remitted. Principal payments on nonguaranteed overseas borrowing by resident companies or individuals are transferable. There are no restrictions on non- guaranteed overseas borrowing by resident com- panies or individuals. Foreign investment is permit- ted in Uganda with or without government participation. Certain industries, such as' public utilities, transportation, telecommunications, ship- ping, and the marketing of key commodities, are wholly reserved for government ownership. In other key industries, such as textiles, brewing, ani- mal feed manufacture, the dairy industry, and tour- ism, the Government may pre-empt a certain per- centage of the ownership but does accept private investment from both domestic and foreign sources. To secure a guarantee of repatriation, it is necessary to obtain "approved status" for the in- vestment in terms of the Foreign Investments (Pro- tection) Act, 1964; in normal circumstances, ap- proved status is given freely. Foreign and domestic investment in specified types of production re- quires approval under the Licensing Act of 1969. All imports and exports of securities require ap- proval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by nonresidents of Ugandan securities, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from such securities is remittable, and the proceeds on resale are normally remittable also. A resident of Uganda may not send money abroad, for whatever purpose, without specific exchange control approval. Prior exchange control approval is required for loans or overdraft facilities granted to a nonresident or to a corporate body resident in ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 512 UGANDA Uganda that is controlled, directly or indirectly, by persons resident outside Uganda. Payments by the private nonbank sector for all other capital transfers and all invisible payments not specified above are freely permitted up to an aggregate maximum allowance of US$500 a person a year, provided there is adequate evidence to sup- port the application. Gold A commemorative gold coin with a face value of U Sh 5 is legal tender but in practice does not circu- late. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Uganda for numismatic purposes. Only monetary authorities and authorized industrial and profes- sional users are allowed to hold or acquire gold in Uganda in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance. Export licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. The import of the following from all sources is subject to individual licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; goldsmiths' or sil- versmiths' wares, including set gems; bullion in the form of ingots, bars, or sheets; and gold coins. Im- port licenses for gold bullion, gold jewelry, and gold coins are issued restrictively and only to goldsmiths. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangements During 1989, the Ugandan shilling was devalued on several occasions, from U Sh 165 per US$1 at the end of 1988 to U Sh 375 per US$1 on November 27. June 14. A second exchange rate of U Sh 400 per US$1 was introduced solely for the purchase of for- eign exchange to import under the revised special import program (SIP II). (This exchange rate was abolished on November 27.) Imports and Import Payments March 31. The special import program (SIP I) be- came inoperative owing to a lack of foreign exchange. June 14. A revised and less restrictive special im- port program (SIP II) was introduced. Except for a small negative list, SIP II allowed the purchase of foreign exchange for all imports on a first-come first- served basis. November 1. The SIP II became inoperative. Exports and Export Proceeds March 7. The export-retention scheme for agri- cultural exports was extended to all commodities other than coffee. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED ARAB EMIRATES1 (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of the United Arab Emirates is the U.A.E. Dirham, which is pegged to the SDR at Dh 4.76190 = SDR 1. The United Arab Emirates has established margins of 7.25 percent around the offi- cial rate; since November 1980, the U.A.E dirham has maintained an unchanged relationship with the U.S. dollar. The U.S. dollar is the intervention cur- rency, and the Central Bank publishes buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar only. On Decem- ber 29, 1989, the official buying and selling rates were Dh 3.6690 and Dh 3.6730, respectively, per US$1. The Central Bank sets no limits on the amount of U.S. dollars that it is prepared to buy from or sell to any commercial bank. Commercial banks are free to enter into foreign exchange trans- actions, including forward contracts related to com- mercial and financial transactions, at rates of their own choosing; the rates quoted by commercial banks for currencies other than the U.S. dollar are determined on the basis of international quotations. There is a swap facility at the Central Bank, which the commercial banks may use to purchase dirhams spot and sell dirhams forward for periods of one week, one month, and three months. For each bank, maximum limits of US$20 million outstanding for one-month and three-month swaps and US$10 mil- lion outstanding for one-week swaps are in effect. There is also a limit of US$3 million in purchases a day for each bank for one-month and three-month swaps. Swap facilities are not available to banks having a short position in dirhams, except for the covering of forward transactions for commercial purposes. There are no taxes or subsidies on pur- chases or sales of foreign exchange. The United Arab Emirates formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement on February 13, 1974. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an exchange control authority in the United Arab Emirates, and there are no registration require- ments for inward or outward transfers. There is no regime of export and import licensing. irThe seven federated states of the United Arab Emirates are Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Sharjah, Ajman, Umm al Qaiwain, Ras al Khaimah, and Fujairah. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel and South Africa are prohibited. No other prescription of currency re- quirements are in force. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments Imports from South Africa and Israel are pro- hibited, as are imports of products manufactured by foreign companies blacklisted by the Arab League. Imports of a few commodities are prohibited from all sources for health or security reasons. Virtually all other commodities may be freely imported with- out an individual import permit, but only licensed parties can enter the import trade, and an importer can import only the commodities specified in his license. There are no restrictions on the availability of foreign exchange for payments in respect of per- mitted imports. With the exception of specified items, imports into the United Arab Emirates are subject to a customs duty of 4 percent of the c.i.f. value. Imports originating from member states of the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf (GCC) are not subject to any customs duty. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports and re-exports to South Africa and Israel are prohibited. Virtually all commodities may be exported or re-exported freely and without an ex- port license to any destination other than South Africa and Israel. Each Emirate establishes its own export regula- tions. The proceeds from exports need not be re- patriated or surrendered and may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles All payments for current invisibles may be made freely, with the exception of payments to South Africa and Israel, which are prohibited. There are no requirements governing receipts. Travelers may take out and bring in any amount in foreign or domestic bank notes. 513 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 514 UNITED ARAB EMIRATES Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or non- residents. Commercial banks operating in the United Arab Emirates are prohibited from owning real estate except for the purpose of carrying on business and for accommodation. Under the United Arab Emirates Company Law (Law No. 8, 1984), at least 51 percent of the equity of companies, other than branches of foreign companies, must be held by nationals of the United Arab Emirates. Nationals of the member countries of the GCC are permitted to hold up to 75 percent of equity of companies in the industrial, agricultural, fisheries, and con- struction sectors, and in the consultancy areas (Law No. 2, 1984). Profits on foreign capital invested in the United Arab Emirates may be remitted freely. Banks operating in the United Arab Emirates are required to maintain special deposits with the Cen- tral Bank equal to 30 percent of their placements with or lending to nonresident banks in dirhams with a remaining life of one year or less. The profits of certain banks are subject to a fee levied by local authorities at an annual rate of 20 percent. Central Bank swap facilities are not made available to banks having a short position in dirhams, except for the covering of forward transactions for commercial purposes. Gold Residents and nonresidents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. They may also, without a permit, import and export gold in any form, but the import of gold for trade purposes is undertaken only by licensed parties. Gold bullion is exempt from import duty but jewelry is not. Changes During 1989 Imports and Import Payments March 14. The United Arab Emirates and the United States concluded agreement concerning im- ports into the United States of five major categories of clothing; the agreement replaced the embargo (of November 1988) on imports into the United States of four categories of clothing. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of the United Kingdom is the Pound Sterling. The authorities of the United Kingdom do not maintain fixed margins in respect of exchange transactions, and the exchange rate is determined largely by the balance of market forces. At times when the rate is rising or falling, the authorities may intervene in the foreign exchange market with a view to moderating excessive fluctuations and pre- serving orderly markets. On December 29,1989, the closing buying and selling rates for the pound ster- ling against the U.S. dollar in foreign exchange mar- kets in London as observed by the Bank of England were US$1.6130 and US$1.6120, respectively, per £ 1. Banks are allowed to engage in spot and forward exchange transactions in any currency, and they may deal among themselves and with residents and nonresidents in foreign notes and coins at free mar- ket rates of exchange. The United Kingdom formally accepted the obli- gations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Administration of Control There are no exchange controls. The licensing of imports and exports is handled mostly by the De- partment of Trade and Industry, but other depart- ments also issue licenses in specialized fields. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency require- ments. Imports and Import Payments Payments for imports may be made freely. For import-licensing purposes, countries outside the United Kingdom are divided into ten groups: the ACP Area;1 the CEFTA Area;2 the Community Area;3 the Dollar Area;4 the Far Eastern and West- ern
