Not for Redistribution 516 UNITED KINGDOM (2) from the Dollar Area only, one group of com- modities; (3) from the German Democratic Re- public, Berlin (East), and the U.S.S.R., one group of commodities; (4) from the State Trading Area only, eight commodities or groups of commodities; and (5) from South Africa only, two commodities or groups of commodities. Individual import licenses are required where goods cannot be imported un- der the authority of the open general import license; some items are subject to surveillance licensing, under which import licenses are issued freely on demand to applicants providing certain informa- tion. Most articles subject to specific import licens- ing can be imported in limited quantities under bilateral or global quotas. A few articles may be imported under open individual licenses, that is, without limit as to quantity or value. Imports of cereals and cereal products, beef and veal, mutton and lamb, poultry meat, and dairy products other than butter and cheese are subject to minimum import prices enforced through autonomously im- posed variable import levies. Imports of many other agricultural, horticultural, and livestock products are subject to European Communities (EC) regulations. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely. Sterling bank notes may be dispatched to nonresi- dents against payment in sterling or in any foreign currency. For any type of travel, U.K. residents can obtain on demand from banks and travel agents such foreign exchange as they may require without limitation. The cost of accommodation, fares, etc. can be paid for without limit in the United Kingdom. Personal checks may be cashed abroad and credit cards may be used without restriction. Travelers may take out any amount in sterling or foreign cur- rency notes. Residents may retain unused travel exchange expressed in foreign currency after their return to the United Kingdom. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports are free of export control, and there are no requirements affecting export proceeds.12 Under the Tender to Contract Facility of the Export Credits Guarantee Department, exporters bidding for major capital projects in Canadian dollars, deut- sche mark, Japanese yen, Swiss francs, or U.S. dol- lars when the U.K. element of the contract is for the equivalent of at least £ 10 million may obtain cover against exchange rate fluctuations between the sub- mission of their bid and the award of the contract. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts in foreign currencies on account of invis- ibles may be retained or may be sold for sterling. British and other bank notes may be brought into the United Kingdom freely. Capital There are no restrictions on capital transfers by residents of the United Kingdom into the beneficial ownership of residents of other countries. All pro- ceeds from the realization, redemption, or maturity of sterling capital assets (including direct invest- ments) are remittable at the market rate of exchange. Residents of the United Kingdom who leave with the intention of residing abroad may transfer all their assets on departure from the United Kingdom. Repatriates who, having been resident in the United Kingdom, return to take up residence in any other country may transfer all their sterling assets abroad at the market rate of exchange. Investments, whether direct or portfolio, may be freely made in the United Kingdom by nonresi- dents or abroad by residents.13 However, invest- ments involving the takeover of existing U.K. com- panies that are considered a vital part of U.K. industry may be subject to the provisions of the Fair Trading Act of 1973. The Government also has powers under the Industry Act of 1975 to prevent or undo undesirable foreign takeovers of important manufacturing undertakings. There are no restrictions on transactions in ster- ling or foreign currency securities, which may be exported or imported without formality. Warrants issued by registrars, company secretaries, and pay- ing agents in respect of interest, dividends, and capital payments on securities registered in the names of nonresidents may be dispatched abroad freely. Banks may freely accept foreign currency deposits and employ them in their foreign currency business or convert them to sterling, subject to pru- dential guidelines issued by the Bank of England concerning the limitation of risks arising from their foreign exchange exposure. Net spot liabilities in foreign currencies (i.e., the net amount of foreign currency resources funding sterling assets) form part of a bank's eligible liabilities that are subject to a 12Exports of certain commodities are controlled for reasons of national security, animal welfare, national heritage, and interna- tional agreements. 13There is a voluntary ban on new direct investment in South Africa by residents, which was announced on October 30,1986. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM 517 0.45 percent non-interest-bearing deposit require- ment with the Bank of England and may also be subject to calls for special deposits to be placed with the Bank. There is currently no special deposit call. Gold Gold bullion and gold coins are not subject to control in the United Kingdom, other than imports of gold coins minted in or after 1961 and originating in South Africa. Gold sovereigns and Britannias, a new gold coin introduced in October 1987, are legal tender but do not circulate. Gold coins have also been issued in Jersey and the Isle of Man and are legal tender there. Except under license granted by the Treasury, it is an offense to melt down or break up any metal coin that is for the time being current in the United Kingdom or that, having been current there, has at any time after May 16, 1969 ceased to be so. The export of gold in manufactured form over 50 years old and valued at £ 8,000 and over for each item or matching set of items also requires a license from the Department of Trade and Industry. There is a free gold market in London in which gold bars are freely traded. Changes During 1989 No significant changes occurred in the exchange and trade system. (See Appendix for a summary of trade measures introduced and eliminated by the European Eco- nomic Community during 1989, page 567.) ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of the United States is the U.S. Dollar. The U.S. authorities do not maintain mar- gins in respect of exchange transactions, and spot and forward exchange rates are determined on the basis of demand and supply conditions in the ex- change markets. However, the authorities intervene when necessary to counter disorderly conditions in the exchange markets or when otherwise deemed appropriate. There are no taxes or subsidies on pur- chases or sales of foreign exchange. The United States formally accepted the obliga- tions of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from December 10, 1946. Administration of Control The Department of the Treasury administers li- censing programs involving direct or indirect finan- cial or commercial transactions with Cuba, Demo- cratic Kampuchea,1 the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam or their nationals,1 as well as the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, as specified under the Cuban Assets Control Regulations, the Foreign Assets Control Regulations, and the Libyan Sanc- tions Regulations. It also has administrative respon- sibility for blocked accounts of the above countries, as well as accounts of Estonia, the German Demo- cratic Republic, Latvia, and Lithuania, blocked since World War II under the Foreign Funds Control Regulations.2 The Department of the Treasury also regulates certain trade and transportation-related activities involving Nicaragua under the Nicaragua Trade Control Regulations and the Islamic Republic of Iran under the Iranian Transactions Regulations, and administers restrictions on certain trade, lend- ing, and investment activities involving South Af- rica under the South African Transactions Regula- tions pursuant to the Comprehensive Anti- Apartheid Act of 1986. The Customs Service of the Treasury Department administers import quotas; such quotas, however, are frequently established or allocated by other agencies. The Committee for the Implementation of Textile Agreements, chaired by the Department of Commerce, with representatives from other agen- cies, decides when to request consultation with ex- porting countries to limit imports on the basis of the guidelines of the Multifiber Arrangement (MFA) and bilateral restraint agreements. Import quotas on specified dairy products are administered by the Department of Agriculture through the issuance of import licenses. Global quotas on sugar and prod- ucts containing sugar are set on an annual basis by the Secretary of Agriculture. For items subject to export control—other than munitions items—the Department of Commerce is, in general, the re- sponsible authority. There are no restrictions on foreign payments, except those imposed under Treasury Department regulations for security reasons on transactions in- volving the authorities or nationals of Cuba, Demo- cratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Re- public of Korea, the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, and the authorities of the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya; those on direct trade and related transactions involving Nicaragua; those on loans and investments involving South Africa; and, to a very limited extent (see footnote 2), those affecting certain assets of the Government of the Islamic Re- public of Iran, its agencies, instrumentalities, and controlled entities. However, certain payments to Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, and the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya related to authorized travel are permit- ted, as are certain payments in connection with travel to and in the United States by nationals of these countries. Limited remittances to the remit- ter's close relatives in Cuba and the Socialist Re- public of Viet Nam are also permitted. 1As cited in the relevant national regulations. 2Payments to the Islamic Republic of Iran, except for payments from Iranian assets blocked as of January 19, 1981, were autho- rized by general license on January 19,1981, pursuant to Execu- tive Orders and regulations issued thereunder. Iranian assets blocked as of January 19, 1981 have, with limited exceptions, been transferred to the Islamic Republic of Iran or to various escrow accounts as set forth in the January 19, 1981 agreements between the United States and the Islamic Republic of Iran. Imports and Import Payments Importation of goods and services originating in or representing a property interest of Cuba, the Islamic Republic of Iran, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the So- cialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, and Nicaragua are prohibited 518 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES 519 under Treasury regulations, unless specifically au- thorized. In addition, importation is prohibited from South Africa of gold coins, uranium in the form of ore or oxide, coal, textiles, iron and steel, military articles, agricultural products, food, sugar, and any products grown, produced, manufactured, marketed, or otherwise exported by parastatal or- ganizations of South Africa, pursuant to the Com- prehensive Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986. The same Act prohibits the importation of gold coins from the U.S.S.R. Import quotas are in effect for certain products, including cotton, certain cotton waste and prod- ucts, many dairy products, peanuts, sugar and cer- tain products containing sugar, and certain spe- cialty steel products. Quotas may be imposed by the President under specified conditions on certain types of meat. All quantitative import quotas, ex- cept those for peanuts, certain cotton products, but- ter, butter oil, certain other dairy products, and certain products containing sugar, are on a country- of-production basis. Certain dairy products that are subject to quotas are also subject to import licensing. The United States is a party to the MFA negoti- ated within the framework of the General Agree- ment on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). It maintains 30 bilateral textile agreements negotiated in accor- dance with the MFA's provisions, and 12 agree- ments with nonsignatories of the MFA. These agreements control trading partners' exports of tex- tiles and apparel to the United States in specific product categories and provide for orderly expan- sion of trade while minimizing the disruption of the U.S. market for these products. Imports from both agreement and nonagreement countries are monitored along with domestic industry perfor- mance to determine if market disruption exists or is threatened. When necessary, consultations with ex- porting countries are requested to establish limitations. Imports, of a limited number of manufactured products (i.e., steel, machine tools, and shakes and shingles) are also effectively restricted by bilateral agreements or by the multilateral procedures of GATT Article XIX designed to provide temporary relief to certain distressed industries. Free-trade area agreements are in force with Israel and with Canada. The Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) for developing countries has been in operation in the United States since January 1976 and is scheduled to continue through July 4,1993. Under a procedure referred to as "product graduation/' eligibility for duty-free treatment can be withdrawn for a particu- lar product in which a beneficiary country has be- come competitive. Cumulative treatment under the GSP scheme is extended to beneficiary members of the Andean Group, the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN), and the Caribbean Com- mon Market (CARICOM); cumulation allows two or more member countries of an eligible association to contribute jointly to the requirement that at least 35 percent of the direct cost of producing a given product should originate in the beneficiary country. Exempted from competitive needs limits is a cate- gory of countries designated as "least developed" beneficiaries; currently, 32 countries are thus desig- nated.3 Under the Caribbean Basin Economic Re- covery Act, 22 countries and entities4 have been designated to receive preferential tariff treatment on specified imports for the period through Septem- ber 30, 1995. Exports and Export Proceeds Munitions may be exported only under license issued by the Office of Munitions Control in the Department of State. The Department of Commerce administers controls directly on exports of crime control and detection equipment, as well as instru- ments and related technical data, to all countries except other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), Australia, Japan, and New Zealand. The Department of Commerce adminis- ters controls directly on exports of other goods from the United States and on re-exports of goods of U.S. origin from any area. (The Treasury Department administers controls on exports to Cuba, Demo- cratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Re- public of Korea, and the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, of goods of foreign origin by foreign firms that are owned or controlled by U.S. nationals.) All exports from the United States to Cuba, Dem- ocratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Re- public of Korea, the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, and Nicaragua (with the exception of publications and other information materials, personal baggage, and Bangladesh, Benin, Bhutan, Botswana, Burkina Faso, Bu- rundi, Cape Verde, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Djibouti, Equatorial Guinea, The Gambia, Guinea, Guinea- Bissau, Haiti, Lesotho, Malawi, Maldives, Mali, Nepal, Niger, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, Western Samoa, and Yemen Arab Republic. 4Antigua and Barbuda, The Bahamas, Barbados, Belize, Brit- ish Virgin Islands, Costa Rica, Dominica, Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Grenada, Guatemala, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Jamaica, Montserrat, Netherlands Antilles, Panama, St. Kitts and Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and Trin- idad and Tobago. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 520 UNITED STATES similar items) are prohibited unless individually li- censed by the Department of Commerce and/or the Department of the Treasury. Exports of crude oil and petroleum products and materials and technol- ogy connected with nuclear power to South Africa are also prohibited, as are exports of computer tech- nology and items on the U.S. munitions list to spec- ified South African agencies. Exports to all other countries, except Canada, of designated strategic materials and equipment require validated licenses from the Department of Commerce. Persons subject to U.S. jurisdiction require a Trea- sury Department license to participate in transac- tions in strategic goods involving certain socialist countries regardless of origin, unless the transac- tion is licensed by another member of the Coordi- nating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls (COCOM). This program is administered pursuant to the Transaction Control Regulation. For many commodities, when exported to countries other than Afghanistan, member countries of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA), Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the Lao People's Democratic Re- public, the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jam- ahiriya, Nicaragua, and the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, distribution licenses may be obtained to cover multiple shipments. The licensing require- ments applicable to Yugoslavia are less restrictive than those applicable to other Eastern European countries. Under the Export Administration Act of 1979, which was amended in 1985, the President can sus- pend the export of nonagricultural goods for rea- sons of national security, foreign policy, or short supply in the domestic economy, although efforts are made to minimize the use of such authority. Export suspension of agricultural commodities may not be imposed for reasons of short supply, foreign policy, or national security unless a direct security threat exists. For agricultural commodities, such as wheat, flour, corn, sorghum, rice, soybeans and soybean products, cotton, and several others, ex- porting companies are required to participate in a reporting system that is designed to improve mar- ket information and allow for more orderly export- ing. The proceeds of exports are not subject to ex- change control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments and transfers abroad may be made freely, except for payments to or for the account of the authorities or nationals of Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, most payments to the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, and certain payments relating to Nic- aragua and South Africa.5 U.S. residents are al- lowed to remit up to US$500 a quarter to close rela- tives in Cuba and US$300 a quarter to close relatives in the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam. In addition, remittances of up to US$500 to Cuba and US$750 to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam are allowed to aid in a relative's emigration from those countries. Re- ceipts of funds from Cuba, Democratic Kam- puchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, and the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam are generally prohibited, as are certain types of payments from the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya. Cer- tain transactions in connection with authorized travel in these countries are permitted. Receipt of funds from Nicaragua is prohibited to the extent that they relate to unauthorized transactions. Indi- viduals leaving or entering the United States with more than US$10,000 in domestic or foreign cur- rency, traveler's checks, money orders, or bearer- form negotiable securities must declare these to customs at the point of exit or entry. Capital Incoming or outgoing capital payments by resi- dents or nonresidents are not subject to exchange control. In addition, inward and outward direct or portfolio investment is generally free of any other form of approval requirement. Investments involv- ing ownership interest in banks are subject to federal and state banking regulations. However, as noted above, there are restrictions on certain trans- actions with, or involving, Cuba, Democratic Kam- puchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, and, to a lesser ex- tent, Nicaragua. (See footnote 5 concerning the Is- lamic Republic of Iran.) New investments by U.S. nationals in South Africa are prohibited, subject to limited exceptions. The Johnson Act, 18 U.S.C. 955, prohibits, with certain exceptions, persons within the United States from dealing in financial obligations or extending loans to foreign governments that have defaulted on payments of their obligations to the United States Government. The Act does not apply to those for- eign governments that are members of both the IMF and the World Bank. In addition, there are certain reporting requirements for travelers entering or 5Certain payments and transfers to the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran, its instrumentalities, and controlled entities involving stand-by letters of credit, performance bonds, and similar obligations contracted prior to January 19, 1981 are subject to restrictions. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES 521 leaving the United States when they are carrying more than US$10,000 in cash or negotiable instru- ments (as well as corresponding reporting require- ments for shipment of currency or bearer assets through the mails). In addition, ownership of U.S. agricultural land by foreign nationals or by U.S. corporations in which foreign owners have a signifi- cant interest (at least 10 percent) or substantial con- trol must be reported to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Certain states in the United States im- pose varying restrictions on purchases of land within their borders by foreign nationals. Member banks are discouraged by the Federal Reserve Board from soliciting or encouraging place- ment of deposits by U.S. residents at their foreign branches, unless such deposits are placed to serve a definite, necessary purpose outside the United States. The foreign currency positions of banks, whether overall or with respect to individual cur- rencies, are not subject to limitations of a quantita- tive nature, but banks are expected to follow normal banking practices and maintain prudent positions. U.S. agencies and branches of foreign banks, as well as domestic banks, are subject to reserve re- quirements by the Federal Reserve system. Loans and extension of credit to or acceptance of deposits from the South African Government or its entities are prohibited; trade credits are exempted. Beginning December 3, 1981, U.S. chartered de- pository institutions, U.S. offices of Edge Act and Agreement Corporations,6 and U.S. branches and agencies of foreign banks were allowed to establish international banking facilities (IBFs) in the United States. IBFs may accept deposits only from foreign residents (including foreign offices of domestic banks), from other IBFs, or from the institution es- tablishing the IBF. Such funds are exempt from reserve requirements of Regulation D. For nonbank foreign residents, the minimum maturity or notice requirement is two business days, and the mini- mum transaction amount is US$100,000. Funds raised by an IBF may be used only to extend credit to foreign residents (including foreign offices of do- mestic banks), to other IBFs, or to the entity estab- lishing the IBF. Credit may be extended to nonbank foreign residents only if the proceeds are used to finance operations of the borrower or its affiliates outside the United States. Advances from an IBF to its establishing entity in the United States are sub- ject to Eurocurrency reserve requirements in the same manner as advances to the establishing entity from the entity's foreign offices. Effective Decem- 6These are defined as domestically chartered corporations au- thorized to engage in international banking and financial operations. ber 31, 1988, U.S. banks have been permitted to accept foreign currency deposits. A number of indi- vidual states (but not the Federal Government) have granted favorable tax treatment under state or local law to IBF operations. In addition, federal legislation was enacted to exempt deposits at IBFs from Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation insurance coverage and assessments. Gold U.S. citizens or residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad, except for certain gold transactions (e.g., imports or exports) involving Cuba, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the So- cialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam, and Nicaragua. Imports of South African Krugerrand and other South African gold coins, and gold coins minted in the U.S.S.R. are prohibited under the Comprehensive Anti- Apartheid Act of 1986, as are imports of gold bullion marketed by the Reserve Bank of South Africa. Commercial banks may deal in gold bullion and gold coins, with the same exceptions. Treasury licensing for importers, exporters, producers, refiners, and processors of gold is not required, with the same country exceptions. Producers of gold may sell their output in the free market, with the same country exceptions. Gold, but not counterfeit gold coins, may be freely imported, except from the countries mentioned above. U.S. gold coins are legal tender at their face value. Commercial imports of gold jewelry, except gold jewelry fashioned from U.S.S.R. or South African gold coins, are free of quantitative restriction but are subject to import duty at a rate of approximately 12 percent. There is no duty on gold ore, bullion, or coins. All forms of gold must be declared at the point of entry into the United States. Changes During 1989 Imports and Import Payments January 1. The United States replaced its existing tariff schedule with the Harmonized Tariff Sched- ule, the first major change in its commodity classi- fication and tariff structure in 25 years. Also, new textile import controls and visa arrangements based on the Harmonized System of Commodity Classi- fication became effective. The new system stan- dardized the numerical classification of goods traded in world markets. Hong Kong, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, and Taiwan Province of China were removed ("graduated") from the list of beneficiaries under ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 522 UNITED STATES the U.S. GSP, because they did not meet the com- petitive need criteria under the scheme; the decision affected an estimated US$10 billion in U.S. imports. Sanctions (in the form of 100 percent ad valorem duties) were imposed on imports of coffee, pork, and tomatoes from the European Community (EC) valued at US$100 million in response to the EC's ban on hormone-enhanced beef and beef products. On January 12, 1989, agreement was reached with the EC on a grace period for the affected products, whereby the EC agreed to allow U.S. beef and beef by-products that had received a veterinary certifi- cate for export before January 1,1989 to enter the EC markets before February 1, 1989; and the United States reciprocated by exempting from duties those imports from the EC that were on the U.S. retalia- tory list, provided that these products entered the United States before February 1, 1989. On Feb- ruary 20, 1989, a joint task force was established to examine ways to resolve the hormone dispute. On May 3, 1989, a tentative agreement was reached, under which there would be a partial resumption of U.S. beef exports to the EC; in turn, the United States agreed to lower the level of retaliatory import sanctions against the EC. However, the dispute over the health effects of growth hormones remained unresolved. In July and November 1989, in response to the partial resumption of meat exports to the EC, the retaliatory 100 percent ad valorem tariffs on U.S. imports of pork hams and tomato sauces from the EC were removed. The 1989 sugar import quotas, announced on De- cember 15, 1988, became effective; the total autho- rized import of sugar was 1.13 million metric tons, 17 percent higher than the 1988 import quota. (See also entry for September 12.) The bilateral agreement restricting textile imports from Jamaica, which was scheduled to expire at the end of 1989, was extended to the end of 1992. A voluntary export restraint was negotiated on textiles and clothing imports from the United Arab Emirates. January 4. The U.S. Customs Service reclassified certain vehicles as trucks, thereby subjecting them to the 25 percent import duty on trucks, as opposed to a duty of 2.5 percent for passenger cars. Follow- ing a review of this decision by the Treasury Depart- ment, on February 16, 1989, it was clarified that imported two-door sport/utility vehicles would be subject to the import duty for trucks (25 percent), but that four-door models of such vehicles and vans with rear seats, rear-side windows, and a rear-side door would continue to be subject to the import duty for passenger cars (2.5 percent). January 17. All trade in products made of elephant parts was banned in implementation of the Conven- tion on Trade in Endangered Species. (See also en- try for June 9.) January 19. Thailand was denied duty-free bene- fits under the GSP because of alleged failure to protect U.S. intellectual property rights. The mea- sure, which was taken in accordance with the Trade Act of 1974, affected eight products representing US$165 million a year in Thai exports to the United States, which would henceforth face duties of be- tween 2.5 and 25.7 percent. The affected products were wood furniture, mosaic ceramic floor tiles, artificial flowers, jewelry, telegraphic and tele- phonic connection equipment, rice meal and flour, dried mung beans, and precious metal jewelry. January 20. The Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) established or revised quota allocations for stainless steel bar and rod and alloy tool steel from Argentina, Austria, and Hungary (54 FR 3173). These changes were authorized under the import relief program for the specialty steel industry. Trade sanctions against the Socialist People's Lib- yan Arab Jamahiriya were modified to allow five U.S. companies to resume their Libyan operations or transfer them to foreign subsidiaries. January 26. The Department of Commerce an- nounced that imports of all-terrain vehicles from Japan were being sold at less than fair value, with dumping margins ranging from 8.47 to 35.43 per- cent. However, on March 1, 1989, the United States International Trade Commission (USITC) deter- mined that such imports were not injuring the do- mestic industry, and the investigation was terminated. January 31. The Department of Commerce ruled that imports of steel light-walled rectangular tubing from Taiwan Province of China were being sold at less than fair value, with dumping margins ranging from 5.51 to 40.97 percent. The USITC found on March 15,1989 that a U.S. industry was being mate- rially injured by these imports, and definitive anti- dumping duties were imposed. February 2. The Treasury Department amended the Foreign Assets Control Regulations and Cuban Assets Control Regulations to terminate restrictions on the importation and exportation of publications and other tangible informational materials between the United States and Cuba, Democratic Kam- puchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, and the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam. February 7. The Department of Commerce deter- mined that imports of microdisks from Japan were being sold at less than fair value, with dumping margins ranging up to 51 percent. The USITC found on March 15,1989 that these imports were injuring a ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES 523 U.S. industry; hence, definitive antidumping du- ties were imposed. The Department of Commerce announced that countervailing duties would be im- posed on imports of malleable iron pipe fittings from Thailand because they were being subsidized at the rate of 2.94 percent. February 21. The Department of Agriculture is- sued new rules for agricultural imports requiring additional certification for selected items entering the United States (54 FR 7391). March 1. Final regulations implementing the countervailing duty provisions of the Trade and Tar- iff Act of 1984 were issued (53 FR 52306). The USITC ordered that imports of certain types of memory chips made by the Hyundai Co. of the Republic of Korea be banned. The order was part of a final ruling in 1987 that concluded that Hyundai chips violated U.S. patents. March 2. The Department of Commerce deter- mined that imports of electrolytic manganese diox- ide from Greece and Japan were being dumped, with dumping margins of 77 percent and 36.72 per- cent, respectively. Definitive duties were imposed on March 4,1989, following positive determinations by the USITC that U.S. industries were being mate- rially injured or threatened with material injury by these imports. March 14. Imports of semiautomatic assault rifles were banned indefinitely, pending a review of whether these military-style weapons were being used for sporting purposes. March 20. The Department of Commerce deter- mined that imports of cloth headwear from the Peo- ple's Republic of China were being dumped in the United States, with weighted-average dumping margins ranging from 5.3 percent to 32.06 percent. However, on April 27, 1989, the USITC, in a final determination, concluded that such imports did not threaten material injury to the U.S. headgear indus- try; hence, the investigation was terminated. March 22. The United States announced the initia- tion of the first binational panel reviews of two anti- dumping cases under Chapter 19 of the U.S.- Canada Free Trade Agreement, pertaining to im- ports from Canada of red raspberries and replace- ment parts for self-propelled paving equipment. (See also entry for December 1.) March 27. The Commerce Department deter- mined that imports of anti-friction bearings from eight countries were being dumped in the United States, with margins ranging from 0.5 percent to 212.45 percent. The countries were France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Japan, Ro- mania, Singapore, Thailand, and the United King- dom. The USITC made a final determination on May 2,1989 that the dumped imports of anti-friction bearings were materially injuring a U.S. industry; hence definitive duties were imposed. The USITC also determined that a U.S. industry was being materially injured by subsidized imports of anti- friction bearings from Singapore (weighted-average subsidy rate estimated at 2.34 percent) and Thai- land (21.54 percent). March 28. Final regulations implementing dump- ing provisions of the Trade and Tariff Act of 1987 were issued by the Department of Commerce (54 FR 12742). Most of the regulations would take effect on April 27, 1989, although some would not take effect until June 1, 1989. April 3. The Department of Commerce found that imports of pipes and tubes from Argentina were being dumped in the United States, with a margin of 56.26 percent. On May 5,1989, the USITC deter- mined that a domestic industry was being injured or threatened with material injury by reason of the dumped imports; hence, antidumping duties of 56.26 percent were assessed. April 10. Antidumping duties were terminated on imports of sodium nitrate from Chile. The Depart- ment of Commerce determined that imports of fab- ricated steel wheels from Brazil were being sub- sidized at rates ranging from 1.82 percent to 17.29 percent. However, on May 17,1989, the USITC determined that the domestic industry was not suf- fering material injury by reason of these imports, and the investigation was terminated. April 12. The Department of Commerce an- nounced that imports of industrial belts, and com- ponents and parts thereof, were being sold in the United States at less than fair value from several sources, including the Federal Republic of Ger- many, Israel, Italy, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, Taiwan Province of China, and the United Kingdom. It also determined that Israel was subsidizing these products. On May 23, 1989, the USITC determined that the domestic U.S. industry was being injured by imports of industrial belts from the Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Japan, and Singapore; hence, definitive antidumping du- ties were imposed on imports from these four coun- tries. On June 7, 1989, the USITC determined that imports of subsidized industrial belts from Israel were not causing material injury to the U.S. indus- try; hence, countervailing duties were not imposed. April 28. The U.S. administration announced that retaliatory action would be taken against Japan un- der Section 301 of the U.S. Trade and Competitive- ness Act of 1988, following a determination that Japan had violated a telecommunications pact with the United States by limiting access of U.S. products ©International Monetary Fund. An unfair trade practices investigation against Canada's export policies on unprocessed sockeye salmon and herring was dropped in favor of formation of a panel to address the issue under the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement. Imports of raw and worked ivory from all ivory-producing and intermediary nations were banned as part of a drive to protect endangered species. June 9. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled that third-party imports of foreign godds bearing the same trademark as their U.S.-made version but differing in physical content should be barred under Section 42 of the Lanham Act, even if produced by affiliates of U.S. manufacturers. The Department of Commerce deter- mined that imports of generic cephalexin capsules from Canada were being sold at less than fair value, with an estimated weighted-average dumping mar- gin of 7.5 percent. However, on August 4,1989, the USITC determined that such imports did not mate- rially injure or threaten material injury to the U.S. industry, and the investigation was terminated. June 22. How- ever, on August 8,1989, the USITC determined that no U.S. industry was being injured or threatened with material injury by such imports, and the inves- tigation was terminated. July 1. The United States decided to ban remain- ing uses of cancer-causing asbestos by 1997. The ban would take effect in three stages and prohibit U.S. production/importation of all but a few indus- trial products that cannot use substitutes or where there is low chance of fiber inhalation. July 1. The USTR's annual review of the GSP program, announced in April 1989, became effec- tive, and the following measures were taken: (1) Is- rael retained its duty-free benefits; (2) Thailand lost duty-free status on goods valued at US$63 million a year, including furniture, tiles, and artificial flowers; (3) the Central African Republic and Myanmar con- tinued to have their benefits suspended; (4) nine products from 16 countries with a trade value of US$10.8 million were added to the GSP program; (5) US$8.7 million in GSP-ineligible imports were reinstated in the program; (6) an estimated US$229 million worth of imports from developing countries were removed from duty-free treatment, of which products valued at US$216 million were removed because they exceeded competitive need limits; (7) the review of the eligibility status of Haiti, Li- beria, Syria, and Venezuela was extended by one year pending investigations for alleged workers' rights violations or expropriation without compen- sation; (8) Brazil's GSP eligibility with respect to cigar filler tobacco was restored; (9) on July 7,1989, cigarette leaf tobacco was removed from the list of products eligible for duty-free treatment under the GSP; and (10) on August 10, 1989, the USTR an- nounced that the eligibility of eight countries for continued GSP duty-free treatment was under re- view, five (Benin, Dominican Republic, Indonesia, Nepal, and Thailand) for alleged failure to honor internationally recognized workers' rights prac- tices, and three (Costa Rica, Peru, and Uruguay) for allegations that their governments expropriated property from U.S. citizens or companies without compensation. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY (Position on December 32, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Uruguay is the Uruguayan New Peso. Uruguay follows a floating exchange rate pol- icy under which the exchange rate of the Uruguayan new peso is determined by market forces, although the Central Bank reserves the right, in principle, to intervene for the purpose of preventing disorderly conditions in the exchange market. Buying and sell- ing interbank rates for the U.S. dollar, the interven- tion currency, on December 29, 1989 were NUr$804.0 and NUr$805.0, respectively, per US$1. Rates for other currencies are based on U.S. dollar rates in exchange markets abroad. A tax of 2.0 percent is levied on sales of foreign exchange in both the spot and forward exchange markets, if a transaction is settled in Uruguayan new pesos; the tax rate is 0.05 percent for sales of foreign exchange through interbank operations. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk in the official or the com- mercial banking sector. Export proceeds are required to be negotiated in the banking system. (The term "negotiate" means that export proceeds may be converted into other currencies or used to pay off obligations or generate other assets.) There are no limits on the amount of foreign exchange that the Central Bank may sell to or buy from the Bank of the Republic, the Mortgage Bank, commercial banks, and banking and ex- change houses. Uruguay formally accepted the obligations of Ar- ticle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agree- ment, as from May 2, 1980. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through authorized banks, banking houses, exchange houses, and the Bank of the Republic. Any person or firm may conduct exchange transactions in the market, provided this does not become a customary business. Exchange houses must also be authorized by the Central Bank. Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries with which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agreements may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the framework of the multilateral clearing system of the Latin American Integration Associa- tion (LAIA); these countries are Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ec- uador, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru, and Venezuela. There are separate arrangements for trade in spec- ified goods with Argentina, Brazil, and Mexico, among other countries. There is a similar arrange- ment with Cuba, but settlements are effected in a currency other than the U.S. dollar. All settlements of balances under the multilateral clearing system are made in U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to registration before the goods are shipped. The registrations are generally valid for 180 days, within which period goods must be cleared through customs. Most imports are subject to import surcharges. The surcharge rates are within a range of 10-40 per- cent and are payable to the Bank of the Republic at the time of registration. Full or partial exemption from these surcharges is granted for imports from member countries of the LAIA, imports of agri- cultural inputs, imports by the public sector, im- ports of machinery, equipment, tools, and spare parts for certain priority industries, and imports under the temporary admission scheme. The Bank of the Republic also collects a consular charge of 4 percent on the f .o.b. value of imports, with certain exemptions. Most imports are also subject to a customs tariff (impuesto aduanero unico, IMADUNI) and a service charge (tasa de movilizacion de bultos, TMB), collected by the Customs Office. Tariff rates vary between zero and 15 percent. The service charge is 1 percent of the c .i .f. import price for most imports. There are exemptions to IMADUNI and TMB. The combined effective tariff rate (including surcharges, tariffs, consular fees, and service charges) is limited to a maximum of 40 percent. Import surcharges, IMADUNI, and TMB are calcu- lated either on an officially assesed price (precio de referenda), on a minimum export price, or on the actual c . i .f. value, whichever is the highest. Payments for Invisibles There are no limitations on payments for invis- ibles or the export of foreign or domestic bank notes. 528 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY 529 Exports and Export Proceeds Foreign exchange proceeds from exports must be negotiated in the banking system not later than 36 months after the date on which shipment is re- quested. Exporters are eligible for rebates in respect of indirect taxes paid during the production pro- cess; these rebates replaced the system of tax credit certificates with effect from January 1, 1983. From time to time, and for special reasons (e.g., stock position, protection, or sanitary considerations), certain exports are forbidden or subjected to special conditions. Some of the traditional exports, such as meat (mutton, beef, and horse), greasy wool (scoured and semiscoured), dry, salted, and pickled hides, and livestock on the hoof (except pedigree or pure crossbred), are subject to an export tax at the rate of 5 percent. Fish exports are eligible for tax credit certificates amounting to between 2 percent and 8 percent of the f .o.b. value of exports, which can be used by the exporter to pay taxes or social security contributions, or can be sold to a third party. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no surrender requirements on the pro- ceeds from invisibles, and there are no limitations on the import of foreign or domestic bank notes. Capital Inward and outward private capital transfers by either residents or nonresidents may be made freely, with the exception of certain inward and outward transfers relating to investments regis- tered under the Foreign Investment Law. The amor- tization or liquidation proceeds of foreign capital registered under this law cannot normally be trans- ferred abroad until three years after the date on which the investment was approved. Gold Residents and nonresidents may freely purchase, hold, and sell financial gold with a fineness of not below 0.9 in Uruguay or abroad. Gold for industrial purposes is subject to the general policy governing the export, import, and trading of goods. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement October 1. The rate of tax on sales of foreign ex- change in both the spot and forward markets was raised to 2.0 percent from 1.5 percent provided the transaction is effected in Uruguayan new pesos. Imports and Import Payments May 31. The criterion for the establishment of reference prices and minimum prices for imports was modified to limit the use of such prices to cases where prices of imported goods are considered to be below standard international prices. May 31. The maximum customs tariff rate was reduced to 40 percent from 45 percent. The customs tariffs on crude oil and its derivatives were reduced to 35 percent from 40 percent, and those on many basic items were reduced to 30 percent from 35 percent. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VANUATU (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Vanuatu is the Vatu. Since Feb- ruary 5,1988, the external value of the vatu has been determined on the basis of an undisclosed transactions-weighted basket of currencies. The Re- serve Bank of Vanuatu buys and sells foreign ex- change daily, and buying and selling rates of the vatu against major currencies (Australian dollars, French francs, deutsche mark, Japanese yen, and New Zealand dollars) are quoted within margins of 0.25 percent around the middle rate. The Reserve Bank deals with the commercial banks only in U.S. dollars on a spot basis, and buys and sells foreign exchange only in transactions with the commercial banks for account of the Government or for com- mercial banks' operations. On December 29, 1989, the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar (for telegraphic transfers) were VT 110.47 and VT 110.98 per US$1, respectively. There are no taxes or sub- sidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. There are no arrangements for forward exchange rate cover facilities operating in the official sector. As a rule, the commercial banks also do not provide forward exchange rate cover facilities. Vanuatu formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from December 1, 1982. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency require- ments. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts of resi- dents and nonresidents. Debits and credits to all accounts may be made freely. Imports and Import Payments All items may be freely imported with the excep- tion of the following: any goods that are controlled under internal legislation in the interest of national health and well-being, such as arms and ammuni- tions, explosives, and dangerous drugs; and certain plants, foodstuffs, and animals, which are also re- stricted and subject to authorization. The importa- tion of chicken pieces, canned soft drinks, and T-shirts bearing a Vanuatu motif are restricted through import licensing arrangements. A similar restriction is applied to the importation of five basic products—rice, sugar, flour, canned fish, and to- bacco products —under a scheme designed to provide funds for the National Cooperative Federa- tion. Three importers pay a commission fee to the Cooperative for the right to import these five products. Customs duties are levied mainly on an ad val- orem basis on the c . i .f. value of imports. Certain goods, including spirits, wine, beer, tobacco prod- ucts, and petroleum products, are subject to specific rates of import duty. Imported goods that compete with locally produced equivalents are generally lia- ble to high duty rates. A customs service tax of 5 percent is applied to most imports based on the duty-inclusive import value. Goods imported for a specified end-use may be exempt from import duties. These include goods imported by or on behalf of the Government that are funded by external aid, goods imported for sale to and exported by tourists, ships' stores (including fuels), goods imported for processing and re- exportation, and goods imported for investment projects. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on payments for invis- ibles. Exports and Export Proceeds With a few exceptions, no restrictions are applied on exports. Exports of trochus, green snails, beches- de-mer, and crustaceans1 are subject to authoriza- tion by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries, and Forestry. Copra and cocoa exports are channeled through the Vanuatu Commodities Marketing Board (VCMB), and exports of coffee are subject to authorization from the VCMB. Artifacts that are five years old or more are subject to authorization from the Cultural Center. Most exports are subject to export duties, mainly on an ad valorem basis (f.o.b.); specific duties are levied on some minor exports, including scrap metal and timber. There are no surrender require- ments for export proceeds. 1 Including coconut crabs for conservation purposes. 530 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VANUATU 531 Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered. Capital All inward and outward movements of capital are unrestricted. Gold There are no restrictions on gold transactions. Changes During 1989 No significant changes occurred in the exchange and trade system. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Venezuela is the Venezuelan Bolivar. Venezuela maintains a unified, interbank exchange system under which the currency is al- lowed to float in response to market forces. The U.S. dollar is the intervention currency. The Central Bank participates in the interbank market at the prevailing market-determined exchange rate; its foreign exchange sales are conducted so as to main- tain both an orderly development in the interbank market and its net international reserves targets. The Central Bank quotes daily reference exchange rates for the bolivar in terms of the U.S. dollar, which are the modes of the buying and selling rates at the closing of the interbank market. The country's largest exporter, the state-owned Petroleum Corpo- ration (PDVSA) and its affiliates, is obliged to sell to the Central Bank its foreign exchange earnings, ex- cept for those needed to maintain working balances at a level pre-approved by the Central Bank Direc- torate. The Central Bank enters into agreement writh PDVSA on the amount to be bought at the average interbank selling rate minus 10 centavos. The Central Bank's reference exchange rate applies to official foreign exchange transactions, other than with PDVSA, that must be effected through the Central Bank, which mainly include disbursements and debt-service payments associated with public and publicly guaranteed external debt and imports of goods and services by the Central Government. The reference buying and selling rates on Decem- ber 29, 1989 were Bs 42.95 and Bs 43.05 per US$1, respectively. The Central Bank sells, under a transi- tional arrangement, foreign exchange at Bs 4.30, Bs 7.50, and Bs 14.50 per US$1 for settlement of certain import and private debt-service payment obligations registered with the Central Bank, sub- ject to exchange rate guarantee, and outstanding before the date of the adoption of the unified ex- change system (on March 14, 1989). All other cur- rent and capital transactions are effected through the interbank foreign exchange market at the uni- fied, market-determined rate. Resident commercial banks and exchange houses are designated as authorized foreign exchange dealers. Exchange houses are allowed to deal only in narrowly defined cash (currency notes, coins, and traveler's checks) and are not authorized to hold or trade in foreign currency deposits. Resident com- mercial banks are allowed to hold foreign exchange deposits, sell such deposits to, and buy them from, other commercial banks, and purchase foreign cur- rency personal checks. Sales of foreign exchange by authorized dealers to nonresident corporations, ex- cept to correspondent banks, are prohibited. Tour- ism establishments are allowed to offer their clients foreign exchange services in the form of purchase and sale of foreign currency notes, coins, and trav- eler's checks. Cover against exchange risk is provided through forward foreign exchange contracts negotiated freely between participants in the interbank market without the intervention of the Central Bank. How- ever, as of the end of 1989, the forward foreign exchange market remained underdeveloped mainly as a result of limitations affecting the domestic fi- nancial markets. Venezuela formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agree- ment on July 1, 1976. Administration of Control Foreign exchange policies are established by the Ministry of Finance and the Central Bank. Within the guidelines prescribed by the Ministry of Fi- nance, the Central Bank Directory regulates and supervises the foreign exchange activities of autho- rized dealers. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, the Ministry of Development, the Ministry of Defense, or the Ministry of Foreign Rela- tions, depending on the product. The Superintendancy of Foreign Investment (SIEX) supervises foreign investments in Venezu- ela, contracts with nonresidents involving technol- ogy transfers and the use of foreign patents and trademarks. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Payments between Venezuela and Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Cuba, the Domini- can Republic, Ecuador, Jamaica, Mexico, Peru, and Uruguay may be settled through accounts main- tained with each other by the Central Bank of Vene- zuela and the central banks of the countries concerned. 532 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA 533 Imports and Import Payments Imports from South Africa are prohibited. Some imports, irrespective of country of origin, are sub- ject to licensing control for environmental, health, or security reasons. At the end of 1989, import li- censes intended for the protection of domestic in- dustries are estimated to have covered about 15 per- cent of manufacturing.1 Protection-related licenses apply to all imports, except those from the member countries of the Andean Pact and Latin American Integration Association (LAIA) and from South Af- rica. Arms and ammunition may be imported only by the Government. Payments for imports can be effected freely through the interbank market. Nor- mally, imports are financed with 90-day letters of credit opened at a domestic commercial bank. In some instances, private sector imports are financed directly by the importer or with suppliers' credits. Customs tariffs on manufactured goods are mostly on an ad valorem basis, with a maximum rate of 80 percent on consumer goods and of 50 per- cent on intermediate and capital goods. Raw mate- rials for industries are generally subject to tariff rates of a maximum of 50 percent or lower.2 Customs tariffs on certain goods are higher than 80 percent, and some specific tariffs apply to agricultural prod- ucts and to certain products included in Chapter 27 of the Tariff Code (corresponding to mineral fuels, oil, mineral wax, distilled products, and bi- tuminous substances). Exemptions from customs tariffs apply only to the products in the "basic bas- ket," consisting of 17 essential consumer goods3 and to articles imported entirely for assembly in Venezuela (C.K.D. regime).4 In addition to customs tariffs, all imports are sub- ject to customs service charges assessed on an ad valorem basis. These charges are 5 percent for arti- cles imported by air, land, and sea, and 2 percent for articles imported in postal packages. Storage According to the timetable of the Government's Trade Reform (Decree 239 of May 24, 1989), between March and Septem- ber 1990 the coverage of licenses required for protective purposes is to be reduced to a maximum of 5 percent of manufacturing production. 2The timetable of the Trade Reform calls for a reduction in March 1990 of the maximum tariff on manufacturing sector im- ports to 50 percent. 3Wheat flour, edible food products made from wheat, table rice, precooked maize flour, canned sardines, powdered milk, refined or brown sugar, mixed vegetable oil, pasteurized semi- fatty white cheese, pulses, infant formulas, dehydrated soups, essential medicines, type C toilet paper, fertilizers, and urban and intercity passenger transportation vehicles. 4The timetable of the Trade Reform calls for the elimination of customs tariff exemptions for articles under the C.K.D. regime by early 1991. charges apply to imports that remain in customs warehouses for more than 12 days. The industrial free zone of Paraguana and the Free Port of Margarita Island enjoy a special customs regime that includes exemptions from customs tariffs. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely through the interbank market without limit, except that an annual ceiling applies to dividend remit- tances on direct foreign investment in nonpriority areas or those associated with debt-conversion schemes (see section on Capital, below). A fee of Bs 900 is charged to travelers leaving Venezuela for business purposes; the fee for tourists and children under the age of 12 is Bs 505. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to South Africa are prohibited. There are no other controls or restrictions on exports, except for products included in the "basic basket" and certain goods specified by the Government for rea- sons of public interest.5 With the exception of the export earnings of PDVSA and its affiliates, export proceeds are not subject to surrender requirements and may be sold freely in the interbank market. Exports containing domestic value added of 30 percent or more are entitled to a fiscal credit in the form of a negotiable bond issued by the Ministry of Finance. These bonds may be used for the pay- ment of taxes. The rate of fiscal credit is 30 percent (based on the f .o .b. value of exports) for products with domestic value added of between 30 percent and 90 percent, and 35 percent for exports with domestic value added of between 91 percent and 100 percent. PDVSA and Ferrominera Orinoco have the mo- nopoly on the exportation of hydrocarbons and iron ore, respectively. The National Funds for Coffee and Cocoa, which are autonomous institutions attached to the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, have the monopoly on the exportation of coffee and co- coa, respectively. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles are not subject to sur- render requirements. Travelers may freely import 5The list of articles subject to export licenses includes certain agricultural products (milk, green peas, lentils, dry beans, rice, and maize), prepared and canned sardines, saccharose, sugar, uranium and thorium minerals, metallic minerals, and fertilizers. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 534 VENEZUELA domestic and foreign currency, with the exception that the importation for commercial purposes of foreign coins other than gold coins is prohibited. Capital Direct foreign investments in the petroleum sec- tor are prohibited. Certain other sectors are re- served for mixed or national ownership (e.g., basic industries, domestic commercialization of nondur- able goods, mass media, and communications), but the Government may modify the restriction in ex- ceptional cases. New investments do not require prior authorization from the SIEX; ex post registra- tion with the SIEX is required and approval is auto- matically granted if the new investment meets any one of seven general criteria.6 Reinvestment of profits does not require prior authorization and is not restricted. Dividend remittances in respect of investment in nonpriority areas are subject to an annual limit equal to 20 percent plus the prevailing LIBOR rate of the registered foreign investment amount, net of Venezuelan income tax on divi- dends. There are no limits on dividend remittances associated with priority foreign investments, which include (1) investments in agriculture, agro- industry, construction, tourism, data processing, electronics, and biotechnology; (2) joint ventures with the State; and (3) investments in companies exporting more than 50 percent of their production. Repatriation of capital is not restricted, provided that all domestic taxes have been paid and the corre- sponding investments have been duly registered.7 An auction-based scheme governs the conversion of public external debt into domestic equity. The Central Bank conducts monthly public auctions of a preannounced amount (expressed in terms of U.S. dollars) of debt-conversion rights. This amount is based on an annual ceiling set by an Interministerial Debt Conversion Commission and quarterly dis- tributions of such a ceiling made by the Central Bank in view of monetary policy targets. National or foreign investors seeking to participate in this 6Foreign direct investments must either: (1) incorporate na- tional value added equal to at least 40 percent; (2) export prod- ucts with at least 30 percent national value added; (3) generate significant levels of employment; (4) be established in geo- graphic zones considered to be relatively less developed econom- ically; (5) bring technology to the country; (6) pledge to reinvest in the country at least 50 percent of profits; or (7) substantially contribute to import substitution. 7A substantial liberalization of the foreign direct investment regime was introduced on January 26, 1990 (Decree 727). The main changes concerned the reduction of the number of sectors reserved for mixed or national ownership, the removal of the limits on dividend remittances, and permission for foreign inves- tors to participate in the Caracas Stock Exchange. scheme must first submit to the SIEX a request for debt-equity conversion, accompanied by appropri- ate documentation, including a specific investment plan involving eligible investments.8 The SIEX, upon examination of the documentation, recom- mends approval of the request to the Inter- ministerial Commission. Approved investments receive a "Constancia de Calificacion," which au- thorizes the investor to participate for one year in the auctions up to the amount of conversion re- quested. (The period may be extended to two years.) In order to present bids at the auction, an autho- rized investor must deposit with a financial institu- tion or insurance company a guarantee in bolivares in favor of the Central Bank for an amount equiv- alent to 5 percent of the face value of the external public debt intended to be tendered at each auction. This guarantee is released to the investor only on completion of the conversion or rejection of the bid. Bids are presented in sealed envelopes and must include, inter alia, the face value of the external public debt to be converted, the discount relative to face value at which the investor is willing to convert such debt, and an indication of whether the conver- sion would be partial or total. Winning bids receive a "Constancia de Conversion/' that is, a nontransfer- able, nonnegotiable right, valid for 60 days, to effect the conversion of the tendered debt at the bid dis- count and at the reference exchange rate of the Central Bank prevailing at the time of the conversion. A "total" conversion is allowed when a winning bidder submits to the Central Bank, in one opera- tion, the entire amount of external public debt au- thorized for conversion under the Constancia de Calificacion. Under the modality of "partial" con- versions, a winning bidder has the right to convert the external public debt in the Constancia de Cal- ificacion in a series of operations, according to a timetable presented with the bid, without having to participate in fu ture auctions. Partial conversions are allowed only when the external public debt to be converted has a face value of more than US$2 mil- lion. Under the system of partial conversions, the investor must tender in the auction at least 20 per- cent of the face value of the external debt, provided that the amount does not exceed 50 percent of the amount of conversion rights being auctioned. The 8Eligible investments are those directed at either export indus- tries, import-substituting industries, preventing closure of Vene- zuelan enterprises, or one of the following 12 priority sectors: agriculture, agro-industry, infrastructural construction, con- struction of low-income housing, tourism, capital goods produc- tion, chemical products, electronics and data processing, bio- technology, aluminum, metal working, and mining. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA 535 discount applicable to partial conversions is the weighted-average discount obtained in the auction immediately preceding the date of each partial con- version. Both total and partial conversions are effected at the reference exchange rate of the Cen- tral Bank prevailing at the time of the conversion. The Central Bank may purchase the external debt associated with winning bids either with domestic currency or with public internal debt securities. The proceeds from the conversion are transferred to a trust account constituted by the investor with a fiduciary agent (which could be a commercial bank, an insurance company, or the Central Bank itself). The fiduciary agent has the responsibility of ensur- ing the proper use of the trust account and will release the funds to the recipient resident enter- prise according to the timetable of the investment. There are no restrictions on conversions of private external debt into private domestic debt or equity; these conversions may be effected freely through the interbank market. Foreign direct investments in Venezuela associ- ated with conversions of public or private external debt are subject to the same regulations that apply to ordinary direct investments, with important ex- ceptions in respect of dividend remittances and cap- ital repatriation. Dividend remittances on invest- ments associated with debt conversions are subject to an annual limit of 10 percent of the registered investment during the first three years after regis- tration. Capital repatriation is not allowed for five years, and an annual maximum of 12.5 percent of the registered investment may be repatriated dur- ing the following eight years. Following the pre- scribed periods, the dividend remittances and capi- tal repatriation of direct investments associated with debt conversions are subject to the same reg- ulations as those that apply to ordinary direct investments. Capital inflows and principal repayments associ- ated with external debt contracted or guaranteed by the Venezuelan Republic require parliamentary ap- proval and must be channeled through the Central Bank. Prior authorization from the SIEX is required for private sector external borrowing that carries a maturity of more than two years. All foreign credit transactions of the private sector must be registered with the SIEX. Gold Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment purposes. Gold coins, medallions, and bars are freely negotiated among authorized travelers, ex- change houses, and the public. Commercial banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and other residents but do not normally deal in gold with the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold and imports of gold coins that are legal tender in Venezuela are reserved for the Central Bank. Imports and exports of nonmonetary gold (other than jewelry for personal use) and of gold coins eligible as legal tender in Venezuela or abroad are subject to prior authorization by the Central Bank. In addition, imports may require licenses from the Central Bank and, in some cases, from the Ministry of Development. The Central Bank may authorize private exporters to export gold bars, provided that such exports are re-imported following transforma- tion processes not available in the country and that the re-imported gold is used as an input in domestic production. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement March 13. The system of multiple exchange rates was replaced by a unified, interbank market system under which the exchange rate would be allowed to be determined by market forces. Virtually all forms of exchange control were eliminated. On a transi- tional basis, the exchange rates of Bs 4.30, Bs 7.50, and Bs 14.50 per US$1 would be applied to the settlement of certain import and private debt- service obligations contracted before the new ex- change system took effect subject to exchange rate guarantee. June 19. Regulations were issued concerning the sale by the Central Bank of foreign exchange at Bs 4.30, Bs 7.50, and Bs 14.50 per US$1 for regis- tered private external debt-service payments. Imports and Import Payments May 24. The first stage of the Government's new Trade Reform for the manufacturing sector was ini- tiated. Licenses and prohibitions previously im- posed for protective purposes were eliminated on 1,899 items, which represented 76.9 percent of all manufacturing sector imports that were subject to such licenses. Specific tariffs on manufactured goods were replaced with ad valorem tariffs. Ex- emptions from customs tariffs for manufactured goods were eliminated, except for 17 essential con- sumer goods in the "basic basket" and for entirely dismantled articles intended for assembly in Vene- zuela (articles falling under the C.K.D. regime). The maximum ad valorem customs tariff rate was set at 80 percent for consumer goods and at 50 percent for raw materials and intermediate and capital goods. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 536 VENEZUELA Exports and Export Proceeds May 24. Licensing requirements and prohibitions on exports of manufactured goods, except for the products included in the "basic basket" and goods identified by the Government for reasons of public interest, were abolished. August 17. The fiscal credit for exports was modi- fied to apply only to those containing domestic value added of 30 percent or more. The fiscal credit, consisting of a negotiable bond that may be used for tax payments, was set at 30 percent (of f .o.b. value) for exports with domestic value added of between 30 and 90 percent, and at 35 percent for exports with domestic value added of between 91 and 100 percent. Capital March 15. A new framework for debt-equity con- versions was established. September 6.
