Not for Redistribution VIET NAM (Position on December 31, 1989) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Viet Nam is the Dong. The ex- change rate is quoted in terms of the U.S. dollar. Adjustments to the exchange rate, aimed at main- taining the spread with the parallel market ex- change rate within a given range, are made at irreg- ular intervals in light of developments in the domestic economy and movements in international prices. In March 1989, the previous system of multiple exchange rates applied to various transactions was abolished. All previous exchange rates were unified at the level of the then-prevailing parallel market exchange rate of D 4,500 per US$1. On Decem- ber 29, 1989, the official exchange rate was D 4,300 per US$1. Most of Viet Nam's trade and financial settlements with the member countries of the CMEA are effected in transferable rubles through the International Bank for Economic Cooperation (IBEC).1 On December 29, 1989, the transferable ruble rate (TR) was D 1,190 = TR1 for machinery and equipment and D 1,500 = TR1 for most other transactions. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the State Bank of Viet Nam. Foreign trade is administered by the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations, which authorizes the foreign trade transactions carried o>ut by specialized import-export corporations and some cooperatives or state enterprises. Import and export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Foreign Eco- nomic Relations; approval is given for imports in excess of the plan on the merit of each application. Most foreign exchange transactions are effected by the Bank for Foreign Trade. Most of the foreign exchange transactions related to foreign technical assistance are monitored by the Aid Reception Commission, which is an agency directly attached to the Cabinet of the Prime Minister. Foreign invest- ment regulations are coordinated by the State Com- mittee for Cooperation and Investment (SCCI). Ar- rears are maintained with respect to external payments. 1The member countries of the CMEA are Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and Viet Nam. Prescription of Currency Trade transactions with member countries of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA) are settled under the transferable ruble system ad- ministered by the International Bank for Economic Cooperation (IBEC). Transactions with Albania, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, and the Demo- cratic People's Republic of Korea are settled through individual clearing accounts using clearing (or bilat- eral) rubles. As a member of the CMEA, Viet Nam is entitled to use credits in transferable rubles from the IBEC to facilitate the clearing of transactions with the CMEA member countries. Viet Nam is also entitled to use credits from the IBEC to finance its external trade deficit with the CMEA countries, pending the conclusion of medium- or long-term financing arrangements with the trade parties. Viet Nam maintains a special current account in convert- ible foreign exchange with the IBEC for a petroleum joint venture between Viet Nam and the U.S.S.R. Nontrade transactions with countries with which Viet Nam has bilateral payments agreements2 take place at exchange rates specified in those agreements. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents are permitted to maintain nonresi- dent accounts either in foreign currencies or in con- vertible dong. Nonresidents can freely reconvert into foreign currency and transfer abroad unused balances in Vietnamese currency that have been acquired against foreign currency. Imports and Exports An import plan and an export plan are drawn up annually on the basis of the overall annual plan and quotas agreed upon under bilateral trade arrange- ments. Import and export activities are regulated by Decision No. 177, which was issued by the Council of Ministers on June 15,1985 and amended by Deci- sion No. 161 of the Council of Ministers of Octo- ber 1, 1988, and by Decree No. 65/HDBT of the 2At the end of 1989, Viet Nam maintained bilateral payments agreements with three member countries of the Fund —the Lao People's Democratic Republic, Mali, and the Syrian Arab Re- public (only the agreement with the Lao People's Democratic Republic was operative), and with two countries that are not members of the Fund—Albania and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. 537 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 538 VIET NAM Council of Ministers of June 10,1989. Trade transac- tions are carried out by 140 import-export com- panies, which produce exportable goods them- selves or purchase them from producers. About 240 producers have temporary or permanent trading rights that allow them to export and import directly. In addition, about 100 foreign-owned or joint ven- ture companies trade directly with foreign partners. State-owned companies with annual export turn- over of more than US$5 million may obtain perma- nent foreign direct trading rights, while those with export turnover in the range of US$2-5 million may obtain temporary (annual) foreign direct trading rights. Other firms may obtain direct export permits on the basis of shipments or investment trade with an export-import corporation. All payments for ex- ternal trade transactions are made through the Bank for Foreign Trade; export receipts are also normally channeled through the Bank for Foreign Trade. Local export companies are permitted to export all available commodities, including the 25 items previously under the monopoly of the central export-import companies. Local corporations may import only commodities appearing on a list ap- proved by the Ministry of Foreign Economic Rela- tions, which is amended periodically. The procure- ment prices of exportable commodities and the domestic prices of imported goods are determined by local companies within ranges that are set by the State Pricing Commission for each group of com- modities. In order to make better use of available marketing expertise and facilities, local trading com- panies in the provinces are permitted to enter into joint venture arrangements with trading companies located in various municipalities. Following the fulfillment of the export plan against the delivery of input by the Government, export-producing enterprises are entitled either to retain 10-30 percent of export earnings in deposits in foreign currencies or to use foreign exchange at their discretion; the remainder must be surrendered to the Government. In the case of exports not cov- ered by the plan, the relevant proportion that can be retained by the enterprises is 70-90 percent. Local trading companies are also required to sur- render 10-30 percent of their export earnings (in convertible currencies) that exceed the quota deliv- ered to the State. However, many exemptions cur- rently apply. For localities that borrow in foreign currency, the surrender requirement is applied to their export earnings, net of their debt-servicing payments, for a period of three to five years; com- panies operating in the highland area are exempted from surrendering foreign exchange for a period of five years after they start producing exportable goods. Centrally managed companies operating in the tourist sectors are exempted from the surrender requirement, and central companies exporting coal, rubber, and marine products are allowed to retain 80-100 percent of their export earnings to purchase necessary inputs from the convertible area. De- posits arising from foreign currency receipts are held in special domestic currency accounts that can be used for the purchase of foreign currency for imports. The right to use these convertible dong deposits can be relinquished to other enterprises in exchange for the supply of inputs. State enterprises have two export plans. Primary export plans are formulated by the Government against deliveries of key inputs by the Government; secondary plans are set by the producing units which do not obtain a sufficient supply of inputs (e.g., fuel) by the Government, thus leaving the task of procuring the needed inputs to the enterprises. New taxes on international trade became effective in April 1989. Import duties ranging from 3 percent to 100 percent were introduced. The lowest rates are levied on imports of raw materials and capital equipment, and the highest rates are levied on im- ports of consumer goods classified as luxuries (pre- viously, import duties were levied only on noncom- mercial imports, and this duty was retained). Export taxes for most products range up to 50 per- cent. For imports from the nonconvertible currency area, foreign exchange is allocated annually to im- porters on the basis of production plans; in princi- ple, such foreign exchange cannot be carried over from one year to the next. For imports from the convertible area, although a similar foreign ex- change allocation system exists in principle, it is not in use, as decisions to allocate foreign exchange are taken by the Prime Minister's Cabinet on a case-by- case basis, on recommendations from the State Planning Commission, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations, and spec- ified Vice-Premiers. For transactions under the local production plans, local authorities are authorized to decide on foreign exchange allocation, provided that the resources are derived from their retained export earnings. Food grains, coffee, peanuts, rubber, coconut meat and oil, logs and lumber, and metals and metal wastes are subject to export quotas; transportation vehicles, cement, electronic goods and compo- nents, textiles, bicycles, electric fans, beer, soft drinks, cigarettes, cosmetics, and ready-made clothes are subject to import quotas. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET NAM 539 Payments for Invisibles All transactions in invisibles require individual authorization by the Ministry of Finance. Foreign exchange is made available upon authorization of the transaction. All travel abroad needs individual authorization from the Prime Minister's Cabinet and is limited to official businesses for which all reasonable foreign exchange expenses are covered.3 Receipts from transactions in invisibles must be sur- rendered to the Ministry of Finance. The export and import of Vietnamese currency and of securities denominated in Vietnamese cur- rency need the special permission of the State Bank. As from October 1988, Vietnamese citizens having foreign currency have been allowed to sell it to banks at commercial exchange rates, to make pur- chases at shops selling goods for foreign exchange, or to deposit it into bank accounts bearing interest on foreign currency at interest rates set by the bank. Foreign currency deposited with a bank may be withdrawn for payment or transfer to other units or individuals. Legal holders of foreign exchange are authorized to buy foreign and local consumer goods in special government shops, and tourists are re- quired to make certain payments in convertible for- eign currency. Capital A new law on foreign investment was approved by the National Assembly on December 29, 1987, providing for three forms of foreign investment: (1) contracted business cooperation, such as product-sharing arrangements; (2) joint ventures between a foreign investor and a Vietnamese state economic organization; and (3) categories wholly owned by foreign investors. The permitted share of foreign capital is to be no less than 30 percent, and there is no upper limit. Other provisions under the Investment Code include: (1) the duration of the enterprise with foreign capital, not to exceed 20 years, but if necessary, to be extended for a longer period; (2) a tax of 5-10 percent, to be levied on remittance of profits abroad; (3) income taxes, to be paid at the reduced rates of 15-25 percent, starting two years after the first profit-making year; and (4) possible exemptions from or reductions of import and export duties in exceptional cases. The Code also provides that foreign investors need to deal only with one organization within the Government specifically created for that purpose. 3As of February 1988, private travel has been permitted for specified reasons, including study, health, and visiting relatives abroad. In the latter case, the traveler must have a round-trip ticket and adequate funds provided by transfers from the rela- tives abroad. Beginning October 1988, Vietnamese organiza- tions and citizens who need foreign currency for production and business purposes are permitted, upon verification by competent agencies, to borrow foreign currency or get a bank guarantee for loans in foreign currency. If allowed to borrow directly from foreign countries under commercial credit, the bor- rower must report periodically to the State Bank the expenditures in foreign currency from funds depos- ited abroad, including loan repayments. Gold Gold may be brought into the country, provided that required customs declarations are made and a customs tariff is paid; nonresidents are entitled to export gold up to the amount they brought in. The price of gold for domestic transactions is set at auc- tions organized by the Viet Nam Gold and Silver Trading Company. Changes During 1989 Exchange Arrangement March 5.
